PROCTEXT.PARA: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Kerry Sibraa) took the chair at 10 a.m., and read prayers.

PETITION.TITLE: Australia Card Legislation
PETITION.PARA: The Acting Clerk-Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:
Australia Card Legislation

To the President and Senators in Parliament assembled, your humble petitioners showeth that the proposed Australia Card will have a dramatic impact on the lives of all Australians, and your petitioners therefore request a national referendum on the Australia Card Bill before the proposal is resubmitted to Parliament.
As in duty bound your petitioners will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Australia Card Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
(1) That we are totally opposed to the introduction of the Australia Card
(2) That this National Identity System will be intrusive, will not appreciably combat tax or social security fraud, is authoritarian and alien to the Australian way of life.
Your petitioners most humbly pray that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, should:
urge the Government to institute a national referendum on the Australia Card Bill before the proposal is re-submitted to Parliament.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Telecom: Metered Calls
PETITION.PARA: This humble petition from certain businessmen of Western Australia requests that representation be made to Telecom advising it to immediately abandon its reported proposal to charge local telephone calls on a time basis.
We humble petitioners believe that such a proposal, if implemented, would seriously damage the continued welfare and profitability of many small businesses in Western Australia.

PETITION.TITLE: Food Irradiation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and the members of the Senate in the House assembled.
The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:

That we most strongly oppose the process of `food irradiation' by cobalt 60 or any other radioactive substance. That we oppose the introduction of regulations that will facilitate the food irradiation process being permitted by State Governments. That we express our deep concern at this attempt to extend the use of radioactive substances and exposure of workers to radiation.

Your petitioners humbly pray that the Senate ban the importation of radioactive Cobalt 60 or other radioactive substances for the purpose of food irradiation and disallow regulations permitting the irradiation of food in Australia.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Casino: Australian Capital Territory
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
The petition of the undersigned shows that:
most of the patronage of a casino in Canberra would come from local residents, not tourists
Canberra families would suffer economically and socially if a casino were to be established in the ACT

any potential economic benefits from income generated by the casino would be outweighed by the costs to the community of the damage to individuals and families caused by compulsive gamblers who provide most of the revenue of Australia's casinos

Your petitioners therefore request the Senate and the Government of the Commonwealth of Australia to reject any proposal for or legislation which would permit the establishment of a casino in the Australian Capital Territory.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Superannuation Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That we consider the 2% discounting of Commonwealth Occupational Superannuation Scheme pension adjustments on 10 Oct 86 to be a serious breach of trust by the Government. The Commonwealth has reneged on an established commitment as incorporated in Commonwealth legislation and benefit promise pensions are not being paid in full. In particular we resent the long-term effect of the discounting. The pension loss is compounded throughout the life of a pensioner and surviving dependants-into the 21st century for many. We consider this Government-induced penalty to be out of all proportion to the short-term ``extraordinary circumstances of the economy'' given as the reason for the discounting.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Government:

1. limit the pension discounting effect of the Superannuation and Other Benefits Legislation Amendment Act 1986 to the period 10 Oct 1986 to 1 Jul 87 so that pensions are restored to the 9 Oct 1986 level as a base for the 1987 pension adjustment; and
2. consult with organisations representing pensioners before changing the terms and conditions of Commonwealth Occupational Superannuation Schemes.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Post Office: St Morris, South Australia
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
The petition of the undersigned shows:
Signatures of people protesting against the closure of the Post Office at 403 Magill Road, St Morris.
Your petitioners request that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, should:
Request that the Post Office remains open.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: BAUME

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I present to the Senate the following petition, from 60 petitioners, which is not in conformity with the Standing Orders as it is not in the correct form, requesting that the Senate urge the Government to reform tax for pensioners:

SPEECH.PARA: Dear Senator
I am writing to you concerning the steadily deteriorating position of pensioners.

The decline in the value of pensions is well known, yet little is known about the influence of taxation on their living standards. Contrary to popular belief, pensioners pay tax. Not only do they pay sales and excise taxes like other members of the community, but those who earn more than $3.72 per week above the standard pension are liable for income tax. In the next financial year, unless reforms are made to the income tax system, pensioners will pay income tax on the pension itself.
More tax reform?

The Income Tax reforms undertaken by the Government in 1986-87 brought little relief to pensioners and low income earners. The recently announced review of the Corporate Tax system and of tax concessions in the cause of superannuation provide an opportunity to direct some benefits to people in greater need.

It is recognised that there may be some justice in rationalising the Corporate Tax system to make it comparable to our overseas competitors, however, there is a stronger case in our view to direct some attention to the needs of pensioners.

The Combined Pensioners Association has proposed an increase in the value of the Pensioner Tax Rebate from $250 p.a. to $700 p.a. This would enable pensioners to earn up to $40 per week above the pension, as allowed under the Social Security means test, without any losses through the income tax system.
The Pensioner Rebate has not been increased since it was introduced in 1982 and, through the effect of inflation, its value has declined by 46 per cent.

The other matter of considerable concern is provisional tax. The policy of encouraging pensioners to invest their savings to supplement their meagre pensions is being negated through the threat of provisional tax.
These two key issues, the threat posed to living standards through the income tax system and provisional tax require urgent attention.
As a Senator representing the people of NSW I urge you to support the calls of pensioners for tax reform. Pensioners deserve better treatment than they are getting at the moment.
Yours sincerely,
G. DRISCOLL
Hon. Secretary

DEBATE.TITLE: STANDING COMMITTEE ON LEGAL AND CONSTITUTIONAL AFFAIRS

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the report of the Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs on matters relating to the War Crimes Amendment Bill 1987, together with submissions and the transcript of evidence.

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the report.

On 15 December 1987 the Senate referred a series of matters relating to the War Crimes Amendment Bill 1987 to the Committee for inquiry and report. The Committee's inquiry provoked considerable public interest and debate and attracted more than 350 submissions. We also held two days of public hearings in Canberra at the beginning of this month.

The terms of reference required the Committee initially to consider whether the general nature of the evidence and the related material believed to be available in foreign countries, particularly the Soviet Union and eastern European countries, is likely to be of sufficient evidentiary value to warrant the institution of any prosecutions. In so doing, we were precluded from encompassing the facts of particular identified cases. The Committee is of the view that it is not possible to form a judgment on the evidentiary value of such evidence without referring to specific cases.

The only material before us on the general nature of this evidence came from Mr R. F. Greenwood, QC, the Director of the Special Investigations Unit. The Committee notes that Mr Greenwood advised that he had `grave doubts' that such evidence, of itself, would be likely to be of sufficient evidentiary value.

In the light of the prohibition against referring to specific cases, and having no first-hand knowledge of the general body of evidence and related material believed to be available in foreign states, the Committee is not able to report to the Senate that it has formed any final conclusion on the evidentiary value of `the evidence and related material believed to be available in foreign states'. The Committee's tentative conclusions on the evidentiary value of this material were not unanimous. The majority of the Committee, that is all members except Senator Stone and myself, have taken the view that, on the basis of Mr Greenwood's advice, including his advice that evidence and related material was available in the Soviet Union and other Eastern European countries, it is reasonable to expect that if that evidence and related material were to be brought to Australia, its evidentiary value is likely to be sufficient to warrant the institution of prosecutions.

The minority on this point, that is Senator Stone and I, are not satisfied on the basis of what was put to the Committee that there is available in foreign states, and in particular in the Soviet Union and other Eastern European countries, evidence and related material of sufficient evidentiary value to be likely to warrant the institution of any prosecutions. Senator Stone took this view one step further, and concluded that, if the Bill is enacted and prosecutions initiated, evidence and related material from the Soviet Union and Eastern European countries should be used only if corroborated by material derived from outside those countries.

Term of reference (b) required the Committee to consider what procedures should apply to the collection of evidence in foreign states, if it is available. The Committee is firmly of the view that witnesses and evidence should be produced for examination, and cross-examination, in Australia. Despite the procedures laid down in Part IIIB of the Evidence Act 1905 and also the provisions in the various court rules for taking evidence overseas on commission, the Committee concluded that it could not contemplate any situation where these procedures should be adopted for taking evidence on future prosecutions, if the Bill is enacted.

On the question of applicable law, the Committee has recommended that the Bill be amended to require any prosecution to be conducted in the jurisdiction in which the defendant is resident when the prosecution is brought. Further, we have recommended that the Bill be amended to allow the magistrate or trial judge, as the case may be, the discretion to terminate proceedings and authorise the prosecutor to re-enter them in another jurisdiction, in accordance with the rules of forum non conveniens or as agreed between the prosecutor and the defendant. The Committee was concerned by the failure of the Bill to prescribe the substantive law to be applicable in any prosecutions. Accordingly, we have recommended that the Bill be amended to include a provision that the part of Australia in which the act in question would have been an offence-in the sense contemplated by proposed section 6-be the part of Australia, that is, jurisdiction, in which the proceedings are brought.

In relation to term of reference (c), and following on from the Committee's other recommendations, the Committee concluded that the normal rules of evidence and procedure should apply in any war crimes trials. This conclusion was reached, at least in part, because of our considered view that the accused in such trials should not be in any way disadvantaged simply because of the nature of the offences alleged. Similarly, in relation to term of reference (d), the Committee concluded that the procedures for instituting and conducting war crimes trials should be the same as in other criminal proceedings. This was, in our view, the best means of ensuring that there will be no diminution in the normal standards of justice applicable in Australia if such trials are conducted. Following from this conclusion, the Committee is of the view that both the prosecution and the defence should have an unrestricted opportunity to examine and cross-examine witnesses. The Committee was of the firm view that this should take place in front of the jury.

In adopting this view, the Committee has consciously rejected the practice of videotaping of witnesses' depositions which has been extensively used in United States cases. We were aware that the videotaping of witnesses' depositions appears to have been an integral part of the agreement which is reported to have been recently concluded between the Soviet Union and Canada on the provision of evidence by the Soviet Union on alleged Nazi war criminals. However, we are of the view that it would be undesirable for Australia to enter into agreement to provide for taking evidence abroad and leaving juries to rely upon a video recording of the process.

The Committee noted that Mr Greenwood has exchanged letters with the Soviet Union, Hungary and Yugoslavia with a view to Australia entering into a similar agreement with these countries. Copies of Mr Greenwood's letters to those countries have been included as appendices to our report.

The Committee is of the view that prosecutions should not proceed until agreements have been concluded between Australia and all countries from which evidence and related material is believed to be available, that both prosecution and defence witnesses will be able to travel to Australia and that it will be possible to test their evidence in our courts in the usual way. We are of the view that any trials for alleged war crimes should be conducted in accordance with the usual rules of evidence and procedure usually applying in our courts. But we are conscious of the special difficulties which may be encountered by defendants in proceedings for events which occurred in other countries more than 40 years ago. Consequently, the Committee is of the view that the Government must be especially conscious of the needs and interests of possible defendants when negotiating with other countries about the travel of witnesses and access to documents and the site of alleged war crimes. This being so, we have concluded that prosecutions should not proceed unless and until the Government is satisfied that any defendants have had access to defence witnesses and to such sites and archives as is reasonable in the preparation of their defence.

It is the Committee's view that proceedings should commence by way of committal proceedings, as is usual with trials on indictment. Like the Director of Public Prosecutions, we recognise that proceedings for alleged war crimes are likely to be complex, protracted and expensive. Consequently, in the interests of fairness to the accused, the Committee has recommended that special provision be made to ensure that persons charged be entitled to legal aid. In the interests of justice, the Committee recommends that any investigations and subsequent prosecutions should proceed without delay. Accordingly, the Committee considers that additional resources might have to be allocated initially to the Special Investigations Unit and, later, probably to the Director of Public Prosecutions. Throughout the inquiry the Committee has formed and maintained a firm view that, in the interests of fairness and justice, the normal rules of evidence and procedure apply to anyone accused under the Bill, if it is enacted.

Before I sit down, I wish simply to say that I am delivering this tabling speech as Deputy Chairman in view of the elevation of the Chairman, Senator Bolkus, to the Ministry. I take this opportunity, on behalf of Committee members, to congratulate him on that appointment and to record our appreciation of the work he has done as Chairman of the Committee and the work he previously contributed as a member of the Committee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Stone Sen J.O.

TALKER.NAME: Senator STONE
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to commence by adding my congratulations to those just uttered by Senator Hill to Senator Bolkus on his translation-that is the word I would use, rather than `elevation'-to the Ministry from the chairmanship of the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs. However, whatever semantic phrase one might use to describe it--
—You are under the influence of Cumming Thom.

—As my leader in this place says, I am already under the influence of the Senate. The Senate will be aware that the terms of reference given to the Legal and Constitutional Affairs Committee in this matter were extremely carefully and I would even say narrowly defined. It is partly for that reason that the Committee's first conclusion, reached under paragraph (a) of the terms of reference, states in paragraph 9.2 of the conclusions chapter of the report which Senator Hill has just tabled:

SPEECH.PARA: The Committee is of the view that it is not possible to form a judgment upon whether the evidentiary value-
I stress `evidentiary value'-
of `evidence and related material believed to be available in foreign states' is likely to warrant the institution of any prosecutions without referring to specific cases.

Of course the Committee was precluded from doing this. Senator Hill and I have, however, formed a general view about some part of that matter which has already been referred to by Senator Hill in his tabling statement. That view is contained in paragraph 9.9 of the conclusions, where it is stated:
In the absence of any first-hand knowledge of the general body of `evidence and related material believed to be available in foreign states', and relying only upon the advice provided-
to the Committee by the Director of the Special Investigations Unit-

by Mr Greenwood, neither Senator Hill nor I were satisfied that the `evidence and related material . . . is likely to be of sufficient evidentiary value to warrant the institution of any prosecutions'.

Senator Hill has noted that my own view goes rather beyond that. In paragraph 9.10 of the conclusions I have gone on to say that if, despite that prior reservation, prosecutions were nevertheless to be initiated under the proposed legislation, if enacted, I am particularly of the view that evidence and related material believed to be available in the Soviet Union or Eastern European countries-in other words, countries under Soviet influence-should be used only in the event that it is fully corroborated, not merely corroborated but fully corroborated, by material deriving from outside those countries. We are told that there is such corroborative material in some cases; but, of course, that is a matter for the courts to determine in due course should any prosecutions be brought. In the first instance it is a matter for the Director of Public Prosecutions to determine before launching a prosecution.

As to the second term of reference, term of reference (b), I would like to draw particular attention to paragraph 9.12 of the conclusions of the Committee's report. In chapter 5 of the report the Committee considered some of the types of evidence and related material believed to be available in foreign states and some of the problems which might be encountered in its collection. The Committee concluded-and I quote from that paragraph of the report:
In the main, problems arise out of the doubts surrounding eye-witness testimony in this context. . .

After all, in the case of events which occurred some 42 to 48 years ago there is the question of the ability of witnesses, especially those on behalf of the defence, to travel to Australia, and the possibility that even if such witnesses, including witnesses for the defence, were to travel to Australia, they might still be subject-I would even go so far as to say almost certainly would be subject, but the Committee did not go quite that far-to improper pressures. `Improper pressures' is a kindly phrase, meaning threats against the witness and/or members of the witness's family in the country from which the witness originates. The paragraph continues:
. . . the need for independent interpreters-
of course there is no argument about that-
the importance of cross-examination, and the need for access to, and the authentication of, documents.

I think those are all extremely important considerations which would need to be very much in mind before the Director of Public Prosecutions were to initiate a prosecution under the War Crimes Amendment Bill, if enacted. I have no special comment to make about the third term of reference, term of reference (c), other than to note, as Senator Hill has, that paragraphs 9.16, 9.17 and 9.19 of this segment of the conclusions propose amendments to the present Bill in order to take account of particular matters referred to in those paragraphs.

Coming to the final term of reference, (d), I note in particular what I think are four extremely important paragraphs in this segment of the conclusions of the report. I pay tribute here not merely to members of the Committee generally but to Senator Cooney in particular for his contribution to these paragraphs. Paragraph 9.23 states that the Committee notes that witnesses from the Soviet Union, Hungary and Yugoslavia have not previously travelled to Western countries in order to give evidence in trials arising out of allegations about war crimes.

TALK.START.PARA: —That's right; they won't this time either.

—That is, not even witnesses for the prosecution and, of course, certainly not witnesses for the defence. Senator Crichton-Browne has interjected to say that they will certainly not do so this time either. I suppose the Committee had to have in mind and did have in mind the testimony it had from Mr Greenwood, the Director of the Special Investigations Unit, suggesting that in his opinion there would be a change in this circumstance should trials for war crimes be launched under this Bill. Well, we must wait and see.

SPEECH.PARA: In paragraph 9.24 the Committee states that it is of the view that it is crucial that both prosecution and defence should have an unrestricted opportunity to examine and, where appropriate, cross-examine any witnesses and that this should occur in front of the jury; in other words, that evidence should not be taken on commission in foreign countries in relation to crimes of such extraordinary importance and singularity as these but that witnesses should be brought to this country and subjected to the formal procedures of testimony in our courts and cross-examination by counsel for the defence.

In paragraph 9.25 the Committee went on to say that it is therefore of the view that prosecutions should not begin until agreements have been concluded between Australia and each country from which evidence is to be obtained, including those with which Mr Greenwood has already exchanged letters; those countries being the Soviet Union, Yugoslavia and Hungary. Without disrespect to Mr Greenwood, those letters could not be held to be binding agreements. The Committee went on to say that both prosecution and defence witnesses should be able to travel to and give evidence in Australia-that is to say, we should have the agreement of those countries to that effect-and to have their evidence tested in the usual way.

Finally, in paragraph 9.26, the Committee states that it is also of the view that in the overall interests of justice prosecutions should not proceed until the Government is satisfied that any defendants in such prosecutions will have access to defence witnesses and be able to visit such sites and examine such archives as is reasonable in the preparation of a defence. At the risk of labouring the point, I stress the extreme importance that I and all other members of the Committee attached to those four paragraphs and, of course, particularly the final three of them which are, so to speak, recommendatory paragraphs so far as those handling these matters, and particularly the Attorney-General and the Director of Public Prosecutions, are concerned.

The only other paragraph on which I want to touch briefly in speaking to the final segment of the report dealing with term of reference (d) is that to which Senator Hill referred; namely, 9.43 in which it is recommended that if any prosecutions are to be brought under this Bill if enacted, special provisions be made to ensure that any person charged with having committed a war crime who lacks sufficient means properly to defend his case be entitled to receive legal aid, if necessary quite outside the normal provisions of the standing legal aid schemes.

I close with some remarks of a more general nature. As honourable senator's are aware, the Opposition has given support in principle to this Bill, basically on the ground that crimes of the kind with which the Bill purports to be concerned are of such a serious nature that the fact that they may have been committed 40-odd years ago should in itself be no barrier to their prosecution. However, from the outset the Opposition has harboured considerable doubts about many aspects of the proposed legislation. Those doubts were referred to in the other chamber when the Bill was debated there and will no doubt be referred to here when it comes before the Senate.

Having had the benefit of participating in the Committee hearings, having read the many submissions put to the Committee and having spent two days listening to a range of witnesses in public hearings before the Committee, I know that many witnesses expressed very considerable fears about the consequences of this Bill, if it is enacted-not merely, in some cases, for the ethnic communities but, more generally, for the cohesiveness of the Australian community as a whole. The doubts that I referred to earlier have been greatly strengthened.

The Committee has unanimously proposed a number of amendments to the legislation, to which I referred very briefly earlier. I hope that the Government will accept those amendments. If it should do so, and in any case, there will be further opportunity to consider this Bill, both in the normal second reading stage and in the committee stage. As Senator Cooney wishes to speak, I shall conclude my remarks.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —This report from the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs is very comprehensive. Members of the Committee will agree that it was put together in a very short time. Perhaps we could go in for some mutual congratulations. Senator Hill and Senator Stone have already spoken. Senator Giles and Senator Powell-I hope that Senator Powell will speak later-did a lot of work on this report. In that context I join both Senator Hill and Senator Stone in passing on my congratulations to Senator Bolkus, who has moved into the Ministry. He chaired the Committee with great distinction. Under his guidance it has been a very outstanding Committee. He took over from Senator Tate, who, likewise, was a chairperson of great distinction.

SPEECH.PARA: On the question of evidence, the Senate sent to us a difficult question. We had to assess evidence without going into any details. That was quite proper because in going into details the sort of material that may have come out might have prejudiced people whose reputations are entitled to remain intact until it is proved that they should be otherwise. So it was very proper that we should not consider particular cases. On the other hand, it is very difficult to consider the merit of evidence without seeing what evidence is available for any specific case. That point has already been made by previous speakers.

The overall situation as I see it with regard to the evidence is this: the nature of the evidence is such that a lot of it may come, from what we can gather from Mr Greenwood, from Eastern bloc countries. My view on that is that the proper people to test that evidence are the 12 good people on the jury. Given our common law tradition and given the institutions of this country we must have faith in the institutions that have stood the test of time. My view is that the evidence, if put forward by a responsible prosecutor, should be tested and either accepted or rejected by the jury. We were given the task-a proper task-by the Senate to assess the general nature of the evidence but there is a danger in that task in that the legislature, unless it is careful, will fall into the trap of performing a function which is properly the function of a jury.

I am a great believer in the separation of powers. I think that the legislature, the executive and the judiciary should be kept separate. In that context it is absolutely essential that the judiciary be kept quite separate from the other two arms of government. It is for a jury, properly instructed by a judge, to decide whether any witness should or should not be accepted. My view is that the legislature must exercise caution in saying, `We think evidence from a particular place is so tainted that it should not be put before a jury'. Clearly there are great difficulties, as Senator Hill and Senator Stone have both so properly said. But, taking all that into account, ultimately the decision on what evidence should be accepted is a matter for a jury. If that protection is there, if that exercise is undertaken by a jury and a judge and jury are employed in this context, then in my view the prosecutor, exercising his or her function appropriately, should put whatever evidence is available before that jury to be tested.

There is some danger in our labelling evidence as coming from a particular source and saying that simply because it came from that source it is not fit to be put before a court. If we go down that path there is considerable danger that the legislature and perhaps the executive may start exercising functions which are properly the functions of a judge and jury in the judicial area. This question must be faced. But before it gets to that point, given the open nature of our society, great publicity will fall on anybody who is accused. That is a problem not only in this context but also in any criminal context. There is perhaps an increasing danger, particularly with the media providing an outlet to the public as a whole when any incident arises, that people will be grievously prejudiced simply by the fact that they are named and charged. Some circumspection must be exercised in the way the evidence becomes available. So there are two points. Firstly, I repeat: it is very important that the arms of government be kept separate. When we look at the evidence we should look at it not in a way that would usurp the function of the judge and jury. The facts are for members of the jury. It is for them to decide whether evidence, no matter what its source, is to be accepted or not. That is a function that the Senate, as a body, must be forever careful of.

The other point which has been faced properly here today is the question that we always face of quite prejudicial results following the simple allegations that are made when they become public. I think the report has kept both those issues in mind. It did not face the overall question of whether or not trials should go ahead. That is a matter properly for the Senate and will be debated when the War Crimes Amendment Bill comes before the House. But on the technical questions with which the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs dealt and on the question of the sort of evidence that was available and the sorts of procedures that should be available, I think the Committee has dealt with them very well. I think the procedure is absolutely essential. The procedure that should be adopted for these trials is exactly the same procedure that will operate no matter what trial is carried out in Australia. I think that is proper. It is essential that there be committal proceedings. It is essential that any witness who gives evidence should be put before the jury because the jury has to assess the credibility or otherwise of that witness. If that procedure is in place then, as I say, where the evidence comes from becomes a matter of quite minor importance. I congratulate the Committee again. I congratulate Senator Bolkus, wish him the best in his Ministry and thank him for the task he has performed in the Committee in the past.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —In common with all those senators who are not on the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs, I have not yet had a chance to look at this report. Having listened carefully to the comments made by a number of the members of the Committee, through the members of the Committee here in the Senate this morning, I do want to say that I am very grateful that the Senate did choose to send the War Crimes Amendment Bill to the Committee and I am grateful for the evident careful consideration which the Bill has been given by the Committee.

SPEECH.PARA: This is a Bill which excites passions in a number of different directions. There are people who, quite properly, have a passionate concern about the bringing to justice of people who may have engaged or who did engage in war crimes of a particularly foul kind. One can understand the deep feelings of revulsion and concern that people have that such people should be brought to justice. Equally one can understand the deep and passionate concerns of people who see this as an opportunity for other injustices to be done to people who would not have a chance to defend themselves properly against people who might bring forward evidence which could be fabricated for all sorts of reasons. I think one can very easily understand the concerns of the sorts of people who have apparently come and given evidence to this Committee and the concerns that they have expressed certainly have my sympathy.

In those circumstances there is a particularly difficult task for this Parliament to determine what is the appropriate form of legislation. I think this is a classic illustration of where a careful public examination of some of these issues, in addition to the normal processes of debate which can take place in the House of Representatives and the Senate, is of inestimable value. It enables the Parliament to display to the people of Australia the real issues which lie behind the legislation and the concerns which there are about the legislation, away from the suggestion of partisanship which almost inevitably colours debate in this place. Once the Government adopts a position, once the Opposition adopts a position, the arguments that are brought forward are seen as an attempt to justify those positions. I simply want to record my view that it is this sort of difficult legislation which particularly repays careful examination of this sort. I have little doubt that the Government will very carefully examine not only the majority views of the Committee but also the minority views which we have been told have been expressed by a number of Committee members.

I make it quite clear to the Senate that the Opposition certainly will be examining the report very carefully in terms of looking at its own approach to the Bill, the need for amendment and so on. This is a case where it is worth noting-and that is the reason I enter the debate now-that often the question of dispatch to a committee is also dealt with on a partisan basis. Attempts by the Opposition to get a more non-adversary, Opposition-Government approach to the reference of Bills to committees is something we should not lose heart about and we should not lose sight of the desirability of that objective. The simple fact is that governments generally are not interested in seeing Bills go to committees, for reasons that I, as someone who has been a member of a government, can completely understand. It is true of Labor governments and of Liberal-National governments.

We need to pick up the work which has been done in the past on seeing whether we can expand committee consideration. What has been said in the Senate today is an illustration of its value to the Australian community and the law-making process. Again I express my support for the procedures that have been followed in this case. I hope they will be multiplied in other cases. I do not seek leave to continue my remarks. I understand that the report will be available for debate in the Senate again this afternoon although, again, most of us will not have had an opportunity to absorb in that time what is, I am sure, a complex report. Again, I thank all members of the Committee for what has obviously been a most conscientious exercise on behalf of the Parliament.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Knowles Sen S.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to continue my remarks later.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted; debate adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: AUSTRALIAN AIRLINES (CONVERSION TO PUBLIC COMPANY) BILL 1987

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 16 December 1987, on motion by Senator Gareth Evans:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —On the surface, the Australian Airlines (Conversion to Public Company) Bill is about preparing Australian Airlines for sale as a public company. But, in fact, it is a monument to the incompetence of the Hawke Labor Government. It is a shrine to which airline users have come to bewail their losses after five years of absolute incompetence on the part of this Government. The Government's performance with regard to the airline industry can best be summarised by the amendment which I will now move on behalf of the Opposition, which sets down all our major criticisms of the legislation and the Government's performance to date. I move:

SPEECH.PARA: At end of motion, add: ``but the Senate condemns the Government for:

(a) its hypocrisy in introducing legislation similar to that passed under the previous coalition Government to convert the then Trans-Australia Airlines into a company and which this Government repealed;
(b) its failure to take into account the recommendations of the advisory group on Australian Airlines' future capital requirements;
(c) its failure to decide now whether or not to privatise Australian Airlines;
(d) creating continuing unnecessary uncertainty among Australian Airlines' employees as to their future; and
(e) its continuing poor administration of Australia's aviation infrastructure''.

That amendment sets down the major criticisms of this Government. I will now proceed to develop the arguments surrounding those points. Let me first just observe some of the perambulations of the Government in recent times with respect to the personnel, the key players, who have found themselves on the stage over the last several years when dealing with aviation matters. I will deal first with the recent removal of Minister Duncan from the transport and communications portfolio to some outer rim of the Ministry in some other Department. We all know the reasons for that. We all know that, as a left-wing Minister, he has found it extraordinarily difficult to be involved with Senator Evans as the senior Minister in charge of transport and aviation matters. We know of the absolute incompetence Mr Duncan showed in dealing with aviation matters on the floor of the House of Representatives. We recall his misunderstanding, his lack of knowledge and appreciation of the Amann contract affair, in which he caused enormous embarrassment to the Government, and to Senator Evans in particular.

We now find that Mr Morris, who was formerly banished to the outer rings of the Ministry, has been recalled to the Department of Transport and Communications, although after the July 1987 election he was removed from that very position. Does this not clearly demonstrate the lack of control, understanding and competence of the Government when it has to go searching back through its personnel on the outer rings of the Ministry, to retrieve somebody who has at least some understanding of aviation matters at a time when the industry is being reorganised by this Government?

During the period Mr Morris spent away from transport he was, I believe-no-one would ever know it-given the portfolio of housing and the aged. While he was in charge of that portfolio we heard no words at all. What gives us any confidence that, notwithstanding his experience in transport and aviation, he will be able to come back and deal with such sensitive matters as have now been thrust upon him by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke)? It just shows how bereft of talent is the Labor Government when it has to recall Ministers who have made no impact in any other area of government to take over a position in which the Government finds itself to be in dire political trouble? That is the essence of the case we will be putting down today about this long overdue legislation.

Let us now go through the history of this sorry catalogue of volte-face and somersaults on the part of the Government. It is worth reminding ourselves that the Hawke Labor Government, when in opposition, had much to say about what the Fraser Government was doing in aviation matters. I remind the Senate that in 1981 the Fraser Government passed legislation through the Parliament in exactly the same form as that which is now proposed by this incompetent Hawke Labor Government. What did Mr Morris, who was then the shadow Minister for Aviation, have to say? I will quote from Hansard the very words he used in the House of Representatives in 1981 when he was criticising the Fraser Government about this matter. I remind honourable senators that that is the same Mr Morris who is now back in the Department of Transport and Communications, supporting Senator Evans who, of course, has very little understanding of any of these matters. I will quote what Mr Morris said in 1981:
The formation of TAA into a public company is an ill-conceived, expensive and unnecessary gimmick.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who said that?
—That was Mr Morris. He is now Minister in charge of this legislation. He was the shadow Minister in 1981. Perhaps I should just quote one or two more of Mr Morris's words at that time:

SPEECH.PARA: The legislation constitutes a squandering of public resources by the Prime Minister . . .

I have to say that the only public resource that has been squandered is the time this Government has wasted over the last five years in not putting in place the legislation which we passed in government in 1981. The honourable member for Swan, Mr Beazley, became Minister for Aviation in 1984. He is now the golden haired boy of the Australian Labor Party (ALP), being groomed for the deputy leadership of the Party in the light of Mick Young's resignation.

TALK.START.PARA: —They will be down to Nick Bolkus as Deputy Leader.

—Heavens above! The only reason why Senator Bolkus is in the Ministry is the deal done between the Left and Right of the Labor Party. The Prime Minister had to shuffle around everybody in the Ministry to find a senior Minister who would accept Senator Bolkus under his wing, because Ministers have no faith in Senator Bolkus because of his representation of a particular area.

SPEECH.PARA: To make the point crystal clear, I emphasise that the very words used by the present Minister for Transport and Communications Support, Mr Peter Morris, to support his attack when in opposition against the Fraser Government, have now been politely forgotten by this Government because it has now adopted the very views that it decried so heavily in 1981.

Mr Morris was not the only one. The most significant point arises as a result of the discussion in the Parliament in 1984, when Mr Beazley was the Minister for Aviation. As I said, he is one of the rising intellectual giants of the Labor Party who we expect to take over the reins of power to run this country into the twenty-first century. Let us hope that we do not hit a brick wall on the way! What did Mr Beazley say when he was moving to repeal the Fraser Bill in 1984?

TALK.START.PARA: —He didn't do that, did he?

—He sought to repeal the very legislation the Government is now supporting. It was only three years ago that the former Minister for Aviation, Mr Beazley, the putative Deputy Leader of the Labor Party, took this action.
—Tell us what he said.
—Let us see what he had to say, remembering that it was only three short years ago. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: It is the Government's view-
that is, the Hawke Labor Government-
that there is nothing to be gained in setting up TAA as a public company.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is not Mr Beazley talking.
—It is Mr Beazley, who is now the Minister for Defence. At that time he was the Minister for Aviation, the fount of all knowledge on aviation.
—Do you think Cabinet solidarity has now disappeared?
—There is no Cabinet solidarity when the Labor Party has to fiddle around to put Nick Bolkus in the Ministry and move everybody around.
—Order! He should be referred to as Senator Bolkus.
—I beg your pardon, Mr Acting Deputy President. In referring to the repeal of the Fraser Government's legislation, which has now been adopted by the present Government, Mr Beazley said:

SPEECH.PARA: Nor can we justify to the taxpayer the very significant costs that would be incurred in such a transformation. This Government will retain TAA in full public ownership as a statutory authority.
That is what the then Minister for Aviation, Mr Beazley, said. How can we trust the Hawke Labor Government on anything it says?

TALK.START.PARA: —They do not know what they are doing.

—Yes, Government members do not know what they are doing. A classic example of the lack of trust people have in this Government was demonstrated in the Adelaide by-election two weeks ago, when people indicated that they did not believe what the Prime Minister had said about charging for telephone calls. They knew the Prime Minister would proceed with time charging of telephone calls, no matter what he said, because they know that they simply cannot trust him. That view in the Australian community is reinforced by the points I am now making about examples. The Government claimed it would not introduce a capital gains tax, assets tests on pensions or a tax on lump sum superannuation payments, but it has since introduced those measures.

SPEECH.PARA: I shall proceed further in raising points about the Government. I believe we must set down the test by which we would judge the Government's actions in the aviation area. It is clear that the Government is hopeless. Factional manoeuvring within the Government reeks and reminds one very much of the last days of the Roman Empire when the emperor's crown was up for sale to the highest bidder and the highest bidders took over the crown for a few weeks before they were deposed by a person prepared to pay more. That is the situation in the Labor Party at present. The party is cracking down through its factional rifts in such a way that it is destroying itself at the base, and it knows it. The Labor Party knows, from the result of the Adelaide by-election, that its own previously solid supporters are deserting it in droves. The reason is obvious. They do not trust the cracking foundations of the Labor Party any more.

In the aviation area the expense to the taxpayer of five years of ministerial bungling and incompetence has meant that those consumers, namely, users of airlines, have suffered cost increases greater than they would otherwise have experienced had the Government proceeded in 1983 with the legislation enacted by the Fraser Government in 1981. The costs cannot be measured, of course, but they are obviously enormous. Some idea of the cost to the consumer can be gleaned from the actions of other governments overseas where deregulation has occurred, where competition has been encouraged and where lower fares have been introduced and, accordingly, many more people have been able to travel on airlines than would otherwise have been the case. That is a benefit to the consumer. It would have resulted in benefits to our economy by allowing people to move around faster.

Perhaps the worst example of Government incompetence is what has been observed in tourism in this country in recent times. On the one hand, the former Minister, John Brown, has been parading around the country generating some kind of enthusiasm for tourism-and some may say he has done a reasonable job-but on the other hand, the Government has taken no account of the problems that will be generated as a result of increased tourism in this country. There have been no improvements in flight scheduling and generally lower fares have not been available to consumers across the Australian community to enable them to take advantage of new tourism opportunities, whether here or internationally. Consequently, the airlines have simply not been able, because of the lack of competition, to match the challenge that has been thrown out as a result of increased tourism opportunities.

Honourable senators should acknowledge that one of the great tragedies of the past several years of the Government's inaction in opening up the Australian Airlines to competition has been the demise of a fledgling embryonic third national airline based around East-West Airlines. We now know that that company has been absorbed into Ansett Airlines of Australia, but at the time of its creation its charter was to be an effective operator in the low-cost budget area of tourism.

TALK.START.PARA: —But that is serving the people of Australia and why would the Government want to preserve that?

—It is serving the basic Australian consumer and offering more opportunities for Australians to travel more cheaply throughout the length and breadth of this country where new tourist facilities have been established. It was a grand idea and one that should have been fostered by this Government, but it destroyed that opportunity by not allowing competition to develop, by not enacting and keeping in place legislation that was passed by the Fraser Government in 1981, and by removing that legislation from the statute books in 1984, which led with absolute certainty to the demise of East-West Airlines and consequently destroyed the hopes of the average Australian consumer of being able to travel cheaply around tourist facilities in this country.
—Hawke fiddled until East-West was taken over. That is the truth.

—Absolutely. As my colleague says, Hawke fiddled until East-West was taken over by another airline. This Government had the magnificent opportunity laid on a platter for it by the Fraser Government in 1981 to develop an alternative airline scheduling operation in this country which would have provided cheaper fares and facilities for Australians. This Government stands condemned on that issue alone. Consequently it should hold its head in shame at its lack of action over that time.

SPEECH.PARA: I shall refer to two matters to ensure that the record is properly understood about some of this Government's actions. I refer honourable senators to one of the provisions of the Bill referred to by Senator Evans in his second reading speech. He said that matters such as Loan Council borrowing limits, government oversight of industrial relations arrangements, Remuneration Tribunal determination of board member and senior executive salaries, and restrictions on superannuation arrangements for Australian Airlines will remain but will be further considered.

One of the strong arguments that was put against the legislation introduced by the Fraser Government in 1981, emanating from the Minister now subservient to Senator Evans, that is, Mr Morris-he was then the shadow Minister for Transport-was that those things were not included in the original legislation by the Fraser Government and, therefore, the people of Australia would not support the changes which the Fraser Government was then proposing.

But this proposed legislation incorporates none of that. It does not tell us in detail what the Hawke Labor Government proposes to do about employees' superannuation or about industrial relations matters. It does not say anything about what limits will be established by the Loan Council for borrowings, and what arrangements will be initiated for executive salaries. The Bill says nothing about that, yet it now has the full support of the Hawke Labor Ministry which includes Senator Evans and particularly Mr Morris who was then the shadow Minister, decrying the Fraser Government on those matters as well.

TALK.START.PARA: —Do you think the departmental officials must be getting confused by these conflicting instructions they keep getting?

—There can be no doubt about that. Let us remember, of course, that the future for airline development in this country and, in fact, the infrastructure for many public owned authorities that provide services to Australians is one of a very great shortage of capital. Yesterday's Australian contained headline articles where Senator Evans apparently is saying to his own Caucus that $1 billion of capital is yet to be raised to look after transport authorities owned by the Commonwealth Government. Somehow that money has to be raised. Senator Evans is obviously trying to argue within Caucus that the only way to raise the money to modernise our aircraft, our ships and so on is to privatise the transport authorities and to allow the development of a denationalised industry.

SPEECH.PARA: That is obviously what this Bill is all about. Yet those borrowings have blown out in this country; the total Australian debt over the five years this Government has been in power has risen from $30 billion in 1983 to $105 billion in 1987-88. That has brought with it huge costs borne by the taxpayer in repayment of capital and interest on loans to the extent now that every Australian-and the Budget supports this-is paying 10c out of every $1 of tax he pays to the Commonwealth Government just to keep the interest running in respect of the loans which the Commonwealth has entered into: 10 per cent of our taxes go to paying the interest on those loans.

TALK.START.PARA: —The way this Government is going they will not be able to afford to catch buses let alone aeroplanes.

—That is quite right. It is a horrifying situation that we face as we approach the twenty-first century. We are paying more on interest and servicing costs for loans on past debts to maintain our past spending by this Government than we do on education, health and defence. Clearly the Government deserves condemnation on the grounds that it has generated this debt, and that it has led us into this financial mess. It is now forced to the reality of the very truths which the Liberal and National parties were espousing at earlier elections but certainly over the past seven or eight years concerning the need to privatise our enterprises because of the capital demands imposed upon them in the future. Some sections of the Labor Party have come lately to the realisation that that has to happen. Senator Evans obviously has, judging from his articles in the newspapers in recent days.
—Those reports he has leaked are very powerful.
—These are leaked, are they? I thought he must have bought space in the Australian newspaper yesterday.
—It is a good ad.
—It is a good advertisement, is it not? This is the only way he can sell his Caucus, by leaking documents of this size and stature to the Australian Press.
—It is the cheapest way to distribute things. It is the cheapest way to get messages to Caucus.
—You presume Caucus is literate and able to read.

—It is certainly the cheapest way of getting messages to the Caucus, but I point out that not all Caucus members are illiterate because in yesterday's Melbourne Herald newspaper an article headed `Evans takes on Left over Government sell-off' demonstrates that there is at least one literate left wing member, John Langmore, the honourable member for Fraser, in the other place. Yesterday he claimed that an increased public borrowing requirement was no more dangerous to the economy than private companies borrowing capital overseas. He then goes on to say:

SPEECH.PARA: We can fight back. There is talk around the corridors of privatisation being dropped before the ALP National Conference . . .

TALK.START.PARA: —What do you think will happen to travellers while the Labor Party squabbles about privatisation?

—Here is the Labor Party fiddling while the consumers burn. That is the situation. Let me just finish on this point because it is quite illuminating. The reason that Mr Langmore said that we-meaning the left wing-will win over the Evanses and the Hawkes of this world is apparently that suddenly they have had a rush of blood to the head and they are saying they will destroy this issue before the ALP National Conference in July because they want to avoid humiliating the Prime Minister. Do not worry about the consumers. All we are worried about is how good the silver bodgie looks. It is a matter of whether the Prime Minister will look pretty or not; or whether he will burst into tears again on television. The fact is that the Labor Party is united apparently in one view and that is that the Prime Minister cannot be humiliated. Do not worry about the consumers. Do not worry about the airlines. Do not worry about the tourism industry. Do not worry about the balance of payments. Do not worry about the international debt. Do not worry about the taxes that we have to pay to repay the interest and the capital. Just worry about the humiliation of the Prime Minister at the ALP National Conference.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not know whether the Government will end up proclaiming this Bill; possibly it will not in the light of this kind of conflict. But I will say to the Senate that this Bill has the wholehearted support of the Liberal and National parties, and the amendment I moved sets down all the points on which we had argued against the Government, not just this week or last week but over seven years concerning airline policy.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sanders Sen N.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am a person who came here from the United States of America, that bastion of free enterprise and capitalism. Incidentally, I take this opportunity to show to one and all my certificate of Australian citizenship dated 4 July 1979 in case anybody had thoughts of making an issue of my citizenship. I wonder how many other members of this chamber actually have a piece of paper saying that they are an Australian.
—Why did you choose 4 July?

—I thought it was a fitting date. It annoyed the United States Consulate no end. The point I make is that I came from the United States and, having been conditioned by the Eisenhower years, when I first arrived here I thought, `My God, nationalised airlines, nationalised railways and a nationalised shipping service!'. I was aghast at this intrusion of government into what should be the province of free enterprise. But over the years I have found that it is actually a good thing, especially in Australia which has a small population, because Australia has always been controlled by a few monopolies. Generally they were British, now they are Japanese with some help from the Americans. We find that Japanese are actually influencing our government to the extent of trying to unseat the Unsworth Government in New South Wales because of its woodchipping policy. So we are controlled from outside this country. We are controlled by foreign interests. I suppose that Rupert Murdoch and Sir Peter Abeles are home grown capitalists, but I think it is a very good thing that Australian Airlines is a government run instrumentality and it is a good thing that the Australian National Line, Telecom Australia and a number of other organisations are government run. Even though Australian Airlines does make money, some of the organisations do not. Does defence make money or does running a sewerage plant make money? Of course not. The point is that these are governmental responsibilities which should be taken by a responsible government and up until now anyway the governments of Australia have been responsible enough to undertake these tasks.
—Services to the community.

—Services to the community, as the Minister says. I take this opportunity to congratulate him on his elevation to the ministerial benches, and I will be coming around to talk to him about Kakadu in a minute. The Australian Airlines (Conversion to Public Company) Bill is in fact not the thin end of the wedge in the move towards privatisation; it is the thick end of the wedge. This is it.
—Hear, hear!

—Senator Messner says, `Hear, hear!'. This is privatisation coming at us. Of course the Opposition, to its credit, has always said it was in favour of privatisation; it has always been open about this. The Australian Labor Party, up until now anyway, has said, `No, we are against it'. But the Hawke conservative Government-the Opposition for some reason I do no understand objects to this-has not gone that way. Mr Hawke is implementing all the Opposition's policies and all it has to do is just sit back.
—He is not doing as well as we would have.

—I think he is doing better than the present Opposition could have. There is very little opposition to his policies. If those who are now members of the Opposition were trying to implement them, those on the Government side would be over here and they would be yelling and screaming. The Hawke conservative Government, perhaps because of the pragmatism which says, `Look, it is better to have us in government than that other lot; so let us do whatever we want', is getting away with things that Fraser could not possibly have done. Senator Messner nods in agreement.

SPEECH.PARA: So we have privatisation. What will this lead to? It will lead to Hawke's buddies, Sir Peter Abeles and Murdoch, an expatriate who is now an American, taking over the entire airline industry. Do honourable senators think that they would let Australian Airlines go to anyone else if it went private and was sold? Just as they killed off competition from East-West Airlines Ltd they would buy up Australian Airlines. We would have not a two-airline policy, which is bad enough, but a one-airline policy. People would fly when the airline wanted them to. People would belly up to the ticket counter only to be told they will go when the airplanes go. The consumers would not have a look in. There would go the charter fares and cheap fares, as were provided by East-West, that Senator Messner was talking about earlier.

Once Abeles and Murdoch have their tentacles into the entire airline system, which is what they want and what Hawke is trying to give them, we can kiss air travel in Australia goodbye. That is a shame because this country needs air travel. In fact, this country pioneered air travel. Australia was where Kingsford-Smith and people like him demonstrated the efficiency of air travel, but over the years government bureaucracy strangled the development of air travel. We have a Department of Transport and Communications which still has the attitude that the only safe airplane is one in a hangar with the doors welded shut. It does not want the planes to fly. The Government imposes restrictions. There are far too many restrictions on the operations of Australian Airlines, but I do not think this Bill will do anything about that.
Of course, I am not alone in saying these things. Astute journalists have made similar comments. An aviation correspondent, Tony Harrington, writes:
The Federal Government is putting the finishing touches to a bill which would give Australian Airlines greater commercial freedom and help smooth the way for privatisation.

The Canberra Times-that excellent newspaper which has some very insightful columnists on its staff, some of whom actually come here to rest their weary selves in our galleries and use our desks to write their columns, probably because it is too noisy in the other chamber-carried the following article under the heading `Airline privatisation decried':

Government discussion papers on privatisation show that Qantas and Australian Airlines should not be privatised, according to a member of the caucus committee studying the privatisation of the airlines.
This is a reference to the self-same Mr Langmore who was quoted earlier. The article continues:
``The papers show absolutely clearly it would be the wrong thing to privatise [the airlines],'' the Member for Fraser, Mr Langmore, said yesterday.

The papers-on Qantas, Australian Airlines, Australian National Railways and the Australian National Line-were to be discussed this week by the three members of the caucus ad-hoc committee established in November to contribute to government policy on privatisation of government transport enterprises. They expect to report to caucus within four weeks.

``Why privatise Qantas and Australian Airlines when they are making money?'' Mr Langmore asked. ``Qantas is one of the more efficient international airlines in the world. It would be foolish to privatise it.''
It certainly would be.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about the consumer?
—The consumer certainly will not benefit from privatisation if Murdoch and Abeles take over the whole works.
—They are ripping off all the profits and driving the prices up. We want cheaper air fares.

—We certainly do. We need more competition, but we do not need to privatise Australian Airlines. We need complete deregulation. If Opposition senators were for free enterprise they would agree with that stance but, no, I think they want to protect Murdoch and Abeles themselves.

SPEECH.PARA: I turn to the amendment moved by Senator Messner. Once again we find ourselves in the invidious position of actually agreeing with the words but not their meanings. Senator Messner's amendment states:
`but the Senate condemns the Government for:

(a) its hypocrisy in introducing legislation similar to that passed under the previous Coalition Government to convert the then Trans-Australia Airlines into a company and which this Government repealed;

Certainly the Government is hypocritical. Hypocrisy seems to be its stock in trade. So, yes, we can support the condemnation of the Government because of its hypocrisy, but of course we do not really want Australian Airlines converted into a company as that would then lead to privatisation. So we are in a bit of difficulty there. Paragraph (b) of the amendment states:
its failure to take into account the recommendations of the Advisory Group of Australian Airlines' future capital requirements;

We certainly agree there. We do believe that Australian Airlines should be made viable. It should be allowed to compete, and it should have the wherewithal and the material resources to compete successfully and give the consumers the service they require. Paragraph (c) states:
its failure to decide now whether or not to privatise Australian Airlines;

I think the Government should decide on that issue, and I think it would benefit the Australian people, and in fact the Australian Labor Party itself, if it were to stick to its policies and say `No privatisation'. So we agree that the Government has failed to decide whether or not to privatise. Paragraph (d) states:
creating continuing unnecessary uncertainty among Australian Airlines' employees as to their future;
If it did say that there would be no privatisation, the employees would certainly understand their future. Paragraph (e) states:
its continuing poor administration of Australia's aviation infrastructure''.

Over and over again I and other members of the Senate have noted the Government's poor administration of Australia's aviation infrastructure. So we agree with the words, but we do not agree with them in the way they are meant by the Opposition. I think we will actually support the Opposition's amendment, moved by Senator Messner, but not for the reasons he would like us to support it. We agree with the words, but we do not agree with the meanings as he would have them; we agree with the meanings that we believe they have.

What can we do? Instead of this Bill we should force the Government, if the Government will not do this itself, actually to give Australian Airlines the capability of competing, such as by removing the Loan Council borrowing limit. To deal with the staffing problems, it should have Remuneration Tribunal determination of the remuneration of board members and senior executives. In general I think the Government should attempt to trim the bureaucracy which surrounds Australian Airlines, or indeed any other function of government. Bureaucrats have about a five-year productive working span. Believe it or not, bureaucrats are enthusiastic at the beginning of their term. Some of them, when they leave school, even have ideals and they work hard, but after a while they settle into the same old rut and they know that if they make a noise they might not get promoted or they will get shunted sideways. Of course they will always get promoted.

We have Parkinson's law to thank for that, and the Peter principle. I am not making any allusions to the Minister for Resources, Senator Cook, who is the only front bench member of the Government in the chamber at this time. But we have the Peter principle, which shows that people rise to one notch above their level of competency.

TALK.START.PARA: —Does that mean that you will be Leader of the Democrats?

—Well, I seem to be the only person here speaking for them. At this moment I am the de facto Leader of the Australian Democrats. We are a very democratic organisation. The point is that bureaucracy can strangle any viable organisation. The bureaucracy of Australian Airlines should not be allowed to get in the way of the operation of the airline. Therefore, operational personnel should be given far more leeway and should be kept from being stifled by the bureaucrats. The Hawke conservative Government will reap the justified wrath of the electorate if it once again ignores party policy and sells off the people's airline.
—Is that the sour grapes of wrath?

—`Wrath' is one of those contentious terms. I would not pronounce it the way Senator Cook does, but it is grapes of wrath. The conservative Government of Prime Minister Hawke will certainly suffer, because people like their airline. People do want to have their own airline. If people believe in that airline I think they will rise up and take it as another indication of the Hawke Government's inability to keep its trust either with its people or with its own party. It would be another promise broken, another policy area forgone. It would be similar to selling uranium to France. It would have an electoral backlash. I think the Government is astute enough to realise that.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not know why at the moment it has this lemming-like tendency towards jumping off the cliffs of self-destruction, but it seems to be making all the wrong decisions and this certainly is a wrong decision. I would like to think that we could save the Government from itself by opposing the Bill. We will oppose it. It is unfortunate that the Opposition will support it, which of course will mean that it will pass. I think this Bill will cause irreparable damage to Australia's transport policies.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacGibbon Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Airlines (Conversion to Public Company) Bill 1987 is testimony to the administrative incompetence of this Labor Government. It shows quite dramatically once again how out of touch it is with the needs and aspirations of the Australian community, because if there is one thing the Australian community wants it is cheap and efficient air travel. From a national point of view, we need cheap and efficient international travel. This Government has set about perverting the whole of the efficiency of the transport system in this country by the way it kowtows to the bully boys in the union movement and the featherbedding that is inevitable with that and the way it has messed around in repealing this Bill.

SPEECH.PARA: I find it quite incredible that only a few years ago in this chamber this Bill was repealed, and now this Government is bringing it back. As Senator Messner said, the Bill was brought in and passed in 1981 under the Fraser Government, and one of the very first acts of this Labor socialist Government, motivated purely by ideology at the time, was to rescind that Bill. Now, a few years later, all those people over there are going to vote for a Bill that they voted against then. They did that in 1984 not because of any economic argument and not because of any rational argument of any sort whatsoever; it was simply an ideology. People such as Senator Cook, chanting a mindless ideology, a socialist dogma, had to remove it because they did not like the idea that Trans Australia Airlines (TAA), as it was then, should be sold. But it is part and parcel of so many things on the learning curve of this Government. It is now busy doing all the things that the Liberal Party was doing when in government and has told the Labor Party to do all the time it has been in government.

Look at some of the changes that have taken place. I cannot cite them all, but look at some that have taken place in the Government's foreign policy area, in the way it has moved away from supinely supporting the Soviet position when it was in opposition to taking a more realistic view of the facts of life in the international world. Look at its bank policy and the recognition of foreign banks and their admission into Australia, which was Liberal Party policy implemented by the Australian Labor Party (ALP) Government after opposing it for years. Look at the need for restraint in government spending, which is sadly not marked in any way at all by any success to date; but if it keeps trying it might be able to control a little bit its big spending habits. Again it is Liberal policy of responsible government.

Of course, we come to this one, the conversion of Australian Airlines to a public company so that the public company can be sold and we can get rid of the two-airline Act and can inject some real competition into the Australian marketplace in the way of fares so that we can do something for the poor, long-suffering public. That is the aim of this Bill, and no matter how the people over there squirm about it, the Government is going to sell Australian Airlines and it is going to change radically the two-airline Act because it is compelled inevitably by the facts of life to do so.

TALK.START.PARA: —Not if Senator Burns can help it.
—Well, Senator Burns is going to squirm and he will just have to vote. He will have to run with the Minister on this, however much it hurts him before his mates in Queensland.

SPEECH.PARA: We have here a government that is more incompetent than any we have seen in the Federal Parliament since the closing days of the Whitlam Government. It is a government that is tortured by its internal factions; it is a government that lacks consistency in its policies; and it is a government that elects people as senior office-bearers in the Ministry not on a basis of merit and not on ability, but simply on factional deals cut to keep people quiet. It cuts a deal on anything that suits the numbers in the various factions. It is not concerned with the quality of the decision; it is not concerned with the merits; and it is not concerned with the economic or intellectual arguments that might prevail. It is simply jobs for the boys, keeping Bill happy today so that Joe will be happy tomorrow, and the devil take the country as a consequence.

Because the Labor Party has messed around in such an incompetent way, we have lost at least five years, and probably more, of planned improvement in the Australian airlines system. How the repeal of the Bill in 1984, the repeal of the repeal which is taking place today-which the Liberal Party and the National Party of Australia wholeheartedly support-must stick in their craw. I suppose that is why we do not have one Labor speaker on the speakers list for this Bill. The list reads: Senator Messner, Senator Sanders from the Australian Democrats, myself from the Liberal Party, Senator Chapman from the Liberal Party, Senator Michael Baume from the Liberal Party, and finally the Minister will come in, but not one of his colleagues over there.

TALK.START.PARA: —And Senator Cooney.

—Senator Burns will not get up and defend this Bill, will he? None of the other senators from the Labor Party will come in and defend this Bill. They are hiding their heads in shame at the hypocrisy of this Government and at the inconsistency and sheer incompetence that is being manifested today.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to go on to deal with the business of the lost time for the Australian public. Four points are apparent. The first is the erosion of Australian Airlines, the old TAA company, within the Australian airline industry. It is now in a very sad state. The second point is the almost total dominance of the Australian transport field-not only the airline field but also road, freight and passenger transport-by Ansett Transport Industries. More important than those two points is the removal of East-West Airlines Ltd, which was the third competitor injecting some competition into the cosy duopoly existing between TAA, as it was, and Ansett. Most importantly, the Australian public for the last four or five years has had to pay-it has had no choice in it-very much higher air fares than it should have paid. Sadly, it will go on paying those higher fares for quite a few years to come because while the ALP has had a change of heart on this matter and is now moving to sell Australian Airlines, restitution for those lost years cannot be made and the position cannot be recovered in the short term.

I want to dwell a little on those four points and enlarge on them before I move on in my speech. The erosion in the market-place of Australian Airlines is very significant. That airline is totally undercapitalised. It does not have the money to buy the new equipment it needs to stay in business.
