It cannot stay in business when it is faced with a very efficient airline, as Ansett is, operating the latest equipment, which costs far less to operate and maintain and in fuel costs than the equipment that Australian Airlines has. Australian Airlines, as it is structured at present, simply cannot maintain its present position; it is going downhill all the way. This shows that this Government cannot run anything, least of all an airline. It cannot even handle the money that is given to it by donors trying to buy favours from it in an election campaign without breaking the law and farming it out illegally into other accounts.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about the action by you?

—If Senator Burns wants to talk about the by-election in Adelaide I will come to that later. Late last year Australian Airlines was driven, out of necessity, to cancel the Airbus order. It had no option but to cancel a $650m contract to buy new Airbuses to upgrade its fleet. This is testimony to the fact that it does not have any money. It is so bankrupt it cannot fulfil orders it made years ago. Not only could it not face the cost of buying those aircraft but also it could not face the cost of the training programs and the new plant and equipment it needed to support those aircraft on the ground. The airline has to have new equipment if it is to stay in business and it cannot do it while it is languishing as a statutory authority under the Government. The Government, to give it its credit, recognises that it has to convert Australian Airlines to a public company, fatten it up and then sell it so that the airline can survive. The consequence of all this on Australian Airlines is that the morale of the company is at rock bottom. I know quite a number of employees of Australian Airlines both in the air crew and in the administration. The morale has been diminishing for years and, frankly, I do not know how the people keep on going. It is a credit to the resilience of the staff that the company keeps going.

SPEECH.PARA: A second important point is the almost total dominance of Ansett Transport Industries that this Government has brought about in the Australian transport market. Ansett is one of the best airlines in the world and I am proud that it is an Australian company. It is successfully managed, it is aggressively managed and it has followed an aggressive policy of growth. There is nothing wrong with that at all. It does not matter how much Senator Burns squirms on this, it is quite proper for a commercial enterprise to make a profit and to grow. One company is now in a position of great dominance in the Australian airline industry. This position is not going to be reversed in the short term. The consequence is that Ansett will continue to dominate the market for the next decade or two. Any effective competition coming into the market is going to have a very hard row to hoe. It is going to be very hard to take on Ansett. Again, this reflects on the lack of foresight and the total incompetence of this Government. It has delivered Australian Airlines into a situation where it can offer no effective competition which would bring about lower prices.

More important than those two considerations is the very serious loss of East-West Airlines in the Australian airline industry. East-West was an innovative, alternative airline and it believed, as I believe, that there is a very great potential in the low cost travel market in Australia. Everyone in this chamber flies a lot. We all fly too much as passengers around the place and we tend to overlook or even be unconscious of the fact that despite the air-mindedness of Australians very few Australians actually fly as passengers. I forget the figure but it is astonishingly low. A great many more people would fly if fares were at a more reasonable level. That was the great virtue of East-West Airlines. It was developing a new market but it was obstructed at every turn by Australian Airlines and Ansett which used every recourse that was open to them at law to block East-West's routes development. But it was coming along and it showed promise of being in time an effective third airline, injecting long overdue competition into the Australian market-place. The company has now been bought by Ansett. It has effectively been removed as a competitor in the two-airline situation. While Ansett will use it as a separate company for a while it means that if any new company comes into the Australian airline industry and wants to compete in the low fare market Ansett will be able to turn around with a sub-company that it owns in the form of East-West and virtually drive that company out of business. Ansett could run East-West in competition at a loss, and a new private enterprise company simply could not go on not making a profit. This reinforces once more Ansett's present great monopoly position.

That just demonstrates how out of touch this Government is. Mr Hawke does not give a damn about the travelling public of Australia. All his working life he has travelled with a first class ticket in his hip pocket. When he was a flunkey for the Australian Council of Trade Unions-or whatever that body is in Melbourne that calls all the strikes-he would fly around with a first class ticket paid for by the union movement. In the five years he has been Prime Minister whenever he wants to go anywhere he hops on a Royal Australian Air Force VIP aircraft. The plight of the ordinary Australian who lives in a very big country and who is faced with very high air fares is lost on him. It is lost on his Ministry and on all those school teachers and union officials who now hold Labor Party seats in this Parliament.

TALK.START.PARA: —He is just out of touch.

—The Government is totally out of touch-not only incompetent but also out of touch. It does not realise that Australians want to travel. If one looks at the international market one sees that Australians are great travellers. They go overseas. They do not go from Brisbane to Perth; they go from Brisbane to Singapore or Brisbane to London or Brisbane to Honolulu because the fares on the overseas routes now are far cheaper pro rata than they are on the internal airline services. Again, the cheapness of flights on the international airlines is a consequence of the basic competition in that environment. It is not a cosseted environment. There is a great demand in Australia for cheap air fares.

SPEECH.PARA: This Bill, I think, is going to produce quite a bit of suffering within the Labor Party. It is not for me to comment at length on that. The Party and the Government have clearly lost their way. They have been bullied by the Prime Minister and the ALP machine men from New South Wales and Sydney. After the Adelaide debacle they are now exposed to ridicule before their colleagues in the Party. These are signs that the timorous left wing and the Centre Left are now wanting their say, as Mr Langmore did yesterday. It is a little late in the day for that because the Party has been virtually destroyed in the eyes of the public by the way it has run in all directions on a whole range of issues.

The way in which the Government somersaulted by introducing this Bill is proof of what I am saying. The consequence of this Bill is inevitable. The Government will have to sell Australian Airlines. It must sell it because if it stays within the Government's control as a statutory authority it will wither on the vine. It cannot get the money it needs to re-equip and survive. Furthermore, it will not operate in a way that enables it to meet efficiently the competition from Ansett Transport Industries. The reasons why it will not do so, even with the best manager in the world, is there are no hungry shareholders pressing the board of TAA, Australian Airlines, whatever one wants to call it, for a profit. Without that profit motive, and the pressure for a profit all of these socialist ventures fail when they are faced with any real opposition.

The consequence of selling Australian Airlines is that we can then get rid of the two-airline Act. The two-airline Act is necessary because we have a government airline which can afford to run at a loss and a private enterprise airline like Ansett which cannot. The only way one can get Ansett or any private operator to stay in the market is to level the playing fields by putting boundaries around the commercial operations in the form of a two-airline Act. Historically, there was a good basis in the 1950s to have that two-airline Bill, but the industry has grown up. One of the things that led to the Australian Government being involved in commercial enterprises in the early part of the century was the fact that capital was short in this country. Capital is not short any more. People can raise money quite readily overseas, as the great takeover battles in the last decade have shown. The need for a government to start an enterprise or a business because it alone was able to raise money overseas to get that business going for the benefit of the Australian community has now passed. It passed decades ago. There is no argument at all for the Government to be involved in any commercial enterprise that can be done by private industry. That is not a matter of ideology; it is a matter of simple commercial common sense. But simple commercial common sense is a commodity which is quite alien to the Australian Labor Party.

The two-airline Bill must go so that there can be competition between the major carriers. I was always opposed to the two-airline Bill. I voted against it when it was introduced in 1981, so I do not need any comments from Senator Walsh or anyone else in the Labor Party who tries to impute a changed position to me. I opposed that Bill in 1981-the current Bill that is in place-on the ground that it provided no commercial competition between Ansett and TAA, as it was then. I forecast at the time that it would lead to a blow-out in air fares, and that has come to pass. The solution to the problem is to put Ansett and Australian Airlines on equivalent structures commercially so that we can get rid of the two-airline Act and allow them to compete in the market-place.

Before I close I must reflect on the exquisite irony of this issue for the Government. Members of the Government are blundering around and in the process they are destroying the old TAA. The fact that this Bill was rescinded four years ago, the fact that TAA has languished and run down in the market-place and the fact that they have allowed the private enterprise company, Ansett, absolutely to dominate the market, is full of irony. The proudest boast of the Labor Party was that it created TAA. Of course, when it created TAA in 1945 it legislated to provide a monopoly. It did not want any other airline to operate in Australia so it legislated against what was then Australian National Airways (ANA). ANA took on the Government in the High Court, and that monopoly provision was defeated. We then had the golden age of the Menzies era. Australia has never been more prosperous and has never grown faster. Menzies and the Liberal Party, in their wisdom, recognised the need for competition in the market-place. That led to the original two-airlines Bill, whereby TAA operated against ANA, as it was then, and later against Ansett. But now circumstances have changed and the need for the two-airline Bill is no longer there.

What does the Government really think it is doing? What does it see as its purpose in government? Is it the aggrandisement of the Prime Minister? Is it the adulation of the Ministry? Is it jobs for the boys-putting people like Senator Cook into the Ministry and Senator Grimes into an ambassadorial position in Holland? I think it is. I think it is very sad that such a short-sighted view of government is manifested by this Labor Party. I argue that it is the business of government to serve the Australian community, not a narrow section like the bully boys in the union movement or the friends in industry of Mr Hawke and Mr Keating. The business of government is to serve the Australian community.

Today we are talking about the field of transport. This is a vast country. We have a requirement for cheap and efficient internal travel. We have a requirement for cheap and efficient international travel because we are one of the really great trading nations of the world. We are a very great distance from our markets. Yet the Australian Labor Party has done more to destroy Australia's transport capability than any other party in our history. It has cuddled up to and cosseted the union movement. We have seen Australian shipping priced out of existence. We cannot man Australian ships. We cannot get goods across the wharves because of the Labor Party's support for the union movement. It costs up to three or four times as much to get a container across the wharf in this country as it does in places like the United States or the United Kingdom.

Internally we have had a government that has blundered around and destroyed the competition that we were starting to develop in the Australian airline industry. It has left us with a legacy of high fares. We have a government that cannot administer the Department of Aviation. It is only a few years since Mr Dick Smith wrote his famous book entitled Two Years in the Aviation Hall of Doom which accurately listed the problems that he had had as an honest citizen trying to operate a helicopter in Australia. The Government set up a puppet inquiry through the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Expenditure. That inquiry received 800 submissions. I have served on committees in this Parliament for 10 years. I have been on inquiries which had a far broader base than the narrow aviation base of the inquiry into Dick Smith's Two Years in the Aviation Hall of Doom. I would think that the maximum number of submissions received by a parliamentary inquiry is about 60 or 80. Eight hundred were received by this House of Representatives inquiry into the Department of Aviation. Characteristically, the Committee did not find much but most significantly the Government did nothing. The Department of Aviation is still as badly and as incompetently administered as it ever was.

The Liberal Party and the National Party support this Bill. We greatly regret that the Government has been so stupid that it took it three or four years to realise the enormity of the ideological mistake it made in rescinding this legislation. We put the Australian public on notice that it is being governed by one of the most incompetent governments that we have seen. This is a government that has no consistency in its actions, a government that cannot think ahead, a government that cannot get in touch with the reality of what is going on in the Australian community today. We regret the five years that have been lost by the repeal of this legislation and its reintroduction today. We regret that the Australian public, the Australian economy and Australian business has had to suffer the unnecessary high imposts caused by the lack of competition in the airline fields. In this matter, as in so many other matters, the Australian public is being bled dry by the incompetence of this Government to handle our economic affairs.
(Quorum formed)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chapman Sen H.G.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Airlines (Conversion to Public Company) Bill 1987 is a clear demonstration of why the people deserted the Australian Labor Party in droves at the recent Adelaide by-election. It represents five years of Hawke Labor Government incompetence writ large. It demonstrates how the Hawke Labor Government is completely out of touch with the needs of the Australian people. This legislation takes exactly the same form as the Australian National Airlines Repeal Act which was passed by the far-sighted Fraser Liberal-National Government in 1981.
—In 1981, some seven years ago.
—Why are we doing it again?

—We are doing it again because this Government overturned that far-sighted initiative of the Liberal and National parties to convert the then Trans Australia Airlines (TAA) to a public company. Before this conversion was implemented the present Government, in 1984, passed the Australian National Airlines Commission Retention Act which retained the then TAA, now Australian Airlines, as a statutory authority. The Government is now reversing that decision and is restoring the position which was established by the Fraser Government. The legislation we are debating today shows that the Government should be held in contempt and subject to utter condemnation for repealing that Fraser Government initiative. It has taken 4 1/2 years for the Hawke Labor Government to come to its senses, to realise that the 1984 decision and the legislation consequent upon it was wrong and that the Liberal and National parties were right in their handling of domestic aviation policy. We are now wasting the time of this Parliament, and in particular, today of the Senate to restore the position to that which applied under the Liberal and National Party Government, which it created with some foresight, as I said, seven years ago in 1981.
—You were a member of that, weren't you?
—I was a member of the Fraser Government and I was very proud to support that legislation.
—You were thrown out, too.

—Yes, as I have just said the legislation was thrown out by this Government in 1984, much to the detriment of the airline industry. As a result we have wasted 4 1/2 years for the airline industry and 4 1/2 years for the long-suffering travelling public. The reversal of the 1981 Fraser Government initiative in 1984 was introduced purely for doctrinaire, ideological reasons. It is interesting to refer back to what the then Minister, Mr Beazley, said on that occasion. He has now moved on to be Minister for Defence and, as of yesterday, Leader of the House. It is no wonder that he experienced some difficulties in another place yesterday in handling the Government's legislative program, as I understand it, when we look back and see what he said in 1984 and compare it with what the Government is now doing. In 1984, when introducing the Australian National Airlines Commission Retention Bill, he said that it would:

SPEECH.PARA: remove any doubt that Trans Australian Airlines will remain a statutory authority of the Commonwealth . . .
It is the Government's view that there is nothing to be gained in setting up TAA as a public company.
That is the very thing the Government is now doing in this legislation.

TALK.START.PARA: —They seem very confused.
—They have experienced a great deal of confusion. There is no doubt about that. They have completely reversed their position. Mr Beazley went on to say:

SPEECH.PARA: We see no reason to subject TAA to the turmoil and dislocation of transforming the Commission into a company when it can operate just as efficiently and with full accountability to the Government and the Parliament in its present form . . . This Government will retain TAA in full public ownership as a statutory authority . . . the balance will move away from what the airlines want to what the consumers want.

What have we seen over the last 41/2 years as a result of that decision by the Hawke Labor Government to repeal the legislation that the Fraser Government, with such foresight, introduced? We have seen nothing but confusion in the industry. We certainly have not seen anything that consumers want.

This Bill completely reverses the stand then taken by Minister Beazley. It demonstrates the foresight of the Liberal and National parties and, in contrast, the cant and hypocrisy of the Hawke Labor Government. This reversal and counter-reversal over the last 4 1/2 years has cost the industry and the public dearly. All the benefits to be achieved by this legislation could have been realised back in the early 1980s as a result of the legislation of the Fraser Government had it not been repealed in 1984 by this Government. Australian Airlines would have had several years of commercial freedom in which to improve its operation and implement the necessary investment, productivity and efficiency reforms which have not been possible under the current provisions.

In the years following 1981 the loss of benefits which could have been achieved by the 1981 legislation had it remained in place has had a dramatic effect on consumers. When the Fraser Government left office in 1983 we had a third airline bursting at the seams to get into the market to provide some competition for the existing two airlines, the then TAA, now Australian Airlines, and Ansett Airlines of Australia. As a result of the legislation which the present Government passed in 1984 there have been delays in the implementation of an effective competitive system which has sabotaged the potential of East-West Airlines Ltd effectively to enter the market as a competitive airline and provide some competition for the other two. The opportunity for East-West to be viable and the opportunity for a competitive system have been blown out of the water as a result of the confusion and delay for which this Government is directly responsible. (Quorum formed)

I welcome the presence in the chamber of some members of the Government so that they can hear what a hash their Government has made of aviation policy in Australia over the last few years. As I was saying when it became necessary to call that quorum to bring some of them into the chamber to listen to this very important debate, because none of them seem interested in participating, the legislation which the Fraser Government put into place in 1981, which was in operation when it left office, would have allowed greater competition in the industry; it would have allowed deregulation to proceed; and, indeed, it would have allowed East-West Airlines to provide some competition to the two then existing airlines to the benefit of Australia's air travellers. But that has been blown out of the water by the confusion and failure of the present Government to proceed over the past 4 1/2 years with instilling further competition and deregulation into the industry. There is no doubt that people want cheaper air fares. They want competition in this industry in Australia and then they will take the opportunity to travel not only for business purposes but for tourist and holiday purposes as well.

The Government is now talking deregulation, but it is sadly five years too late. This Government stands condemned for what this failure has cost Australian air travellers as well as what it has cost the proposed Australian Airlines company and its ability to compete in 1988. Massive amounts of Australian taxpayers' money have been squandered during the intervening period since 1981 as a result of this Government's incompetence. As a result of this lost time Australian Airlines may now find it difficult to become viable as a public company; indeed, it is quite possible that the only way Australian Airlines can survive is either for the status quo to be maintained-that is for it to be maintained as a statutory authority much to the detriment of air travellers-or for this new company to require substantial government subsidy for an indefinite period, much to the taxpayers' detriment. Should this be the end result, let there be no doubt in anybody's mind who should bear the responsibility: it is this Hawke Labor Government.

In contrast to the Government's about-turn, the Opposition has had a consistent approach and, hence, we support this Bill. But so that nobody remains in any doubt as to the implications of the Bill, I also fully support the Opposition amendment to it. This amendment highlights the failure of previous legislation under this Government and explains the reason for the recent poor performance of Australian Airlines. It also flushes out the real intention of this legislation-the eventual privatisation of Australian Airlines.

Let there be no doubt about the Government's belated conversion to privatisation. Senator Evans, the Minister responsible for this legislation, has reported to the Australian Labor Party Caucus that Australian Airlines will require a capital injection of some $250m in 1988-89 and a further $50m in 1989-90. Consequently, he has apparently recommended that 49 per cent of Australian Airlines should be sold to the public as a means to raise these funds.

The Opposition has been consistently emphasising the wisdom of privatisation to raise capital and inject some profit motive and general efficiency into Australian Airlines. But this Government now appears to be incapable of delivering on privatisation especially with the Left gaining ascendancy in more recent times. If we have any doubt about that we need only look at the election of Senator Bolkus to the Ministry in the last couple of days. It is interesting to note the last question which Senator Bolkus placed on the Notice Paper. It was on the Notice Paper yesterday before he became a Minister and, therefore, was no longer in a position to place questions on the Notice Paper. Question No. 154 states:

Senator Bolkus: To ask the Minister for Transport and Communications-What are the details of amounts paid by the Commonwealth to Ansett Transport Industries and its various air and road subsidiaries during each of the last 5 years by way of: (a) fares for travel; (b) charges for the conveyance of postal materials; and (c) freight for transportation of general cargo.

So let there be no doubt where Senator Bolkus stands on this issue. He is totally opposed to the private sector. He asked an intimidating question of the Minister for Transport and Communications (Senator Gareth Evans). That hostility to the private sector which is so evident in the Labor Party today only reinforces the difficulty which this Government will have in proceeding with its privatisation plans for Australian Airlines. The implication of this possible failure with regard to privatisation is that taxpayers will be asked to fork out the $1 billion for which Senator Evans is looking, to maintain not only Australian Airlines but also Qantas Airways Ltd, the Australian National Line and Australian National Railways. Most Australians realise that we cannot afford to add this $1 billion figure to our deficit, be it real or be it disguised as it was in the last Budget. We have to be realistic and accept that this Government will not be able to deliver on privatisation, nor will it be able to find the funds from the public purse. This then implies that these vital industries will be undercapitalised and suffer long term degradation. The consequences of that will mean that there is no real competition in the Australian airline industry at all, again to the detriment of the long-suffering travelling public.

This prospect will also have devastating negative flow-on effects through the rest of the economy. One particular industry that will be directly adversely affected is tourism. The importance of this is highlighted in the report on Australian industry trends by the Bureau of Industry Economics released last week. In part this report comments on tourism and confirms two things which everybody on the Opposition side of this House has known for a long time. The first confirmation-I hope that even the Government would concede this-is that tourism is Australia's fastest growing source of income dollars. When an industry expands at the rate of 32 per cent, as tourism did in the September quarter last year, then that is real growth. Set that potential against otherwise difficult economic conditions and the necessity to add every possible form of encouragement and incentive to the industry should become clear even to the most short-sighted member of the Government.

The second salient point raised in the Bureau of Industry Economics report is that airlines are failing to capitalise on this potential. The report states that airline flights simply are not adequate to cope with the increase in tourism. Once again, this is an indication that there is inadequate competition in the airline industry in Australia as a direct result of the way in which this Government has fumbled this important industry over the last five years. It is not good enough to consider this subject in isolation. Tourism is a direct reflection of any total travel system and ours is simply not good enough. Apart from inadequacies of flights there are other failings such as inadequate accommodation and insufficient training of hospitality staff to service the demands of our tourist industry. The Government, again, as well as being responsible for the failure of our airline industry to be competitive is also directly responsible for the failure to provide incentives and support for the establishment of adequate training schemes in the hospitality industry.

After 10 months my home State of South Australia is still waiting for the Federal Government to allow a hospitality traineeship to get off the ground. When I recently inquired of the Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Dawkins) as to why this delay had occurred, the Minister's office misled me because it told me the scheme had failed to get off the ground because agreement had not been reached between the South Australian Liquor Trades Employees Union and the Australian Hotels Association. That statement was designed deliberately by the Minister's office to mislead me. In fact, the South Australian Liquor Trades Employees Union and the Australian Hotels Association have come to agreement on the terms of the traineeship but the Federal Government's bloody-minded stance on the conditions required to gain subsidies for the scheme has held it up since April last year.

It is worth noting the conditions the Government is seeking to impose on the union and the Hotels Association for eligibility for this subsidy. The Government insists on including 17-year-old trainees in the scheme in a State where anyone under 18 years of age is not allowed into a drinking establishment. That is one area where industry and the union have reached agreement, yet the Government is quite deliberately holding up the scheme by insisting on an unrealistic condition which cannot be met in South Australia because of State law.

Secondly, the Government is insisting that 19-year-olds be paid $200 a week under this traineeship scheme yet the union and the employers have readily agreed that the rate of pay should be $190 a week. By now, 60 trainees were to have been involved in a pilot scheme and South Australia's technical and further education colleges would have implemented study programs. We have had 10 months' delay because of the totally unrealistic conditions the Commonwealth is seeking to have applied in an area of industry with massive growth potential. We could well ask: Why? It is again a clear demonstration of the incompetence of this Government and the way it has lost touch with the needs of the Australian people. Perhaps it is not so surprising that the Government has an inability to cope with such a self-made dilemma, because if airlines cannot deliver goods or people in the first place, all the training and accommodation in the world will not help.

We need an end to the arrogance which presumes that the Government knows what is best for its people and we need a lot more sympathetic and helpful consultation with segments of the tourist industry. How can a government which charges its own citizens to get back into their country-another example of the way this Government has lost touch-even claim to hold a sympathetic understanding of the needs of people, and the tourist industry in particular? The new backdoor revenue spinner of charging people a re-entry fee to Australia is not odious just to the 96,000 Australian travellers who thus far have refused to pay it; understandably it is odious to our international carrier, Qantas, which is going to carry much of the debt, and to the other 29 international carriers which are likely to be facing stiff fines because they do not want to be honorary backdoor tax collectors for this Government.

If one is super-rich and can afford to travel into Australia aboard the QEII one does not have to pay the arrival tax but if, like the vast majority of people today, one travels by aircraft into and out of Australia, one should beware of Australia's cash curtain. Even Australians cannot get in and out of their own country unless they pay for the privilege. These days we do not have `fortress Australia'; we have `tollgate Australia'. This is the mentality of a government which claims it has the interests of the public at heart and, of course, the interests of the airlines and the tourist industry serving that public, in particular. What a lot of nonsense! There can be no doubt that this Government has lost touch with the Australian people.

Tourism is not alone in suffering the inefficiencies of our airline system. Business travellers suffer equally. Travel in Australia is not a luxury; it is a necessity. It would be ridiculous to give two car manufacturers, one of them government-owned, the entire car market. It is equally ridiculous to cling to the idea that competition would be bad for the airline industry. Yet this is what this Government has done ever since it has been in office. It repealed the legislation of the Fraser Government which would, over time, have opened the way to greater competition and a better service for all Australians. Now, some 4 1/2 years later, it is reverting to that Fraser Government initiative. After years of being clobbered, Australian business needs every form of incentive and relief it can get. In particular, the tourism industry should be getting top priority. Improved airline arrangements, without which none of the rest works, are a matter of urgency.

Let us be in no doubt what this legislation ought to be seeking to do. It redresses a grave mistake which the Hawke Labor Government made in 1984. It is to be hoped that this will return us to a more flexible, innovative and competitive airline system, which will be to everyone's benefit. Let us hope it will not result in a drain on the public purse but will assist, rather, in advancing the economy, particularly in the tourism sector. The Australian public must regret that these opportunities were not taken up when the time was right after 1981, and especially after this Government came to office in 1983, as a result of the innovative legislation of the Fraser Liberal-National Party Government. The Liberal-National Party Government set the agenda for this issue. It is another example of where we are right and the Australian Labor Party is wrong, wrong, wrong. This inefficient and incompetent Government has messed up aviation over the last 4 1/2 years. This has cost the public dearly through the absence of adequate competition and, hence, the lack of cheap fares. The Opposition and I support this legislation which will restore us to the situation which the Fraser Government introduced. I also support the amendment which has been proposed by Senator Messner. In conclusion, I urge the Government, when this legislation is passed, to get on with the job of ensuring that we have a competitive and efficient airline industry for the benefit of all Australian travellers.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have heard a series of speeches from the Opposition, talking about the glories of the past. It is very appropriate that the Opposition celebrates the glories of the past because all its glories rest in the past. That is no fault of those opposite because the Australian people, over the last few years, have entrusted correctly their future to the Australian Labor Party, brilliantly led by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke). That has to be remembered. There was a recent by-election in Adelaide which the Opposition won. It is to be congratulated on that win. But what those opposite have done is erect that single win into a proposition that they are now the government of this country-which is not right at all.

SPEECH.PARA: If a general election were held to morrow-and this is generally recognised-this Government would be returned with the same, if not an increased, majority. That is what has to be remembered. A by-election does not elect government. General elections elect government. This Government was elected on 11 July last year. It gained the confidence of the people and still has that confidence. If we went to the people tomorrow we would win again. The Opposition has to fly with something. It has to be an opposition. I understand that. Those opposite rail against, criticise and blackguard the Government-and that is part of the exercise in this chamber. I understand their position; it is very difficult. The front page of this morning's Australian Financial Review is headed, `Markets rally as trade surplus hits a record'. The markets are up again. That is another indication of the glory with which we have gone ahead. The article says:
The unexpectedly good trade news also thwarted the Federal Opposition's ability to open the new parliamentary session with an attack on the Government's handling of the economy.

That is right. Those opposite are saying, `We really cannot attack the Government on the economy'. Those opposite then say, `You have done the right thing. You are about to pass this legislation but you should have passed it earlier'. That is what their arguments amount to.

TALK.START.PARA: —You should not have repealed it four years ago.
—That is again an indication that the Opposition lives very much in the past.
—You wasted four years.

—Senator Michael Baume claims that the Government has wasted four years. Who has wasted the time? Four senators so far have contributed to this debate, all of whom have said they support the legislation, but they talked about what they did when they were in government many years ago. I can understand that. Nostalgia is a passion we all live with, and if one has nothing else to live with one returns to it all the time. This debate is about nostalgia.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Sanders has said it is a move towards privatisation. I have read the Bill and the explanatory memorandum from start to finish and I found no reference to privatisation. The Bill seeks to create a structure that one hopes will make this efficient airline even more efficient and will enable it to remain in the public sector to compete, as it has already nobly competed, and to compete even better, against the other airline. The structure proposed is directed not towards privatisation but towards making public assets even more efficient than they currently are. The corporate structure that is being set up will enable people to make decisions without going through what are perhaps lengthy procedures that are currently required. This will make for efficiency and better management in the public sector.

I challenge honourable senators who will follow me in the debate, particularly the redoubtable Senator Michael Baume and the redoubtable Senator Crichton-Browne, to show where the legislation proposes at any stage that there should be privatisation. The legislation will simply set up a mechanism to allow the airline to remain in the public sector-I see Senator Burns in the chamber; he will agree that this enterprise should stay in the public sector and he will contribute to the debate later-to allow it to be conducted with more efficiency than is currently the case and to continue the profitable exercise that it has continued to operate over the past three years. It is an enterprise in the public hand that has made profits of more than 20 per cent for at least two of the past three years. It is worth while remembering that point.

One of the two points being made on the Opposition benches is that the Bill is a precursor to privatisation. However, the Bill and the explanatory memorandum do not refer to privatisation. The legislation is about efficiency. The other point is that the Bill is being used, as a legitimate parliamentary tactic, in an attempt to beat the Government around the head for alleged wrongs in the past. For example, Senator Chapman has said that the Government has neglected tourism. That is nonsense. The number of tourists visiting this country now compared with the number under the Liberal Government is so large that it does not bear comparison. One can simply move around airports of this nation to see the number of Japanese who are now visiting Australia. Where could one point to tourism in the days of the Liberal-National Party Government? It is nonsense to suggest that the Government has not encouraged tourism. The numbers of tourists at airports and tourist resorts is an indication of the Government's actions.

TALK.START.PARA: —You encourage tourism by devaluing the currency. That is your greatest policy activity.

—The Opposition is claiming that the economy is not well run and that tourism comes around by devaluation, as if to indicate that devaluation in those circumstances is a great evil. What is wrong with devaluation if it has led to increases in tourism and increases in exports? Our economic record would have been disastrous had there not been devaluation, so what is wrong with that?
—You increased the deficit.
—Senator Messner did not mention previously the fact that the balance of payments is turning in Australia's favour. I quote from the Australian Financial Review of today:

SPEECH.PARA: Australia's current account deficit shrank-
the word `shrank' means that it lessened-
from $694 million in December to only $428 million in January, the smallest monthly deficit since April 1984 . . .

The Reserve Bank's trade-weighted index, which measures the value of the $A against the currencies of Australia's major trading partners, rose from 52.8 to 53.1, its highest level in nearly four months.
That is further evidence that the economic course being pursued by the Government is the correct one.

TALK.START.PARA: —How much is the debt, and how much is it going up each month?

—There is no doubt that Australia's overseas debt is much greater than it should be. That is because of the balance of trade over the years, the sorts of commodities Australia has sold and the history of this nation. That issue has been debated here again and again. It is because in the past Australia has relied too much on commodity exports instead of value-added exports. To take up Senator Chapman's remarks, the Government has increased tourism and increased the export of value-added goods. The Government will increase them more. It has a comprehensive plan for this nation. For example, the Government will direct education as it should have been directed in the past, not in any harsh manner, but simply to enable people of this nation to become better skilled, better educated and better able to cope with the demands of the world-something that was not done until the Labor Government came along. As one considers the record of the Government in various areas, one notes that it comes out in glowing lights compared to what would have been the situation had it gone down the path that we had been guided on by the previous Liberal Government before the success of the Hawke Labor Government.

SPEECH.PARA: I have already indicated that the Bill is a technical measure that will simply put Australian Airlines into the hands of a public company, owned wholly by the Australian Government and through it the Australian people, so that it can be better conducted. As I have said before, that is not to suggest that it has not been well conducted until now. It indicates that the public sector can trade and trade well, and that the public sector can be improved by certain steps and procedures. The Bill is a step in that direction and is what it is all about.

The rest of the debate has been a huff and puff trying to score against the Government in the light of one by-election, which really signifies nothing other than that the people, given a chance to say to a government that it has to raise its game even more than it has already, have said, `Look, you are there to govern in the interests of the Australian people; you are not to take our resounding endorsement of you in July last year as any reason for doing other than pressing on in the way you have been going; don't let your game go down'-and that is quite proper. The message has been taken on board by the Government and it will continue in the next 2 1/2 years, which is the balance of its term, to govern wisely, courageously and in the interest of the Australian people.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —There are two possible reasons for the Government's introduction of this Bill, which is, of course, to restore Fraser Government legislation which this Government wiped out four years ago. One reason for the Government's restoring this measure is simply incompetence. The Government did not know what it was doing four years ago, and to that extent, I suppose, it could have said, `Forgive us for we know not what we do'. To some extent, Senator Cooney's speech was something of that order. He certainly did not know what he was doing when he was making his speech, so one could not expect the Government to know what it was doing in 1984 when it withdrew this legislation that it is now reintroducing.

SPEECH.PARA: Of course, it was Fraser Government legis- lation and, therefore, by definition among the doctrinaire elements of the Labor Party there was something disgraceful about it. The fact that it was doing the right thing, the sensible thing and the proper thing for the people of Australia and the users of airline services in Australia was beside the point. So doctrinaire are elements of this Labor Government that that legislation had to go. Now four years later-four wasted years-the measure is being reintroduced by this Government. Incompetence is one possible reason why the Government is restoring this legislation.

The second is that restoring this legislation is part of a deliberate pattern of abandoning traditional Labor Party policies and pinching large slabs of Liberal Party policies because they are better, they are in the public interest and, as Senator Sanders said earlier-one of the few sensible things he has said in this place-Mr Hawke has done many things that Mr Fraser could not do.

One of the reasons Mr Fraser was prevented from introducing many of his strongly held policies was Labor opposition, particularly in this chamber, which opposition was supported by the Australian Democrats. It is now clear that the Labor Party has set out on a determined campaign to abandon what were long and strongly held traditional Labor Party policies, and this is the latest example. It seems to me that in this instance what we have here is a combination of both incompetence, as evidenced in 1984, and the abandoning of traditional Labor Party policies. The ones who suffer, of course, are the people of Australia, particularly the airline travellers of Australia.

That is the reason that I strongly support Senator Messner's amendment in relation to the proposed legislation. Naturally I supported the legislation when it was introduced by the Fraser Government in 1981. I was proud and honoured to support this legislation then because it was right and proper just as it is right and proper now. Senator Messner's amendment to the Australian Airlines (Conversion to Public Company) Bill is:
but the Senate condemns the Government for-

(a) its hypocrisy in introducing legislation similar to that passed under the previous Coalition Government to convert the then Trans-Australia Airlines into a company and which this Government repealed;
(b) its failure to take into account the recommendations of the Advisory Group on Australian Airlines' future capital requirements;
(c) its failure to decide now whether or not to privatise Australian Airlines;
(d) creating continuing unnecessary uncertainty among Australian Airlines' employees as to their future; and
(e) its continuing poor administration of Australia's aviation infrastructure.

Let us look at the first element of the two factors involved in the Government's introduction of this proposed legislation. The first one is incompetence. The Government has simply made a mess of air travel in Australia since it was elected to office in March 1983. We have witnessed not an increase but a reduction in competition under this Government. East-West Airlines Ltd was recently knocked off because it was threatening to increase the volume of competition, particularly on major usage routes and in areas where internal tourism was a vital factor and where that company was encouraging Australians to take their holidays in Australia rather than use the cheap fares that are available for overseas travel.

More important, under this Government's mistaken and incompetent policies air fares in Australia have risen at double the rate of increase of international air fares during the term of this Government. I shall quote the Senate a couple of examples. In December 1982 a one way economy fare between Melbourne and Sydney was $117.40. By last December it had risen to $171, which is a 45.6 per cent increase on the Sydney to Melbourne route.

TALK.START.PARA: —Outrageous.

—I hear an interjection from a member of the Labor Party that this is outrageous. It is an interesting figure when one compares it with what has happened to the international economy fare for Sydney to London. That fare has increased not by the 45.6 per cent that has been experienced in the Australian internal fare but by 23.1 per cent. That is only half the increase of the busiest trafficked and, therefore, one would think, the most economically efficient route in Australia-Sydney to Melbourne. I have quoted only one example but there are plenty of others. The Adelaide to Perth one way economy fare has risen from $237.10 to $342 under this Government, which is a 44.2 per cent increase. One should compare that again with the Sydney to London international fare, which has increased by only 23 per cent; again it is just about half the increase.

SPEECH.PARA: If one takes into account the minimum fares and special discounts one receives when travelling overseas, one notes, for example, that the Sydney to Singapore minimum fare has increased by only 15 per cent while the internal fare on the major trunk route in Australia has increased by 45 per cent; that is three times the increase experienced for overseas travel. Certainly there are some minimum fares in Australia but they are not as readily available as with overseas air traffic. The minimum fares for Sydney to London have increased by 25.9 per cent as against the 44 and 45 per cent increase in internal air traffic.

Why has this happened? Is it because of a lack of competition? Is it because the Government's policies have brought about a situation when one possible challenger-East-West Airlines Ltd-to the two airline system ended up in its being wiped out or being dismembered under the policies that this Government has maintained. These policies have not led to a stronger, more virile Australian Airlines. Although I have a great deal of time for Mr Strong-and in the early days of Australian Airlines there was certainly a lift in its effort and capacity-that lift seems to have diminished a little now. There is no doubt in my mind that Australian Airlines is now facing a difficult competitive future. If the sort of legislation now being reintroduced had been allowed to remain in 1984, I believe we would have been on a much better basis for the Australian airline industry to be providing effective competition and, therefore, cheaper fares and better service to the airline users of Australia. Surely that should be the objective of government policy, not the doctrinaire nonsense that required this Government to cancel this legislation in 1984 which it is now belatedly reintroducing at this time.
Sitting suspended from 12.45 to 2 p.m.

TALK.START.PARA: —Honourable senators will notice the presence in the chamber today of television cameras and lights. In consultation with party leaders and independent senators, I have granted the usual permission to television networks represented in the Parliamentary Press Gallery to film the proceedings in the Senate for half an hour today, commencing at Question Time. The purpose of the filming is to enable the television networks to obtain footage to illustrate television news items concerning the Senate. The filming will cease at 2.30, at which time the television lighting will be turned off.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Home Affairs in his capacity as Minister Assisting the Minister for Transport and Communications on maritime matters. Is the Minister aware of the chaos in Sydney container depots, where there is now up to a 9-week backlog that is threatening to put some small companies out of business? Is he aware that this backlog appears to be getting progressively worse, and has he heard allegations that some importers have had to pay bribes to tally clerks to get their cargo unloaded? If so, have these allegations been investigated? Does he agree that industrial disputes and restrictive union work practices, particularly in relation to working hours and limits on the number of unpacks, are greatly exacerbating efforts to move the backlog? What action has the Government taken, or is it a matter which is within the responsibility of the Unsworth Government?
—Gareth has the brief.
—I am happy to refer the question to Senator Evans.

—I am aware of the delays which have arisen in Sydney in the unpacking of containerised import cargo. I understand that a meeting has been arranged for later this week between depot operators, the Australian Council of Trade Unions, waterfront unions and shipping companies to consider means of temporarily increasing container unpacking capacity so that the present backlog, which is serious, can be brought under control. Also, the Department is assisting several importers in the clearance of urgent consignments. The problem with unpacking containers illustrates the difficulty the waterfront industries often have in flexibly responding to fluctuating cargo throughputs. The waterfront strategy which this Government has been developing for the last 15 months and which was the subject of a two-hour meeting this morning between 13 Ministers and representatives of all relevant waterfront industry groups-including users, the stevedoring industry, the unions plus the Inter-State Commission (ISC), under whose auspices the current strategy process is continuing-of course addresses these issues and in particular it involves the commencement of a series of hearings by the Inter-State Commission, commencing in March. It can be expected that arrangements at container depots will be an important area of the ISC's investigation and certainly will be a matter which it will be addressing in its report, now expected in July, covering options for structural change on the waterfront.

—Mr President, I have a supplementary question. I thank the Minister for his reply, but the point of my supplementary question is that he did not address himself at all to the serious allegation that we have got to the point where bribery is required to move cargoes. Does the Minister have any information on that and what action, if any, is being taken on it? If he knows nothing about the matter, will he investigate it? I also asked him about the extent to which industrial disputes and restrictive work practices are causing these difficulties and are matters which ought to be able to be resolved without the complex procedures which apparently are required.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —As to the latter part of the question, there is no doubt that the industrial difficulty associated with the closure in December of the Consolidated Cargo Services (New South Wales) Pty Ltd depot has been a significant contributor to the present situation on the waterfront. But there have been other contributing factors, including a significant increase in import containers in the November-January period of the order of magnitude of some 20 per cent, and also there is the smaller but nonetheless not insignificant matter of the closure of the Darling Harbour wharves for a period to allow for the Tall Ships visit. As with so many other things on the waterfront, industrial disputation issues are a factor in the efficiency problems which do continue to be a cause for concern for the Government, but those industrial disputes cannot be wholly placed in the responsibility of the trade unions. They are very often contributed to by managerial practices of long standing which are acknowledged to exist. There are many other inefficiencies apart from those resulting from industrial disputation which are acknowledged by the industry itself to be the product of longstanding managerial practices and other inefficiencies associated with the structure of the waterfront, and a substantial effort needs to be made to overcome these problems. The whole question of the waterfront will remain a central feature of this Government's micro- economic reform strategy and, as I have just indicated, it is very squarely on the Government's agenda, as demonstrated by the very lengthy and productive meeting which was held today and which will, I understand, be the subject of a Press statement to be made by the Prime Minister later today.

ANSWER.PARA: As to the remaining part of Senator Chaney's question, I am aware of some allegations being made about bribery being involved in the movement, or non-movement, of containers on the wharf. I am concerned about those allegations. I have nothing in the nature of hard evidence at the moment but I do propose this afternoon to take up with either the Minister for Justice or the Attorney-General himself the question of an appropriate response to such allegations, possibly in the form of a police investigation.

TALK.START.PARA: —I draw the attention of all honourable senators to the presence in my gallery of a former distinguished President of the Senate, Justin O'Byrne. On behalf of all senators I wish him well, particularly on this visit to Canberra.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: HARRIS-DAISHOWA (AUSTRALIA) PTY LTD: DONATION TO THE AUSTRALIAN LABOR PARTY

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Home Affairs. Will the Minister reaffirm that the Australian Federal Police and the Australian Electoral Commission are investigating the matter of the Harris-Daishowa (Australia) Pty Ltd donation to the Australian Labor Party, without any political interference? Has the Minister been informed of when the Federal Police report will be delivered? Has the Minister's attention been drawn to an article in today's Melbourne Herald quoting `Federal Police sources'? Finally, has the Minister, or to his knowledge any other Minister, authorised the Federal Police to background the Press on this investigation?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I made it very clear yesterday, but I will reaffirm it today, that there will be no political interference in this investigation or in any prosecution.

ANSWER.PARA: Opposition senators interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —I respond to honourable senators by going back to the very start. This investigation was initiated by the Electoral Commission, as it quite properly should have been. It is the Electoral Commission that is, if you like, the custodian of the Commonwealth Electoral Act. It initiated an investigation not into one or two individuals, or any individuals in particular, but into an apparent failure to disclose a donation exceeding $1,000. The matter was put in the hands of the Federal Police without reference to any Minister. That investigation is proceeding. When it is concluded decisions on any prosecutions or any other disposal of this matter will be determined by the Electoral Commission and the Director of Public Prosecutions. At no stage will this Government or any Minister in this Government seek to interfere in that process.

ANSWER.PARA: I am asked whether I have any knowledge as to when the police report will be made available. I have no idea when it will be made available but, given the fact that both yesterday and today Press releases and people in general have expressed an interest in the timing of this matter, I will consult with my colleague Senator Tate and we may institute inquiries simply to ask about how the investigation is going. I would not like it to be thought in this chamber, or anywhere else, that establishing the timing of such an investigation was political interference. The third thing that Senator Black alludes to is a report in today's Melbourne Herald, part of which states:
The key to the case according to the Federal Police sources is the movement of the cheque and covering letter.

I do not believe everything that is written in the Press, and I am not about to impugn the integrity of the journalist who wrote the story. But I do not always find that every article is true in every case. If that were the case, we might as well remove the libel and defamation laws. They are not always accurate. I hope in this case that that report is inaccurate because, given the great reputation built up over many years of the Federal Police, I would regard it as intolerable if members of the police force were at any time backgrounding the Press as to the progress of this investigation. I think I would be joined by everyone in this chamber in condemning the leaking of details of police activities in this area.

Finally, I was asked whether any Minister authorised the Federal Police to do so. I did check this one matter, and one matter only, with Senator Tate, and Senator Tate assures me that he did not authorise any backgrounding of the Press by the Federal Police. I know that I certainly did not. If I did it would be laughed out of court because I have no authority in this particular matter. But it is disturbing that while an investigation is under way the people associated with that investigation are backgrounding certain journalists as to its progress. I find it hard to believe that that has occurred, given the history and given the integrity that has always been exhibited by the Federal Police.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. With superannuation being a matter of major concern and the fear that is spreading among people nearing retirement, will the Minister advise the Senate whether the hurried departure from the Parliament of three senior members of this Government, of whom Mr Young is the most recent and enigmatic, was prompted by their own knowledge of what the future holds for taxation on lump sum superannuation? Will the Minister give an assurance that people who have used superannuation as a form of compulsory saving for their retirement will have the same good fortune as Mr Young in maintaining their right to receive their lump sum entitlement in full? Further, does the Government plan to make any changes affecting the taxation on superannuation, lump sum, investment income or otherwise, and, if so, what are those changes?
—I suppose the honourable senator is referring to the departure of Senator Ryan, Mr Hurford and Mr Young.
—But not Sir James Killen, Mr Fraser and all the others who jumped ship before we amended the superannuation scheme.

—Precisely. I see the political point in the honourable senator's question, but I am quite satisfied that Senator Ryan, Mr Hurford and Mr Young left Parliament for reasons other than consideration of their superannuation entitlement, either actual or potential. I can say that, and of course the honourable senator can make the point-unhappily, it is a free country-that she seeks to make in her question, and I have no doubt she will. In so far as the Government is said to have the superannuation issue on the agenda, no decisions have been made by the Government. If I can provide a more helpful answer, I will certainly put her question to the Treasurer and see whether he can add anything to what I have had to say.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Cooney Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy. I refer the Minister to the purchase by Australian Meat Holdings of Thomas Borthwick and Sons (Australasia) Ltd meatworks. Borthwicks has two abattoirs in Queensland and one in Portland, Victoria. The matter is presently in the hands of the Trade Practices Commission and, accordingly, I do not ask the Minister for any details about it. However, I do ask him whether he is aware of the matter.

QUESTION.PARA: Opposition senators interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —I have to plead innocent. I never actually prompted that question. I do know, however, of Senator Cooney's longstanding interest in the meat industry. I think he has been a distinguished legal representative of some of the major players in this industry over the years. He has asked me whether I am aware of the takeover. Yes, I am. I understand that, as he has said, the matter is at the moment before the Trade Practices Commission. There is an expectation of an outcome of that at some time later this month. I think the 28th has been mentioned as a date on which there might be a decision. In all of those circumstances, as I think the question anticipates, I can only agree, if the question does anticipate, with that anticipation that it would be much more useful for me to wait until there has been an outcome before I comment.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Haines Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce. I preface my question by referring to an article headed `Stop handouts, Minister warns' in a recent edition of the Adelaide Advertiser, in which the Minister is quoted as saying:

QUESTION.PARA: This country is seriously in debt. It has a trade deficit. It has a lot of very cosy arrangements in business and industry which it can't afford and it's got to get rid of those . . .
If it doesn't do that, this government will slip backwards--

TALK.START.PARA: —I said `country', not `government'.
—This country will slip backwards. He went on:

QUESTION.PARA: instead of going forwards and that means we won't have the money to spend on all the things the traditional Labor supporters and people like myself think money should be spent on.

Do these cosy arrangements include such things as accelerated depreciation allowances, tax free superannuation and life fund profits, transfer pricing and negative gearing? If the Minister does not include these costly measures, will he say what those measures are that Australia cannot afford and has to get rid of in order not to become, and again I quote the Minister, `a poor white country in the South Pacific'?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —What Senator Haines has quoted sounds familiar to me. I probably did say most of those things, although I certainly did not say that the Government would slip backwards; I said that the country would. Senator Stone very kindly interjected and made the point that both might slip backwards together, but that is a prospect which one has to face up to in this political business. It is an easy question to ask but an almost impossible one to answer if the honourable senator is asking me to pass judgment on a whole range of issues like accelerated depreciation, negative gearing and so on. The honourable senator then asked me to list a whole range of cosy arrangements. There is such a thing as telegraphing one's punches, but I certainly would not want to list a lot of cosy arrangements which I think exist and which I think governments have to tackle. To identify them as cosy arrangements and things which ought to be tackled might not be the best way of going about it.
—Give us one cosy arrangement.
—Like the motor vehicle industry plan.
—Like time charging of telephone calls.
—If I stayed here talking for a while members of the Opposition would get sufficient interjections to have a list to take back to the electorates.
—You wanted our tax policy. Why don't you come clean?

—I was not enunciating a policy when I made these remarks, not at all. During the last election campaign Senator Michael Baume enunciated a policy of health which he backed away from and he, to use Senator Haines's question in conjunction with Senator Stone's interjection, went down the tube because of his failure properly to enunciate that policy.

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Haines well knows that I was talking on a radio program in Melbourne and it is certainly not my view that it is my job or anybody else's to enunciate on a radio program in answer to questions all the things the honourable senator has in mind. I will try to help the honourable senator over time, to answer a number of points which she makes. I disagree with her first suggestion of what she takes to be a cosy practice. I think it is a very difficult argument but it is certainly not easy to say that accelerated depreciation arrangements are necessarily a cosy practice. I think it is sufficient for my point to say that if I have to argue all these things with her and identify my own position we could go on here forever and I do not intend to do that.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Community Services and Health. It refers to the drug RU 486, the abortion drug which is manufactured by the French chemical company Roussel Uclaf. Is the Minister aware that the Roussel company announced last year that because of possible adverse medical-legal consequences in the United States it would not market the drug in that country `for any reason' despite its approval by the pro-abortion Population Council of New York? Is the Minister aware that the Roussel company has obtained the assistance of researchers who enlisted the support of the World Health Organisation for testing this drug on, amongst others, Australian women and also of the State Family Planning Commission of China, primarily for abortion of living foetuses? Does the Minister support the intention of the Department to give permission for the importation of this prohibited import for trial on Australian women? Is this not a case of a new French test in the Pacific, this time of a weapon of chemical warfare against the unborn? Is it appropriate that this matter should be decided behind bureaucratic closed doors? Will the Minister give an assurance that an opportunity will be provided to Parliament for full debate on this subject and its determination prior to approval being given for the importation of the drug for that purpose?
—I am aware of the drug RU 38-486.
—You are very up with it today.

—Thank you very much, Senator. I hope that remains the case and your interjections reflect your interest. I counted in Senator Harradine's set of questions I think about eight different questions, some of which I cannot answer today. The premises on which some of them are based invite me to draw a conclusion before I answer. I do not know that the premises are accurate but I can say--
—Say why they are not.

—I am saying I do not know whether I can say that the premises are accurate and therefore I will not deal with those questions in which the premise suggests the answer. However, I will say that for the drug RU 38-486 the Roussel pharmaceutical company has been granted approval to conduct a clinical trial in cases where foetal death has occurred in utero during the second and third trimester, that is, during the last six months of pregnancy. What I am saying is that the Roussel pharmaceutical company is enabled to conduct a clinical trial of that drug and that an Australian investigator has also been approached by the World Health Organisation to study the legal termination of early pregnancies using that drug in combination with another drug. Dr Blewett's Department is in the process of examining the available scientific data. Approval has not been granted at this time. All Australian trials are subject to State and territorial legislation and to approval by the ethics committee of the institution where the trials are conducted. I should also say on the subject of this drug that it is meant to address a real and severe medical problem; that is, that in the second and third trimester if the foetus is dead it is not always expelled. If there is dead tissue inside it can give rise to infection. That is in itself a real problem. The purpose of the clinical trial is to examine that tissue. Whether there will be a full debate in this Senate I guess is pretty much up to Senator Harradine but I will take that part of the question on notice and reply to it in more detail when I have a chance to do so.

—I must rise to ask a supplementary question. My question was not addressed to the use of the drug to evacuate the uterus of the dead unborn in the second and third trimesters. That was not my question. My question was addressed to the question of the permission likely to be given by the Department for the drug's trial as a method of abortion of living foetuses. I want an assurance, and I am sure that the Parliament would need an assurance, that there will be a full debate on this particular matter before permission is granted from persons behind closed doors.
—Senator Harradine's supplementary question has the key words `the Department is likely to give permission'. I think I replied to him in the first case that that is an assumption that cannot be made.

—My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. Will the Minister confirm that a general review of the arrangements governing the taxation of superannuation is under way? Will the Minister also confirm that it will be essential for the Government to obtain substantial revenue from decisions resulting from that review if it is to be able to finance any significant cut in the corporate tax rate and, still more, cuts in the personal taxation rate such as the Prime Minister has recently promised? Finally, will the Minister advise Mr Unsworth accordingly?

—It is a pity that I do not have the Budget Speech here with me, because I cannot remember every line of it, but there was in it a sentence or two which said something to the effect that a review of business taxation will be undertaken and completed before the 1988-89 Budget. I think it went on to say that the review would be looking at both the business taxation base and the business tax rate. Why Senator Stone should suddenly develop an acute interest in the specifics of what is being reviewed when it was spelt out, I would have thought fairly clearly, in the Budget Speech last year is, of course, directly attributable to the fact that the National Party thinks that it can get some advantage politically in the coming New South Wales election. The statement was made by the Treasurer at that time. Everybody who is at all interested in the matter has known about it for five months or whatever it is since the Budget came down. I have nothing to add to the statement.

—Mr President, I have a supplementary question. I understand that the Minister's response boils down to his saying that the answers to the first two questions are yes and yes respectively. However, he has not responded to the third; namely, will he advise Mr Unsworth accordingly.
—I have nothing to add to what I said before.

—I direct my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Employment, Education and Training. I refer to reports that the Liberal Party in Queensland has launched a campaign calling for increased education funding in Queensland and is seeking funds from the public for its so-called task force. Is it not a fact that the shortage of places in tertiary institutions in Queensland directly results from the low priority given to higher education by successive conservative Queensland State governments and by the funding policies of the Fraser Government? Since the Hawke Government was elected to office in 1983, has Federal funding for higher education been biased in favour of Queensland and, if so, what are the details?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I did not know that the Liberal Party in Queensland was seeking funds from the public for this reason. I suppose I am pleased that it is seeking funds from the public, because what the National Party in Queensland always does when it wants money is to demand that the Commonwealth Government gives it to it. For example, in October, I think, I received a letter from Mr Harper, the Primary Industries Minister, who, according to my Queensland contacts, is one of the brighter members of the Queensland State Government, telling me that he had attended a meeting at Wandoan, that there had been a drought there and that therefore additional funds should be made available under the rural adjustment scheme for this disaster at Wandoan which was not specified. The envelope, by the way, was addressed to me, the letter began `Dear Mr Keating', and the policy area is within Mr Kerin's portfolio.

ANSWER.PARA: Notwithstanding that, some Department of Finance officers rang Mr Harper's office twice and asked for the details of this alleged natural disaster at Wandoan. On both occasions Mr Harper was not there, but his office promised that he would call back, which he failed to do on both occasions. A couple of weeks ago I received another letter from Mr Harper, which this time was correctly addressed. It was a rather curt note stating that it was about time that I did something about the administrative inefficiency in my office and/or the Department of Finance. Honourable senators can imagine what sort of reply that got.

To return to the question proper, my advice is that applications for tertiary places in Queensland increased by about 9 per cent compared with the figure for last year. That is not at all surprising, of course, because the year 12 enrolment figure has gone up appreciably. Offers have increased by about 3,000 over and above those that were available last year. After the first round of offers there were still vacancies in science, agricultural science, engineering and some teaching courses.

In regard to the latter part of Senator Colston's question, it is true that tertiary education, secondary education and possibly primary education, have long been neglected in Queensland, which by 1983 was reflected by the fact that the higher education participation rate in the 17 to 24 age group was only 80 per 1,000, compared with a national figure of 86 per 1,000. Since 1983 it has increased to 98 per 1,000, compared with the national figure of 102 per 1,000. So there has been both a significant increase in Queensland and nationally and some closing of the gap. Queensland has also received a higher proportion-namely, 22 per cent-of the additional places which are being made available this year than the figure for the population of the State as a proportion of the Australian total, which is 18 per cent. Finally, in the technical and further education area, in which the State retains funding responsibility, the participation rate in Queensland is only three-quarters of the national average and would, of course, be even less were it not for the substantial Commonwealth capital funding that has been provided since 1974.
