TALK.START.PARA: —I draw the attention of all honourable senators to the presence in my gallery of a delegation from the Federal Assembly of the Socialist Federal Republic of Yugoslavia, led by the President of the Assembly, Dr Rozic. On behalf of all senators I extend to the delegation a warm welcome and trust that their stay in Australia is a success.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Justice. I refer to revelations by former National Crime Authority (NCA) commissioner Max Bingham in the Age last Thursday that the National Crime Authority was forced to cancel important drug-related investigations because of interference by Queensland police. I remind the Minister that in answer to a question I asked on 26 October last year in relation to corruption in State police forces he denied that the operations of the National Crime Authority had been compromised. Why did the Minister not then inform the Senate that an NCA undercover drug investigations team had already had to be withdrawn because of interference by Queensland police? Was Mr Justice Stewart not aware of the white-anting when he briefed the Minister, as Mr Bingham clearly was? If not, why not? Or did Mr Justice Stewart advise Senator Tate of the matter and did the Minister therefore again mislead the Parliament when he said the work of the NCA had not been compromised?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I cannot recall the answer given on 26 October. I would like to consult the Hansard, but my recollection is that it was to do with the question of Mr Parker's admission that he was a corrupt--
—You answered about Mr Parker. I didn't ask about Mr Parker.

—I am trying to recall something that apparently happened on 26 October. I do not have the Hansard in front of me, but as I recall I answered a question from Senator Newman in terms of the impact of Mr Parker's role as liaison officer between the Queensland Police and the National Crime Authority. I think it may have been in relation to the question of witnesses who may have been put in jeopardy. I cannot answer the question without the Hansard in front of me in relation to that and I will take that part of it on notice.

ANSWER.PARA: As to the so-called revelation attributed to Mr Max Bingham, a former member of the National Crime Authority, the response which I have cleared with Mr Justice Stewart is as follows: As the Senate is aware, it is not my policy to discuss the operations of the National Crime Authority publicly. From the outset I have been kept fully briefed by the Chairman of the Authority on developments in the matter and I do not believe that the public interest will be best served in this instance by further public comment. I undertake to inspect the Hansard record and give a fuller answer to Senator Newman.

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the attention of the Minister for Finance been drawn to the transcript of an interview with the Leader of the Opposition, John Howard, by Vincent Smith on Adelaide radio station 5DN on 4 February 1988? In that interview did Mr Howard propose financing out of growth a reduction in expenditure as a proportion of gross domestic product (GDP) to a level equal to that of the late 1960s without cutting programs? Has the Minister examined this proposal and will the Government consider implementing it? Has this proposal been suggested before by Mr Howard or any other politician?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have seen the transcript. It is a fascinating piece of reading. It reminds one that Mr Howard started off with his real expenditure and revenue policy in about March last year and it included a consumption tax. That was the real policy-a consumption tax to pay for the reductions in income tax that the Liberal Party proposed to offer. Of course, we all know that within a couple of months that was knocked right out of the ring by the vandals from the north-the Queensland National Party. So he was then left with a phoney policy which was going to cut $11 billion off expenditure, most of which was unspecified.

—I raise a point of order, Mr President. As someone who was involved in the discussions relating to tax policy last year, it is within my knowledge that what Senator Walsh is saying is totally inaccurate. It is totally inaccurate with respect to the Opposition.
—What point of order are you rising on?

—My point of order is that the question was put in order by the questioner by relating alleged facts about Opposition policy to what the Government might implement. That is the reason why I did not take a point of order with respect to the question. I congratulate Senator McKiernan for being a little cleverer than some of his colleagues whose questions have been ruled out of order. My point of order is that the question was put in order by that subterfuge, and the Minister is now replying in terms of statements about the position of the Opposition in March last year which are quite inaccurate. The Minister can have no basis in fact for what he is saying. I ask you to rule that in answering that question the Minister should confine himself to whether or not the Government is in a position to implement or intends to implement the measures which were outlined by Senator McKiernan in his question. To the extent that the Minister simply thinks that he is free to have a canter over his fictitious accounts of what the Opposition policy was or might have been in March of last year I ask you to call him to order and to restrict him in that way.

—On that point of order, Mr President: I think it is intolerable that you be put into the position of having to arbitrate on matters of truth between Senator Chaney and Senator Walsh. My point of order is that Senator Chaney's point of order is just a device by which he can get up and make a minute speech and nothing more. It is a trend that has developed in this chamber. It is becoming more and more repetitious and should be dealt with either by this chamber or by the Procedure Committee of this chamber to prevent someone from rising on a point of order without even quoting the point of order in the Standing Orders. I make the final point that it is not up to the President to determine who is telling the truth; that is up to everyone in this chamber to adduce himself.

—There is no point of order. Senator Walsh was asked a question which was clearly within his portfolio. The only standing order that would apply is that the Minister shall not debate the matter. I believe that the question is in order. I have no power to direct the Minister as to how he should answer a question. I ask him to continue.
—I was saying that the next step was Mr Howard's proposed $11 billion in expenditure reduction.
—That is untrue.
—Senator Walters says that that is not true. She had better write a letter to the Weekend Australian. In the 6 and 7 February issue, in an article written by Robert Hadler, it stated:

ANSWER.PARA: It is true that Mr Howard never directly used the $11 billion figure. It was calculated by this writer on the basis of speech remarks made late last year.

But Mr Howard did confirm that the $11 billion figure published in the Australian newspaper was an accurate calculation based on his remarks. That was the tax and expenditure policy phase mark 2 or 3. In Adelaide, as the transcript to which Senator McKiernan referred shows, we had a mark 3 or mark 4 version, depending on how one likes to name it, when Mr Howard said there would be no expenditure cuts at all but that expenditure as a proportion of gross domestic product would be reduced to 23.1 per cent.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I take a point of order. The Minister is now debating the question. I ask you to call him to order.
—Order! I remind the Minister not to debate the question.
—I do not believe that I am, Mr President. I am stating the facts.
—Order!

—The facts are shown in the transcript to which the question referred. Mr Howard said that he was proposing no expenditure cuts at all but that he was proposing that expenditure would be reduced to 23.1 per cent of gross domestic product by holding expenditure constant in real terms over a period of three to four years. Whether that three to four years is correct is impossible to say in the absence of a given rate of GDP growth but at a GDP growth rate of about 3 per cent it would take about five years for that 23.1 per cent figure to be reached.

ANSWER.PARA: The final part of the question asked whether the proposal had been suggested before, that is, the proposal to hold expenditure as a proportion of GDP constant. I am not sure whether it has been proposed before. I very clearly remember undertakings being given in the period Mr Howard was Treasurer-not perhaps given by him but by Mr Fraser-that expenditure as a proportion of gross domestic product would be reduced. But the record of actually delivering on that proposal when Mr Howard was Treasurer was not very good at all.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Panizza Sen J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. I refer to his statement on Business Sunday:

QUESTION.PARA: The whole issue of Telecom's charging, its regulation and so on is in the melting pot still.

Will the Minister say what particular matters remain in the melting pot? For instance, does he agree with the Prime Minister that the whole question of business usage of the system is up for examination?

TALK.START.PARA: —The remarks which the honourable senator has referred to have been frequently quoted, and frequently misquoted, although not by Senator Panizza. I am not saying that. In the same program to which the honourable senator referred I said that the Prime Minister had said that the question of Telecom Australia time charging was not to be continued with by the Government. I said that the issue, as the Prime Minister subsequently said, was dead. I said that on the program. I went on to say that the whole question of the regulatory environment for Telecom, which includes methods of Telecom charging and regulation, was in the melting pot. What I simply meant by that was that, as is well known, the Government, as part of the process of structural reform, is looking at a number of industries such as transport, communications and broadcasting. My colleague Senator Evans has reviews going in respect of all those matters. Those matters are under continuing review. But in so far as any specifics of those reviews are concerned, particularly the one Senator Panizza asks me about, we will have to wait and see the outcome of those reviews before one can say anything definite about them.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: LOCAL GOVERNMENT: EQUAL EMPLOYMENT OPPORTUNITY PROGRAM

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Local Government. What measures are being taken in the Office of Local Government in response to the Government's equal employment opportunity policies?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Reynolds Sen The Hon M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Office of Local Government is encouraging the development of equal employment opportunity (EEO) within local government. The Commonwealth has provided funds for a number of equal employment opportunity projects under the local government development program. These include $40,000 to the EEO Advisory Unit of the New South Wales Department of Local Government, which has an excellent record in regard to its efforts to promote equal employment opportunity within local government. There is also a study being undertaken by the Municipal Association of Victoria which has identified reasons for the under-representation of women as elected representatives of local government and suggested ways of encouraging more women to stand for local government. Very appropriately, that book is entitled Getting the Numbers. The sum of $47,000 has been made available to the Municipal Officers Association of Australia to undertake an analysis of women's employment in local government and publish the findings.

ANSWER.PARA: At the 1986 annual conference of local government Ministers agreement was reached in regard to resolving in principle to move towards the establishment of equal employment opportunity within Australian local government. They agreed to implement appropriate EEO measures in a manner which was appropriate to each State and to place this topic on the agenda of future Ministers' conferences for ongoing debate to ascertain what achievements had been made. The conference also recommended that the Commonwealth local government development program should accept equal employment opportunity as a priority for funding.

I am pleased to report that in November 1987 EEO representatives from New South Wales, Western Australia, South Australia and Victoria established the national local government EEO steering committee to provide an ongoing forum in local government. It is to meet three or four times annually. The second meeting will take place in Melbourne next week and I hope that all States and the Northern Territory will participate. Unfortunately at this stage the progress made in regard to equal employment opportunity in the non-Labor States is, to put it mildly, negligible, but we would anticipate that as they learn from the Labor States more will be done in regard to equal employment opportunity within local government in Tasmania, Queensland and the Northern Territory.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce. The Minister will recall that debate on the Customs and Excise Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1987 was adjourned from the last session of this Parliament so that industry bodies could make representations to him about their very serious concerns with the Bill. Is the Minister aware that in recent weeks representatives of Australian Consolidated Industries (ACI) and of eight other industry bodies have endeavoured to see him to discuss their concerns about the Bill? Why will the Minister not see them? Is the Minister also aware that his junior Minister, Mr Barry Jones, is also refusing to see any of these industry bodies and, indeed, cancelled a meeting with one of those bodies which was scheduled for 4 February? Was the Minister responsible for that cancellation?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I honestly cannot help Senator Lewis with the last part of the question as to why Minister Barry Jones made the appointment and then cancelled it. It certainly had nothing to do with me; it may have had something to do with his own arrangements. I recall that the legislation was adjourned in the last session of Parliament in order that industry bodies might make representations to the Government and there has been a lot of those representations. As of yesterday I wrote to a number of industry bodies making the point that, as far as I was concerned, the legislation would not proceed until the representations had been fully considered and the consultative process had run its proper course.

ANSWER.PARA: From my own recollection I am unable to say whether ACI particularly sought an appointment with me about its particular problem which relates to soda ash. I have been briefed on both Customs' and my Department's discussions with ACI about the particular difficulty which it has, but I am unable to recall whether the company made an approach to me specifically to see it. However, I am always prepared to see ACI about any of its problems, some of which are large and some of which are small. But it may be that it was considered inappropriate because various officers of the Bureau of Customs were seeing a number of industry groups about this issue and ACI was probably most sensibly treated in the same way.

I do not think the legislation will be brought back until such time as many of these issues are resolved satisfactorily. I think many of them arose from a lack of understanding of the purpose of the legislation, but some of them I regard as very genuine concerns.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister representing the Minister for Defence aware of a newspaper report in the Australian of 8 February concerning the possible siting of an American base in Cape York Peninsula? What licence has the Australian Government given to the United States of America (USA) for it to survey Australian territory for siting foreign bases? Is the Minister aware that this USA proposal is intimately connected with Star Wars? Has any American official contacted the Australian Government concerning new foreign bases in Australia? Has the Government expressed a view concerning any possibility of new bases in Australia? If so, when will the Parliament be informed?

—I am aware of the newspaper report referred to by Senator Wood. No approach has been made to the Australian Government by the United States Government regarding the proposal canvassed in the report. No views have been expressed on the proposal by the Australian Government. The possibility that the proposal is connected with the strategic defence initiative is, therefore, immaterial to this Government.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce. Is it a fact that Australian productivity in the manufacturing sector is generally substantially below that of our trading competitors? Is it also a fact that in the year 1985-86 our productivity actually fell and this financial year it is expected to rise only slightly? Does this mean that instead of catching up we are dropping further behind our trading competitors in manufacturing productivity? Do we badly need a boost in this productivity in order to increase manufactured exports and import replacement, including the necessary investment which often depends on expected productivity? Has the Minister seen a recent statement by the Australian Council of Trade Unions concerning productivity-related wage rises in which the ACTU said that there is no useful scope for the continuation of trade-off bargaining? Is this attitude one that is likely to lead to our desperately needed rise in productivity and consequent recovery from our very serious economic situation?

—I will deal with the last part of the question first. I would not want to say anything here which prejudices discussions between the Government and the ACTU about the current wages system. It is the Government's view that by and large the second tier wage negotiations were a considerable success and I think are widely recognised as such in many industries in terms of productivity gains.
—How many have got it? It is unjust as not everybody has got it.

—I guess that is a point. Where gains can be established, then there has been success, I think. There are some areas where gains have not been established and, accordingly, there has not been success. I do not say that that is an exclusive position, but I think that is generally the picture. I am asked the question: Do we need a boost in our productivity? The answer to that question is undoubtedly yes. I would have given the same answer last year, five years ago and 10 years ago. I just hope that I or my successor here, whoever he may be-will not be giving it in five or 10 years time. I hope he will not have to give the answer yes in five or 10 years time. But I suspect he might because we live in a highly competitive world. A lot of countries and a lot of industries are giving a great deal of attention to the question of productivity. I do not know what survey or comparative study Senator Hamer is referring to when he asks about comparative--
—Your own Department predicts a growth of half of one per cent this year.

—I am just dealing with Senator Hamer first. I am not sure from what survey or material Senator Hamer draws those conclusions. I would have thought that those conclusions are probably wrong, but I am happy to have them examined if the honourable senator would like to put to me the actual study or survey to which he refers.

—Is the Minister for Justice aware of a statement reported in today's Age by the Commissioner of the Australian Federal Police, Mr Peter McAulay, that he supports the death penalty for terrorists who commit murder? Has the Government any intention of acting in accordance with this opinion?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have, indeed, become aware of several reports actually published in the media today which apparently report a Press conference which Commissioner McAulay gave yesterday. Several statements are attributed to him concerning the death penalty. To put it in perspective, Mr McAulay did make it clear that in his view most murders committed in Australia arising out of domestic friction were not the sorts of murders which, if the murderers were convicted, should lead to the execution of the criminals concerned, but he did make some remarks about the possibility of the introduction of the death penalty in those cases of murder which were associated with terrorist activity. In so far as he made that comment he was expressing his own personal view and his view in that regard is certainly not shared by the Government. The introduction in 1973 of Commonwealth legislation to abolish the death penalty followed a worldwide trend against capital punishment. The Government then was of the view that it should act to heighten public regard for the sanctity of human life; moreover-and honourable senators will be aware of this well-worn argument-that capital punishment allowed no room for corrective action where a person had been mistakenly convicted; and in the absence of statistical support for its deterrent value it could not be justified.

ANSWER.PARA: The Australian Institute of Criminology put down a report entitled `Trends and Issues in Criminal Justice-Capital Punishment', in February 1987. That very interesting trends and issues paper indicated that the preponderance of evidence suggested that the abolition of capital punishment had not resulted in any significant increase in murder rates in Australia or in other countries. I assure Senator Zakharov that the Government does not propose to reintroduce capital punishment for Federal or Territory offences, as it does not consider it justified in principle or to be in the community's interest, having regard to such matters as deterrence and public safety.

I take the opportunity to welcome Mr McAulay's appointment as Commissioner of the Australian Federal Police. I believe that he will bring to the management of this pre-eminent law enforcement agency of the Commonwealth a lot of skill and expertise which will help it as it grows into its full stature. I know that Mr McAulay has the full support and confidence of the commissioners of the other Australian police forces and, indeed, of Mr Justice Stewart of the National Crime Authority. In that respect, I am sure he will be able to do an excellent job.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: HARRIS-DAISHOWA (AUSTRALIA) PTY LTD: DONATION TO AUSTRALIAN LABOR PARTY

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yesterday I was asked by Senator Tambling:

ANSWER.PARA: Which Ministers, other than himself-
that is, referring to me-

have either given instructions or directions or have received information from the Australian Federal Police or have had access to information deriving from the AFP in relation to their current investigations into the Harris-Daishowa (Australia) Pty Ltd undisclosed financial donation to the Australian Labor Party?

I had inquiries made last night and the answer is that no Ministers have given such instructions or have been involved in that regard. In case there is any inference that I may have given any instructions or directions, I have not, nor would I in any operational matter.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I have received a letter from Senator Puplick proposing that a matter of public importance be submitted to the Senate for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The need for new and constructive arrangements to be developed between the Commonwealth and the State of New South Wales, following the admission by the Premier of New South Wales that the Labor Party is out of touch with the people of Australia and that his Government has lost the confidence of the people of New South Wales.
I call upon those senators who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of senators required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I propose that the following matter of public importance be debated:

SPEECH.PARA: The need for new and constructive arrangements to be developed between the Commonwealth and the State of New South Wales, following the admission by the Premier of New South Wales that the Labor Party is out of touch with the people of Australia and that his Government has lost the confidence of the people of New South Wales.

We are watching, in the State of New South Wales, the gruesome death throes of the Wran-Unsworth Government, a bunch of archetypal Australian Labor Party apparatchiks, a government with a record whereby half its members end their political careers living at the taxpayers' expense in expensive sinecures while the other half end their political careers living at the taxpayers' expense in Her Majesty's prisons.

Yesterday, Mr Unsworth, the Simon of Cyrene of the Labor Party, who has been condemned to carry its cross for the last few paces, gave a speech to the Labor faithful. We are told that it was a speech written by Graham Freudenberg, a noted wordsmith. If it was, Mr Freudenberg must have cringed as he heard his words regurgitated by the Premier of New South Wales, because it was a speech given by a loser, sounding like a loser, to a bunch of losers. What exactly did Mr Unsworth have to say in this speech? He said, among other things:
The Labor Party, at all levels, must be perceived not just as the true Government of the people, but the true voice of the people . . .
It is not that it must be the true voice of the people provided it is perceived to be the true voice of the people. He said:
We will go among the people-our people-and we will not only talk to the people, we will talk with the people and listen to the people.

What a marvellous condescension from the Premier of New South Wales! He said, `We will go amongst the people'-not so much like a missionary but like an infectious disease. The Premier of New South Wales again felt it necessary to relieve himself of his frustrations by attacking the Labor Federal Government. We see the report on the front page of this morning's Australian, `Unsworth to PM: Lay off super'. The Age today says:

In his second day of pointedly distancing himself from the Federal Government, Mr Unsworth said that `one of the things I want to put an end to is the suggestion that there might be a tax on superannuation funds'.
Mr Unsworth yesterday criticised the Hawke Government, claiming it must accept some responsibility for the flagging performance of the NSW Government in the lead-up to the state election.

So, the flagging performance of the New South Wales State Government was admitted to by the Premier of New South Wales. We were told in the same report that Mr Hawke told the Federal Caucus that the Government in New South Wales was in some difficulty. Is it not interesting that the Age newspaper report says that this is the second day of `pointedly distancing himself from the Federal Government'. Yet on 20 January, the Australian Financial Review reported:

The Federal and NSW Cabinets held a historic joint meeting in Sydney yesterday, setting the scene for an election campaign in which Labor will make as much mileage as possible from the Unsworth-Hawke-Keating team.
Well, the Unsworth-Hawke-Keating troika appears to have lost a couple of wheels since it was attempted to give it a little trot in January this year.

TALK.START.PARA: —Only January.

—As Senator Messner says, it was only in January. It only takes the loss of a major by-election and a small turnaround in the polls for Mr Unsworth suddenly to realise that there are some mates not worth having, they are too expensive to have. And the mates he does not want to have at the moment are the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), the Treasurer (Mr Keating) and the whole rigmarole that allegedly constitutes the Federal Labor Government.

SPEECH.PARA: Is Mr Unsworth alone in his complaint that Labor has lost touch with the people of New South Wales? Far from it! Mr Clyde Cameron, a former Labor Federal Minister, speaking in Adelaide the other day, complained that the Labor Party ought to be careful of becoming the `creature of rich businessmen and that there was evidence to support a strong suspicion that some Labor Ministers were already playing footsies with millionaires such as Abeles, Anderson, Rivkin, Bond, Packer, Murdoch, Singleton and Laurie Connell'. If the Ministers are not playing footsies they are using public money to bail these people out whenever trouble comes along. If Labor is not bailing them out it is simply making life easier for them with all its other legislative changes. Mr Cameron is not alone. Mr Uren, another former Labor Minister, when speaking in August last year, told the New South Wales Young Labor Council that the Prime Minister was leading a government which had betrayed Labor's traditional supporters and the Party's rank and file.

I am delighted to see Senator McMullan sitting in the chamber. I certainly welcome him because he is another person who has been recently reported as having told the National Executive of the Labor Party that there was resentment among wage and salary earners, due to the pressure on their living standards, pressure that has been created exclusively by the policies pursued by the Wran-Unsworth Government in New South Wales and the Hawke-Keating Government in Canberra. He told them that the Labor Party was not sufficiently concerned about or focusing its attention sufficiently on the needs of ordinary Australians. If the Prime Minister thought that simply translating Mr McMullan into Senator McMullan would get the National Executive off his back, he has another think coming, because Senator McMullan's putative successor in the Labor Party's bunker is a certain Mr Hogg, and Mr Hogg has gone on the public record as saying that Mr Hawke and senior Cabinet Ministers have become `isolated and insensitive' to the electorate-and that is certainly the case.

Mr Unsworth says he wants to move among the people. The first thing he is doing is inflicting himself on the poor citizens of Rockdale by actually going to live amongst them. He has decided, as today's Age states, `Poll forces Unsworth to move house'. One must give Mr Unsworth some credit-at least he is moving into a traditional Labor electorate. It is interesting to note the factional unity in this matter that otherwise exists. Senator Richardson and Senator Childs are present in the chamber. They do not agree on very much, but they do agree on the necessity to move out of Labor electorates and into blue ribbon Liberal electorates as quickly as possible, moving from Kogarah to Killara or, in Senator Childs's case, moving up to Scotland Island, where he knows he is sufficiently isolated from plebeian Labor voters because one cannot even get to the place unless one has a private boat.

This is indicative of the whole approach of both the Left and the Right in New South Wales. The one thing they do not want to do is to maintain contact with the ordinary Labor voters and ordinary people of the State. I shall discuss some of the particular matters that simply demonstrate in a range of areas, including the environment, the celebration of Australia's bicentenary, legal rights of people, the economic state of New South Wales and the various skeletons in the closet, the way in which the Labor Party has ensured that it no longer represents the interests of ordinary people. I say `ordinary people', not `ordinary Labor voters', because the Labor Party is as out of touch with those ordinary Australians who never vote Labor as it is with those who traditionally vote Labor. The Labor Party no longer represents anything except its own party factions or its own rich and powerful mates. It no longer represents either traditional Labor voters or traditional Australians battling for decent standards for themselves and their families, their economic well-being, the physical security of their communities and the advancement of their State as a whole.

We have seen the shabby, shoddy way in which the Labor Party has gone about disposing of public land in New South Wales-not in returning it to the people of New South Wales for parks and recreational purposes, but selling it off to rich developers who will make large sums of money from obtaining Commonwealth land on the cheap and reselling it to other people who can afford to pay high prices. The Liberal and National parties in New South Wales have made it clear that a caveat emptor situation exists. Anyone who buys that land at Balmoral has been told by Nick Greiner and Tim Moore, the shadow Minister for the Environment, that a New South Wales Liberal and National Party government will not connect the power or the sewerage or water supplies to any of those sites. We will ensure that that land continues to remain in the hands of the people of New South Wales and not some friends of the Labor Party in New South Wales.

TALK.START.PARA: —They are privatising public land, are they?

—They are not only privatising public land; presumably they expect the sort of private return that they normally obtain when deals of this type are made in New South Wales. We have seen the way in which areas, even those with World Heritage listing such as Lord Howe Island, have been shamefully neglected by the Labor Party at Federal and State level. We have seen the way in which the birthplace of the nation in terms of European settlement, the Kurnell Peninsula, has been raped by people who have been allowed to get away with developments on that peninsula, contrary to the wishes of the people of the area and environmental advice. We have seen how easily they turn upon people who do not toe the line on all sorts of Labor plans. We have seen, after all, the Harris-Daishowa incident and how one day Mr Loosley could write to the company thanking it for the marvellous donation, and how the next day Mr Unsworth could stand back and describe the donation as dirty money. The only difference between clean money and dirty money to Labor Party members is that clean money is what is put in one's pocket without telling anybody and dirty money is money other people have to know about when it is handed over.

SPEECH.PARA: Yesterday, in the Caucus, Senator Richardson, as the great organiser of various factions, told everybody how important the environmental movement is and how important the green vote is in New South Wales. However, the headline in today's Sydney Morning Herald was, `Labor's anti-greenies come out of the woodwork'. It is not so much that they are coming out of the woodwork as the fact that somebody kicked over a stone and there they were. People who otherwise have immediate access and are courted by Senator Richardson and his mates, such as Mr Phil Toyne of the Australian Conservation Foundation, are now condemned in the Labor Party Caucus. Mr Toyne was described as `an ice charlatan'. All of a sudden, friends become enemies and enemies become friends, clean money becomes dirty money and mates in the Labor Party in Canberra become people the Labor Party does not want to have around during an election campaign.

One should consider the hypocrisy of the State Labor Government when the bicentennial celebrations were being planned, and how the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs in New South Wales, Mr Gabb, could say that he would not have anything to do with the bicentennial celebrations. He said he would boycott the celebrations. In appealing to those who are sensitive to the Aboriginal cause in New South Wales, Mr Unsworth said that it was perfectly proper for Mr Gabb to boycott the celebrations. However, during the course of the visit, Barrie Unsworth stuck closer to the Princess of Wales than a blowfly at a barbecue. If he had got any closer he would have been committing a criminal offence. The Labor Party was parading itself around the place as the party of great initiators during the bicentennial celebrations, the party that brought the great spectacle to the people of New South Wales-but the Minister had to be given permission by the Premier to boycott the celebrations.

By attempting to become all things to all men, the Labor Party in New South Wales has become nothing to anyone. It has attempted to extinguish the legal rights of people in New South Wales. Changes to the workers compensation system, which is of critical importance to traditional Labor voters and people in the lower socioeconomic stratas of society, represent changes to the rights of those people at common law and are nothing short of scandalous.
Mr George Petersen, a former member of the Labor Party, who has held a seat in Parliament for many years, made the following statement when the new Labor Government legislation was introduced:

I oppose the legislation because it represents the most massive attack on the rights of New South Wales workers by any Government, Liberal or Labor, in my nineteen years in this Parliament. It is a complete reversal of Labor's policies and practices since Jack Lang introduced workers compensation in 1926-
for which he was expelled from the Australian Labor Party.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who was it that said that?
—It was George Petersen, former Labor member for Illawarra. We oppose that legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: The economy of New South Wales has been driven into the ground by the State Labor Government. On a number of occasions Senator Stone has drawn attention to the way in which the last New South Wales State Budget was the most irresponsible Budget in its public expenditure brought down in the past couple of years. He quoted extensively from the work done by Mr Les McCarrey of the Institute of Public Affairs (IPA) in Western Australia, indicating how bad Labor budgets have been.

In our Dateline News Digest of today it is indicated that the cost of business visits to Sydney increased in the past year by 25 per cent-more than any other major city in the world. That is a result of the policies put in place by the Wran-Unsworth Government. We have seen that retail sales growth in New South Wales has been among the most sluggish. The number of residential dwelling commencements-something of absolutely imperative significance to low income people including traditional Labor voters in New South Wales-over the past 12 months decreased by a massive 13.8 per cent while the numbers were up, for example, in Victoria. Adult earnings in New South Wales have grown far less quickly than in the remainder of the country. The consumer price index has gone up much faster in New South Wales than in the remainder of the country. The unemployment rate in New South Wales has in the past 12 months grown at a greater rate than the national average. We have a whole series of indicators by which this Labor New South Wales Government can be judged.

We have not yet started to explore all the ramifications of the latest example of political interference in the New South Wales judicial system, revealed by the Tina Wong case. That scandal has yet to be explored, but it will be explored. The truth will be told about this in the same way as the truth was eventually told about the Brereton business, about the Farquhar business, about the Jackson business and about all the other scandals and political interference in New South Wales.

If there is one thing that ordinary people resent more than anything else, it is not just the assault upon their standards of living but the assault upon their parliamentary and judicial systems. They know that justice in New South Wales is a tradable commodity under the Labor Party Administration and will remain so until steps are taken to clean up that whole system. My colleagues Senator Peter Baume and Senator Brownhill will be drawing attention to a large number of other matters in respect of this matter of public importance. Tomorrow we will again have the opportunity to debate the scandalous assault which this Labor Government in New South Wales, aided and abetted by the Labor Government in Canberra, has made on the health and welfare systems of the people of New South Wales. But perhaps just to prove that the devil can quote scripture for his own purposes, I should bring to mind two last sad relics. The first is the way in which Laurie Brereton, once upon a time the golden haired boy of New South Wales, was chucked out of his ministerial office the moment he looked as if he was becoming a political embarrassment to the Government. I give the final word to the most discredited politician in Australia's recent history, Neville Wran, who said this:
No government that has been in office for 11 years deserves another try.

The Wran-Unsworth Government does not deserve another try. It is going to get a trial but not another try. That cannot come quickly enough to install in New South Wales a Liberal and National Party Government which will not only clean up the Augean stables that that State has become under Labor, but also will restore real contact and real hope to the people of New South Wales and Australia generally.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALKER.NAME: Senator RICHARDSON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories)

TALK.START.PARA: —Today we have seen the first of what no doubt will be a number of instalments in the saga of the New South Wales election over the next couple of weeks. I do not think I heard anything new over the past 20 minutes or so and I suspect that nobody else did either. Nonetheless we will all ritually come in here over the next couple of weeks; I will listen to insults from the other side of the chamber and, as usual, I will answer them with wit and charm.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to begin by looking at the perspective from which Senator Puplick made his speech. It seems to me that if one looks around Australia and starts with Queensland, Madam Acting Deputy President, one recognises that the Liberal Party is not in government. It is a National Party Government-it is not a Bjelke-Petersen one any more but it is a National Party Government.

When we move south of Queensland, we find that in New South Wales, Victoria, South Australia and Western Australia there are Labor governments. In fact, what does the Liberal Party rule as we enter our bicentennial year? The Liberal Party has government in the island State of Tasmania and a share of government, if you like, by the Country Liberal Party in the Northern Territory. If one adds it all up, that means the Liberal Party can claim government over something like 450,000 people out of Australia's 16 million. The Liberal Party in Australia in 1988 is an irrelevance. (Quorum formed)

I am always grateful to those who want to try to stop my speaking because it demonstrates that whatever I am saying must be doing some damage. As I was saying, at the moment the Liberal Party speaks from the perspective of a party that governs something like 450,000 out of 16 million Australians. At the national level the Liberal Party is more than an irrelevance; it is non-existent. The Liberal Party is a rump. The conservative parties are now in a similar position to that of the Labor Party of the 1950s. They are alone, they are involved and they are going nowhere. Similar to the Labor Party in the 1950s, it must also be said that they are wracked by internal division. In the Liberal Party today we have the wets and the dries. I might say that the wets are a little more in evidence in the Senate chamber than the dries at the moment, although Senator Boswell from the National Party will no doubt make up for all of them with his arrival. The Opposition is dreadfully split.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tell us about last Saturday and the Adelaide by-election. Thirteen per cent!

—There are leadership contenders all over the place. How can one forget last night when Andrew stood up, in a better suit and a much nicer tie than John Howard, and made his pitch. We wonder how many he was to win over. Is there any authority in the Party? We must remember the performance of John Howard. Last July the Labor Party won its historic third term, and that had never happened before.
—It will not happen again, either.

—Senator Boswell, in his own peculiar and particular style, has interjected. He was referring to the swing against us in the Adelaide by-election-the end of the world swing in the Adelaide by-election. I recall looking at the polls at the end of 1986 and members of the Opposition gleefully telling me that everything was all right, things would go back to normal in Australia and that the Labor Party was on the way out. We dipped at one stage to 41 per cent, but come the time of the election eight months later, there we were winning another election and increasing our majority. When the crunch comes, when the pen actually goes to paper and the people of Australia vote, they will take a long hard look at you lot and they just will not wear you. Now that it has happened three times in a row, I think members of the Opposition must be prepared for a lot more. The voters repelled a divorced coalition.

SPEECH.PARA: I can take Senator Boswell back to that coalition, because he remembers that. He had a bit to do with it, as I recall, because it was the Queensland Nationals who took the Nationals out of the coalition, was it not? As I recall, they did not like their leader. I keep hearing that they are going to promote Senator Stone. I hope they do, if only to alleviate the boredom in the Senate. Anything new would be better than the existing leadership.

I want to refer to remarks by some Liberal Party luminaries who have commented on the state of their Party in recent times. If one does not like the state of the Labor Party in Australia, one should ask the Liberal Party President-and the national President of the Liberal Party is not an insignificant person-what he thinks. What did John Elliott, from Elders-IXL Ltd, say about the Liberal Party? He said, `We didn't deserve to win'. That was yet another pitch from one of the extraparliamentary contenders, another one after John Howard's mantle. I quote a prominent Liberal from the House of Representatives:
The overwhelming decision of the electorate was that it was not prepared to accept Howard, his policies, campaign or his people.

Hear, hear! At least one Liberal has got something right. The coalition failed to understand last July, and it is incapable of understanding it now, that the Australian people still care about some social values. As well as balance sheets and dollars there are other things in the world about which they care. They care, of course, about the environment.

Before I finish today I will remind Senator Puplick of some of the things he has not done within his own party about the environment. I note that he said that somebody from the Australian Conservation Foundation was attacked, verbally, in our Caucus room yesterday. That is true. I would have to concede that there are some people in the Australian Labor Party who do not like the green movement. But the difference between this side and that side over there is that nobody over there likes the green movement. They have all spent years attacking that movement. Their policies totally reject any environmental ideals. Given that Eden is becoming such a big issue for all of those opposite because of the Harris-Daishowa (Australia) Pty Ltd matter, why do we not ask Senator Puplick whether or not he supports Nick Greiner when Nick Greiner says that if the Liberals win, the 80,000 hectares of national parks just dedicated in the Eden region will go? Why do we not ask him whether he supports logging in those parks? Will he take the position he has on the tropical rainforests of north Queensland? Will he tell us that next August he might let us know if he has got his party to agree to anything? The reality is that the electorate will always reject the politics of greed. They will reject the Liberal Party's line for the rich.

We heard Senator Puplick refer to Clyde Cameron, who attacked some people in the Labor Party for being close to millionaires. All I have to say is that the Australian people have shown often in recent times that they know where the Labor Party stands. They have stuck with us through thick and thin because they will always reject the approach of the Liberal and National parties.

TALK.START.PARA: —They rejected you out of hand two weeks ago.
—Order! Senator Boswell, Senator Richardson has the call.

—Senator Boswell is a most unruly fellow. As we have heard before, and as I have said, we will no doubt hear a lot more of this in the next few weeks, the Labor Party has ruled New South Wales for 36 of the last 47 years. That is what the people of New South Wales have thought about the matter. Now we hear Senator Puplick, of all people, talking about ordinary people. We are going to take up a collection on our side and issue Gregory's street directories to all the Liberals in New South Wales so they can find the western suburbs. They have suddenly discovered there are votes in them, but they have yet to discover where they are. I would hope that, unlike Rosemary Foote and others who could not even find their way across the Gladesville bridge, just a few Liberals will venture out west, if they are game. I suspect that not too many of them will be game when the crunch comes.

SPEECH.PARA: In Nick Greiner's New South Wales Inc. there are only two rules: the survival of the fittest and the survival of the richest. They are the rules under which he seeks to conduct affairs in New South Wales. We saw last year in the July Federal poll, and we will see the same thing when the State election comes around this year, a fair go from the Labor Party and dog eat dog from the other side. In the end I am sure that people will make the same decision that they made last time. Nick Greiner does not offer any new program, any new approach; it is all the old program, the old approach that we saw from John Howard last year.

It is pretty hard to find out just what Greiner stands for. There are no policies; there is no chance that one can pick up a book and find a policy. All we know is what Nick Greiner does not want, because he spends a lot of time whinging and whining. There is nothing positive; everything is negative. In the next few weeks there will have to be a change to all of that if he wants to win. He will also have to explain how he balances his freeze in government spending with the $1.2 billion worth of promises he has made over the past few months.

Just how will he make the two parts of the equation add up? Perhaps he will turn to a Liberal Party apparatchik for help? We have heard attacks on Labor Party apparatchiks. I recall that only last June when there was some figuring going on in the Liberal Party's back rooms, when the abacus was out and they were adding up their proposals for a Budget to go to the people with, the person who had the abacus was Jim Carlton, a former Secretary of the New South Wales branch of the Liberal Party. What happened? As usual, he got it wrong-horribly wrong-and of course when that effort was seen, when that fraud was exposed, the Liberals backed off and the people backed off them.

Let us have a look at the effect on health services Nick Greiner's coming into government would have. You will recall, Madam Acting Deputy President, that the conservative government in Queensland has already introduced a number of charges in public hospitals, and the coalition in New South Wales would follow the same path. The Opposition intends to push more and more people into private health funds. It intends, so we are told, to get right away from Medicare. It will satisfy the demands of the Australian Medical Association. For all the talk of dirty money and clean money, might I say this: it is all right for Nick Greiner to write to doctors in New South Wales and say `Send me some money', because Nick Greiner intends to run the hospital system, the whole health system, for those doctors. Why would they not send him money? He is saying to them, `Charge what you like, do what you like; it will be all okay'. But I do not think the people of New South Wales will wear that approach. Obviously Nick Greiner wants to move towards the United States system, where something like 40 million people are not covered by health insurance and where the cost of the privatisation of health care has been enormous. If there is to be no coverage, no access for ordinary people to medical care, the prescription that Nick Greiner and the Liberals have for New South Wales will be, as always, as I said, the survival of the richest.

Some issues other than health are worth mentioning in the few minutes I have left. Nick Greiner has loudly trumpeted the user pays principle in the area of transport. This means that the people in those suburbs that the Liberals cannot find without the aid of a street directory are the people who will suffer. How much does old Nick care for the battlers in the western suburbs? Under his scheme, the cost of a weekly train ticket between Sydney and Blacktown would jump from $16.70 to $33.75. That is what he wants to give ordinary people-the ordinary people to whom Senator Puplick refers. The cost of a ticket from Sydney to Bankstown for the same period would double from $12 to $24. If a person wants a ticket from Sydney to Wollongong or Gosford he is real trouble. It will go from $21.90 to $44.26. That is what the Liberals want to give New South Wales under their user pays principle. They reject the belief that the transport system meets an essential need of ordinary people. There is a requirement for community services. Their proposals go back to the elitist principles upon which the Liberal Party was founded and which today it still embraces.

Nick Greiner also says he wants no frills suburbs. This is an interesting point as far as Senator Puplick is concerned, because he professes an interest in the environment. The concept of no frills suburbs means that we will go back to the old days. We will not have any more of those underground utilities, no more power lines underground; they will go back on top of the street because it is much cheaper. We do not need wide streets and wide footpaths; we will go back to the old days and have narrow ones. Why do the Liberals want to do all that? It is because once again the houses and the suburbs in which they will be built will be a long, long way away from Nick Greiner and the Liberal Party. There is just no way that even a street directory will ever get him into those suburbs. I think that quoting the man himself is by far the best way to show this. In a celebrated interview recorded in the Penthouse magazine-that well known working class magazine!-in October 1983 Nick Greiner said:
I have no plans to solve the unemployment problems the Government has.

He has never spoken a truer word. Since July 1987 unemployment in New South Wales has fallen from 9.3 per cent to 7.5 per cent. That is the record for jobs in New South Wales. That is what the Unsworth Government is delivering. For the first time since the Liberal Party-induced recession of 1982, unemployment in New South Wales is lower than the national average. It continues to go down. New South Wales now has the second lowest rate of unemployment in Australia.

One hundred and three thousand new jobs were created in New South Wales in the last year. That is what Barrie Unsworth has done for New South Wales. New South Wales has had a growth rate of 4.4 per cent-virtually double that of the rest of Australia. That is what the Unsworth Government has done for New South Wales. Only a Labor government can protect jobs. Only a Labor government can create them. Only conservative governments destroy them, and their records suggest that they destroy them very quickly, at the rate of several thousand a week during the last year of the Fraser-Howard Government. Nick Greiner's proposals will destroy jobs. He does not offer us a new government or a new program; he offers us only a change for the worse.

Let us consider the feelings of the ordinary people, such as the wage earners. The Liberal Party has opposed every wage increase throughout the whole of the 1980s. For the whole of this decade the Liberal Party has never wanted to offer workers in Australia any wage increases at all. Poverty is the prescription it offers them. It is the only thing it knows for the people who live on the other side-give them poverty, feed them nothing. The Labor Party fortunately has a different view. Our view of what we have to do for the commuters, for the sick, for the disabled and for the pensioners is very different.

If Barrie Unsworth said anything the other night, I think he said this: `We do not have a problem in knowing where we stand. We do not have a problem in having the right policies. We do, however, need to improve our communication, and that is something upon which we are working'. But one would hope that communication is not the only thing upon which governments are won. In the end the people of New South Wales, and indeed the people of Australia, who have a pretty fair record of making the right choice, will do so again. When the crunch comes, they will support the party that looks after them and not the party that believes in only the two rules that I mentioned earlier-survival of the fittest and survival of the richest. That is what Nick Greiner wants for New South Wales, and that is what New South Wales will never want from Nick Greiner.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLean Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats, of course, support the proposition submitted to the Senate by Senator Puplick on behalf of the Opposition. It is essentially in two parts. The first suggests that we-namely, we as a Senate and we as a nation-recognise the need for effective co-operation between the Commonwealth and the States in order to best serve the interests of Australians. That is the very essence of our federal system. We would not disagree with that. The second part acknowledges that the New South Wales Government has lost touch with the electorate and is about to lose office. Certainly, the Australian Democrats agree with that. We go further, however, and suggest that, tragically, the Australian Labor Party and all its governments seem to be equally at fault and equally to have lost contact with their electorates in each of the States in which they are presently in government.

SPEECH.PARA: What is implied, of course, is that when the coalition comes to power in New South Wales in several weeks time things will suddenly change for the better. Well, the Democrats have some reservations about that. Two significant things will happen in New South Wales on 19 March, when we go to the polls to elect our new State Government. The first is that there will be a change of government, and we are fairly confident that that will happen. But the second is that the balance of power in the Upper House will pass to Australian Democrats and Independents. In short, the people of New South Wales will again call upon the Democrats to keep the others honest, in the same way as they have depended upon us to perform that role effectively in the Senate.

What we really have before us now is a trumped up excuse, in a pre-election climate, to throw some stones at the New South Wales Labor Government. We have no objections to that. We have some stones to throw at the Labor Government in New South Wales as it departs after a disastrous decade. We, like the coalition, believe that Labor has had it in New South Wales. As I have moved around the State in recent weeks, I have sensed that voters believe yet again that is is time for a change. Certainly, the prospect of a Greiner-led coalition government does not seem to have set hearts pounding, but they most definitely want to end the present undemocratic centralist regime.

It seems reasonable to ask why the people of New South Wales are going to change their Government on 19 March. It comes down to the fact that the arrogance and deception of the Hawke-Wran-Unsworth governments have created a yawning gulf between Labor governments and the people who elected them. There is in fact a huge gulf. The voters of New South Wales especially, but one could also add those of Victoria, South Australia, Western Australia and of Australia at large, are now seeing through the contemptuousness of Labor governments.

This contempt for the people is nowhere better illustrated than in the crude and destructive changes made to the electoral processes in New South Wales in recent months. The Parliamentary Electorates and Elections (Amendment) Bill and the cognate Election Funding Bill are an outrageous attack upon democracy and the rights of Independents, interest groups and minor parties to participate in New South Wales State elections. It is now law, having been rushed through the Parliament by the Government in the final days of the last parliamentary session. Significant clauses affect the conservation movement and its desire to influence elections by campaigning for the environment, to mention only one of the impacts of this crude Act.

Here are just some of the effects of this Act: First of all, it is now an offence to distribute on polling day electoral material that was not registered and approved by the Electoral Commission. I will repeat that: It is now an offence, in a democracy, in Australia, to distribute on polling day electoral material that has not previously been registered with the Electoral Commission. Electoral material cannot be registered for distribution if the group does not have an endorsed candidate. Furthermore, electoral material is defined in extremely broad terms and must be registered with the Electoral Commission eight days prior to polling day.

TALK.START.PARA: —So, interest groups can distribute nothing.

—Interest groups can distribute nothing in support of candidates with whom they identify without contravening the Electoral Act, and this is in a democracy, in Australia, in 1988, bastardised and distorted by a Labor Government in NSW only a few months ago, and done in the early hours of the morning in the last few days of parliamentary session.

SPEECH.PARA: The registration of a political party has been made much more difficult. The number of members now required to register as a political party has doubled to 200, which must restrict groups of concerned citizens in organising to take advantage of an election to air an issue. The very essence of democracy has been truncated, and quite deliberately. The fielding of candidates has become extremely difficult for groups or minor parties. It now takes $750 to register to become a candidate for the Legislative Council-$750 to contest an election as an ordinary citizen. It costs $500 to nominate to contest for election to the Legislative Assembly. Amazingly-this is truly amazing-the Act now prevents the use of the word `independent' in association with another political party. In other words, one cannot run as an independent Labor candidate, an independent Democrat or an independent something else. Quite clearly, the intention of this is to cut off at the knees the source of the Australian Labor Party's greatest difficulty, its own disaffected who leave and choose to run on matters of principle as independent Labor candidates or as independent something else. And this is in 1988 in one of the great democracies, so-called, of the world; namely, New South Wales, Australia.

Is it any wonder that there is a conspiracy theory raging out in the community? Even though the Democrats do not support the conspiracy theory as it is propounded by Peter Sawyer, we do understand why it should have emerged in the context of such draconian laws at the State level in Australia. Of course these, running in parallel with proposals such as the Australia Card, have aroused the growth of suspicion in Australian voters. The Australian Democrats Leader in the New South Wales Parliament, the Hon. Elisabeth Kirkby, MLC, led a valiant but unsuccessful assault against this legislation. We were certainly grateful that the coalition Opposition expressed equal abhorrence. I quote the Leader of the Opposition in the New South Wales Legislative Council, the Hon. Ted Pickering, who said:

This is yet another attempt in a series of efforts by the Government to undermine the role of the Upper House-recent attacks have focused on Upper House committees, and now they have extended their attack to try to destroy the democratic integrity of the Legislative Council--

and the processes by which it is elected. This is not, of course, the only area where the New South Wales Government has demonstrated contempt for the institution of parliament. In an attempt to answer a question from a constituent concerning access to national parks in New South Wales, my Democrat colleague Elisabeth Kirkby recently requested a copy of the relevant regulations from the National Parks and Wildlife Service. She heard back from it only today that it is not able to provide her with those regulations or indeed any information at all; that it had been instructed by the Minister, Mr Carr, that it was not to give any information to any member of parliament or the representative of a member of parliament. This was advice that came to an elected member of the State upper House today. So much for New South Wales Labor's contempt for the electorate and for parliament.

The Labor Party in New South Wales has been inconsistent as well as extraordinarily contemptuous. The Wilderness Bill 1987 was but one example. A Democrat amendment in the interests of Aboriginal land rights referred to as the Uluru lease back mechanism and in line with stated Labor policy was negated by the Government. Yet now, in pre-election days and with new found love of the wilderness, Mr Carr is promising to amend the legislation in line with the very Democrat amendment which the Government previously disregarded. Really, this blatant political inconsistency is extremely transparent.

Not only has the New South Wales Labor Government been contemptuous and inconsistent but it has also been inept. Let me give just one example. Already its workers compensation legislation is in serious strife. The New South Wales Government, in its arrogance, chose to ignore the advice of both the unions and the legal community. South Australia's effective model, which greatly reflects the contributions of Democrat Legislative Councillor Ian Gilfillan, was equally ignored in the enacting of its present form of workers compensation. Of course, it has been very much the style of the New South Wales Government to railroad through sloppy, poorly drafted legislation and then attempt to keep it afloat with a myriad of tangled and confusing regulations. As a result, its workers compensation legislation is in desperate strife, and it is only one example. Indeed, the Australian Democrats agree that the Unsworth Government is out of touch and must and will go.

Finally, I would like to return to the first proposition that is before us; namely, the glaring need for effective State and Federal co-operation. Where such co-operation is absent the community can pay an enormous cost. I will illustrate this point. Just today I received a phone call from a Democrat in Kyogle, which is one of the safest National Party seats in the State, who cited the fact that in the Kyogle Shire there are 371 timber bridges that are more than 50 years old. Numerous school buses carrying hundreds of children daily use these bridges, exposing the young passengers to real danger. For years the community-as I said, in a safe National Party seat-has not been able to convince the State Labor Government to seek from the Federal Government the $1m or $2m necessary to rectify this potentially disastrous situation. As evidenced by the article that appeared on page 3 of the Northern Star of Tuesday, 16 February, voters in this electorate-and I would imagine in many others-endorse the need for better and closer co-operation between Federal and State governments.

It would seem that the coalition parties, by raising this matter of public importance, besides providing themselves and the Australian Democrats with the opportunity to offer fair and strong criticism of the present New South Wales Labor Government, are also promising when in government to strive hard to keep close to the people and to forge strong and effective relations with the Federal Government. I am interpreting that as the promise that is inherent in these propositions. The Australian Democrats, who will almost certainly hold the balance of power in the New South Wales Upper House after the election on 19 March, give their assurance that they will give their total co-operation in forging a better and more democratic future for the people of New South Wales.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a pleasure to follow Senator McLean in this debate and to commend the sentiments which he has expressed in support of the terms of this matter of public importance. The matter reads:

SPEECH.PARA: The need for new and constructive arrangements to be developed between the Commonwealth and the State of New South Wales, following the admission by the Premier of New South Wales that the Labor Party is out of touch with the people of Australia and that his Government has lost the confidence of the people of New South Wales.

The Labor Government of New South Wales has lost the confidence of the people of that State. It is to all intents and purposes finished. It no longer has public acceptance or acceptability. Labor in New South Wales has the smell of electoral death about it. It is a stale and tired Government recognised as such be everyone who cares to look. The citizens of New South Wales have lost patience with Labor; they have lost faith in the Labor Party and its Ministers and the people of New South Wales want a change. The Labor Government has lost its capacity to develop or carry out any arrangements with the Commonwealth. That makes this matter of public importance a proper one for discussion here today.

The desire for change that we recognise emerged some time ago and has been reflected in opinion polls for some months now. The opinion polls have shown consistently and continuously that Labor is finished in the premier State of Australia. It is not at all surprising that it should be so. Governments have their beginning, they have their maturity and they have their old age. Labor in New South Wales is now an aged Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a senile Government.

—Yes. It has run out of steam and run out of ideas. It has grown in arrogance and that could not have been demonstrated better than when Senator Richardson this afternoon talked about Labor having `ruled'-that was his word-for so many years. Why did he not say `served' the people of New South Wales? Senator Richardson did not say it because he meant what he said. It is indicative of the arrogance of a Labor Government in New South Wales and of the people who ran the Labor machine in that State. The Government has been characterised by its patronage and its cronyism. All these things have disgusted the citizens of the State. They have made the Government the object of concerned pity from the rest of the country.

SPEECH.PARA: New South Wales Labor has other disabilities besides the poor quality of its government. It has been tainted by corruption for years. The smell of that corruption-the corruption around the Australian Labor Party and the Labor machine-is with the Party and its State parliamentarians. The people of New South Wales know and understand this. How much has to happen before a government gets into such a sorry state? It has taken many scandals and quite a few years in New South Wales. John Dowd first raised awkward questions about corruption in New South Wales a decade ago. His allegations were denied. Labor attacked John Dowd personally and mercilessly for the allegations. But as the years have passed and as events have unfolded, most of John Dowd's claims have been vindicated. Not only did they have substance, but he was right-not once, but again and again. What he alleged about corruption in New South Wales has come to be revealed as fact. Not only that, but the confirmed corruption has moved further and further into the Government of the State of New South Wales during the period that Labor has served as the Government. No one has ever explained properly why the Labor Government intervened to prevent one of its members, Mr Brereton, going on trial early in its term of office.

TALK.START.PARA: —The first act of the Government was to squash that prosecution.

—Senator Puplick says it was the first act of the Government. It intervened to make sure that one of its members did not go on trial after he had been committed for trial. No one has ever explained why that was done. No one has ever explained why a Labor Premier for so long and so fiercely protected Mr Rex Jackson. The people of New South Wales remember Mr Rex Jackson. He was a Labor member of the Parliament of New South Wales. He was a Labor Minister in the Labor Government now coming to its death. He was caught using his official office for corrupt purposes. His Labor Premier tried to deny the substance of the charges and to blacken the names of those who were exposing Mr Jackson. But it did not work and eventually he was charged, convicted and sentenced. The people of New South Wales remember, too, that the Labor Government at the time decided that Mr Jackson's legal bills would be borne by the public-the taxpayers of New South Wales-until the public outcry forced a retreat from that position.

SPEECH.PARA: The people of New South Wales remember Mr Mochalski, too. He was a Labor member of the Parliament. He had to resign in the face of scandal, but because he is yet to face trial I will say no more about him or the circumstances surrounding his resignation. The people of New South Wales remember the police commissioner, Bill Allen, promoted inexplicably over many more senior police by a Labor Premier against all advice. The people of New South Wales remember the subsequent resignation of that police commissioner in disgrace, associated with corruption.

The people of New South Wales remember the extraordinary extensions of term for the Chief Stipendiary Magistrate, Mr Murray Farquhar. The people of New South Wales remember the outrageous Cessna-Milner judgment he made, and the absolutely astounding things that occurred during his last days as Chief Magistrate. The people of New South Wales know that that particular Labor crony, Mr Murray Farquhar, has been charged, convicted and sentenced and has served his prison term for corrupt behaviour.

The people of New South Wales remember the case of Kevin Humphreys. They remember the rorting of Labor Party branches. They remember the Enmore conspiracy case. They remember Labor's reluctance and slowness in investigating the death of my former friend and a former Liberal candidate, Donald Mackay. They also remember the abuse that was heaped upon the Mackay family by the former Labor Premier of New South Wales when they complained about the slowness to investigate this matter.

The people of New South Wales remember the criticism of Labor's Mr Grassby by Mr Commissioner Nagle, but since that matter has yet to be concluded elsewhere I will say no more about it. The people of New South Wales remember Mr Tom Domican. They remember Wings Travel. They remember the Labor Premier, Mr Wran, being fined $25,000 for contempt of court-a contempt of a court of New South Wales committed while he was Labor Premier of the State; and so on.

But there are recent events, too. There are the events associated with the resignation of Labor Minister Mick Young. Honourable senators will recall that the Labor Party in New South Wales received money from a woodchipping company last June as a campaign contribution and honourable senators will know that the Labor Party used that money for a different purpose. That matter, and whether Labor officials in New South Wales have committed any offence, will be the subject of a police report soon. But what is clear is that the money was given to the Labor Party and that the Labor Party accepted it. It is also clear that the Labor Party misapplied that money in a manner which enabled Labor to avoid the disclosure requirements of the electoral law.

TALK.START.PARA: —Its own electoral law.

—Yes, its own electoral law, as my colleague says. It is acknowledged by Labor officials that this is what happened and it is acknowledged that they are to blame. But at the same time we have had the extraordinary spectacle of the Premier of New South Wales launching a vicious attack against the donor company-the people who made the money available. The Premier accused them of environmental vandalism, pillage and rape. He described the money which they gave as filthy money, and with a flourish he had the donation returned. Then the people of New South Wales became aware that the company had made further donations to the Labor Party. This time it was to Mr Akister-one of Mr Unsworth's Ministers-to help in his forthcoming campaign. I forget how much it was, but I think I have seen in the newspapers that it was $5,000. This was a substantial donation-and to another candidate. The Premier of New South Wales, having described the donations from this company as filthy money on one occasion, has not required these latest donations to be returned. The people of New South Wales call that hypocrisy.

SPEECH.PARA: Instead the people of New South Wales have seen the Premier and the Government of our great State using the people's money for expensive advertising of State services. This advertising is in the run-up to an election-improper advertising. We have seen advertising which is a blatant attempt to buy votes with taxpayers' money-advertising which is also often untruthful. Some of the advertisements are for the much vaunted Healthline-something to do with how good the State hospitals are. Well, it is just pathetic.

TALK.START.PARA: —Absolutely pathetic.

—Just try to use the hospitals in my State! I think my colleague Senator Brownhill may have something to say about that later. But the people of New South Wales who use the hospitals and who try to get access to them know what the situation is. We know what happens when we are in need of services-whether it is hospitals, police, transport or any of the other State services. We know what the situation is and we know who has had the stewardship of our State, who has `ruled the State', as Senator Richardson cares to say-`served the State', we would rather have him say-for over a decade now.
