The people of New South Wales know that these advertisements were crook. The people of New South Wales know the advertisements were untrue and they know that their funding was a scandal. It is yet one more scandalous activity by a corrupted government now in its death throes.

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Clyde Cameron, Mr Hurford and Senator McMullan have all had things to say about the performance of Labor. But now we find the Labor Premier of New South Wales starting to attack his Federal Labor counterparts. He attacks them over the proposal to introduce time charging for telephone calls. He is now attacking his Labor colleagues over some superannuation matters. He has admitted and acknowledged what the polls have been saying for months, namely, that his Government is trailing badly, that the people do not like him as Premier and that they are sick of the Government which he leads. The people of New South Wales are sick of his Government. The people of New South Wales do not like Barrie Unsworth. The people of New South Wales wish that he would live in the electorate he purports to represent.

The people of New South Wales want a change of government. They want it soon. What the Premier must do now is call the election which, by rights, we should have had last December. He has delayed, hoping for help from the bicentennial celebration. But the people of New South Wales are not to be bought off with a few fireworks or even with a splendid bicentennial day. The people of Adelaide have already delivered a stinging rebuke to the Labor Party just one week ago. The people of New South Wales will do the same as soon as they are allowed to vote. The Premier is correct to admit that his Government is out of touch. Neville Wran is correct in trying to help New South Wales Labor to lift its game. It needs to. But today they are up against a clean, young, dynamic, vigorous, determined and tough Opposition which is ready for government and ready to govern. It is time for change in New South Wales, and a change for the better in every way. The people of New South Wales are sick of patronage, cronyism, Tammany-Hall government and factional dictatorship. The people of New South Wales are fed up with corruption. In Nick Greiner we look forward to new arrangements between the Commonwealth and the State to benefit the whole community. It will be clean and straightforward government, eager and ready to achieve, and the sooner it comes the better.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Childs Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —In March there will be an election in New South Wales. The Opposition has introduced this blatant electioneering matter of public importance today which has been characterised by Opposition speakers attacking personalities. But we welcome the opportunity to remind Australians, and particularly the people of New South Wales, what the real issues, the important issues, are. One must start with the most important background fact. When this Government came to power we had the Fraser inheritance of galloping unemployment and the worst recession since the Depression of the 1930s. The Labor Government set about healing the community. In co-operation with the trade union movement through the accord we were able to put in place constructive arrangements which contrast so much with the confrontation of the Fraser years.

SPEECH.PARA: We were also able to co-operate positively with the States and local government. No better model of co-operation between a national government and the State governments exists than the co-operation between the Unsworth Government and the Hawke Government. The people of New South Wales have been the beneficiaries of that approach. I accept that we are on the threshold of the State election campaign, which means that we have to examine what the alternative might be. It is quite proper to consider what a Greiner-Murray coalition government would be like. The coalition, including Senator Peter Baume, has ignored the fact that it would not be a Greiner government; it would be a Greiner-Murray government, with the National Party holding 40 per cent of the coalition membership. The task of the Federal Government has been made very difficult in recent years. That is ignored by Senator Puplick, who blames everything on the Hawke Government. He ignores the crisis in world commodity prices and the automatic reduction in our balance of trade balance sheet.

Despite these problems, the people of New South Wales have benefited from two Labor governments working in co-operation with each other. I remind the Senate of the advantages this co-operation between two Labor governments represents to the Australian people, particularly the people of New South Wales. The first and unassailable achievement of the Hawke Labor Government was to create one million jobs since it came to office, attacking the problem of poverty and providing people with creative employment. The number of people in full time employment has increased by 652,000, a 12.6 per cent increase. The significant factor for New South Wales is that that has contributed the bulk of new jobs over the past year. The level of employment in New South Wales in January was a remarkable 6.2 per cent higher than a year earlier. More than half the jobs created over the past year were in New South Wales. That is a tribute to the co-operation between the Hawke and the Unsworth Governments. The New South Wales unemployment rate fell by 1.5 per cent to 7.5 per cent over the year to January.

An improvement in school retention rates has been another achievement resulting from the co-operation between governments. It gives the lie to the statement contained in the matter of public importance introduced by the Opposition that we are not in touch with the needs of young people. There was a miserable 36 per cent retention rate for year 12 students when the Fraser Government left office. It is 50 per cent under this Government. It will soon be 66 per cent. We set out to change the situation that existed whereby our young people were not being trained for the future. A number of training schemes have been designed to encourage people in every way to increase their skills. We have only just started. We have declared that this area is a priority. We need a sympathetic government with similar approaches in New South Wales to continue that program. We do not want the user pays principle of the Liberal Party in New South Wales threatening the progress we have made.

I mention the family assistance package. One of the priorities both of the New South Wales Labor Government and the national Labor Government is to eradicate poverty amongst young families and young people. The family assistance package will help almost 600,000 families and the 1.2 million children who could be in poverty. There is an income test threshold of $300 for families with one child, with $12 for every additional child. The other significant features of the package are rent assistance and a child disability allowance. Families with three children and one bread winner with a wage of $300 to $330 a week, renting privately, will be better off by $51.60 to $66.50 a week. There may be people listening to this broadcast who do not realise that they are entitled to this assistance because it is a recent initiative of this Government. Such assistance does not occur with conservative governments. They have shown, in government and out of government, that they are not concerned with alleviating poverty.

This Government is concerned not only about young people-it has shown how in touch it is by the measures I have outlined-but also about our elderly. Pensions are now just on 25 per cent of average weekly earnings, which represent an 8.1 per cent real growth in pensions since we came to power. It contrasts with the 2.4 per cent decline which occurred under the Fraser Government. In the area of housing we have spent $2 billion over the last year alone and $5.3 billion over five years. It is because we knew that housing would get Australians working that we made it a priority of the Hawke Government. Our housing program is a testimony to co-operation. Once again the Unsworth Government, and before it the Wran Government, has given priority to that tremendous housing program.

I just want to mention another issue that is of particular concern to a lot of women and that is really threatened by the user pay principles of the Liberal Party and the National Party. From 1984 to 1988 we have created 20,000 child care places which is more than all the previous Federal governments combined. I am pleased to say that in January the Unsworth Government announced that it is allocating another $5.2m to make sure that an additional 1,500 children will receive the benefits of that program. I could go on detailing the advantages, but I just want to mention one other advantage. Senator Richardson referred to the fact that the average person on $400 a week has effectively had a tax cut of $14 from Labor governments. He pointed out that the Liberal Party had opposed increases to wage and salary earners over the last decade on every occasion. The wage and salary earners in New South Wales have to realise that a Greiner Government would follow the same Liberal policies of trying to resist wage justice for the people who are entitled to it.

In an election context, I think it is important to consider how a Greiner-Murray Government would be set up. As I said, Murray would be the Deputy Premier in a theoretical coalition government. I use the word `theoretical' because I do not believe it will be a reality, but one has to look at this matter because most people do not know about Mr Murray. They do know that Mr Greiner has been associated with the frog as a symbol. If he is the frog, then I am afraid he has a very large toad behind him in the National Party presence of Mr Murray who is the Russ Hinze of the New South Wales National Party. He is nowhere near as sophisticated as my colleague Senator Brownhill. Mr Murray has represented the most primitive attitudes of policy. I would like to mention the conflict we can expect. With 40 per cent of the National Party in the coalition, added to the other New Right figures in the Liberal Party in New South Wales, no matter what Mr Greiner says we will find that the conflict that is being kept to some extent behind doors will be out in the open if that coalition were ever to be elected to office.

Senator Puplick very significantly did not deal with the environment issue on which he is the shadow spokesman. I can understand why. If he talked about New South Wales coalition parties, he would find that the record has been one of complete squabbling. I will refer to a couple of quotes of what has been said by various leaders of the coalition Government, the people who Mr Greiner has carefully packaged. But the ugly face of any coalition is Mr Murray and some of the conservatives who would make up a coalition Cabinet. I will quote Mr Wal Murray when he opened a Northern Tablelands campaign in May last year:
The National Party won't have a bar of wilderness legislation. It is unnecessary; it is divisive--

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, as there are no New South Wales Government senators even bothering to listen to Senator Childs in this debate I draw your attention to the State of the House.
—Yes, I notice that there are very few people on my left as well. There is no quorum. Ring the bells.
—That is not for you to judge from the chair.
—Well, I just did. If you want to do something about it, you know what to do.

—I was hurting the Opposition because I was referring to the real statements made by real members of the Opposition in New South Wales. I was drawing attention to the primitiveness of the National Party leader in New South Wales and I was quoting his opposition to the wilderness legislation. I will quote from an article in the Australian of 18 October 1985. Nick Greiner, the Leader of the Liberal Party-this is the other half of the coalition team-stated:

SPEECH.PARA: The National Party has what I might choose to call a blind spot on national parks which, representing the electorates they do, simply reflects the attitudes of their constituents.

Mr Greiner is trying to win votes from the urban middle class people but it would be very doubtful what would happen with a conservative government. Earlier today somebody reminded the Senate of what the President of the Liberal Party said of the Liberal leadership eight months ago. He said, `They did not deserve to win in the last election'. What I am suggesting is that-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brownhill Sen D.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support Senator Puplick and Senator Peter Baume in this matter of public importance. It is very interesting that members of the New South Wales Labor Party have not got enough people to speak in the debate and so have had to call in Senator Beahan from Western Australia. Is it any wonder? It is the case because the State Government in New South Wales is in its death throes. The Premier of New South Wales has been like his Federal counterparts, lurching from one crisis to another. With each disaster has come the ever growing reality that Mr Unsworth is headed for political oblivion. As each day and week pass the Premier knows that he has to announce an election date. He talks about the campaign; indeed, he hosted a candidates dinner in Sydney the other day. He talks about elections, but he is so frightened of the prospect of defeat that he has not been able to muster the courage to announce the execution date, which Senator Childs tells me will be in March, but we have yet to hear about it.

SPEECH.PARA: The matter of public importance today highlights the New South West Premier's admission that he and his Party have lost the confidence of their members. To anyone following New South Wales politics that has been patently obvious for some time. The former Premier, Neville Wran, knew it only too well and he got out. He did not want his record spoilt by defeat at the polls. Nowhere is the Labor Party more out of touch than it is in rural New South Wales. To the people living outside the metropolitan areas the Labor Government has all the popularity of a blowfly in a butcher's shop.

Senator Puplick talked earlier about how close Barrie Unsworth was trying to get to our royal guests. We have been talking about blowflies getting close to things, but this Government is no more popular than a blowfly in a butcher's shop. The rural sector of New South Wales is the most important sector in the Australian economy. The farm sector generates approximately one million jobs throughout the national economy and thus supports about three million Australians. Every dollar which agriculture generates creates an estimated $3 or $4 in the wider community and every job created in farming generates another two jobs in our towns and our cities. Yet for years people in rural Australia, particularly in New South Wales, have been treated as second class citizens. While Sydney gets better roads, country areas have had cutbacks; while Sydney was getting its multi-billion dollar Darling Harbour extravaganza, country hospitals were without doctors; and while Sydney students were getting language laboratories, improved science blocks and multifaceted gymnasiums, country schools were pleading for even temporary accommodation so that students could actually have lessons under cover.

While Sydney people have been getting improved rail services, more frequent and faster train services to country towns have been abandoned and entire railway tracks have been sold off or removed. While country towns have been drying up and dying as one small business after another is forced to close, the New South Wales and Federal Labor governments have shrugged their shoulders and said, `Sorry, we cannot help'. There is no better example of the neglect of rural New South Wales than the timber industries. The Australian Labor Party's deep and meaningful relationship with the green movement knows no bounds, it seems. Mr Unsworth is determined to snatch the title `greenie of the year' from the Federal Minister for the Environment and the Arts, Senator Richardson. The big difference is that Senator Richardson at least gives the appearance of understanding, or tries to tell us he understands, the issues involved in the environmental debate.

Mr Unsworth continues to demonstrate his abysmal ignorance. Let us take as an example the Tumut-Tumbarumba region of New South Wales. Mr Unsworth apparently has not got a clue about what goes on down there and from today's newspaper reports it seems that he is not likely to learn. He claims that he is unable to go to the Tumbarumba area because of death threats. Apparently he thinks the town is full of axe-wielding mass murderers out to get him because he has threatened their livelihood. I can certainly understand why Mr Unsworth might think he is not popular in that region. It is very likely that people in the town and throughout the southern timber regions have some reason to want to have discussions with the Premier. But how offensive and how out of touch can one man get? He claims-and I emphasise that-that he and his Party are out of touch with people. Is it any wonder, when he accuses them of being potential murderers? What a slight that is to the town and the local police of the area.

TALK.START.PARA: —All Labor voters.

—That is right. The way Mr Unsworth has emasculated police stations in rural towns, he has every reason to think that there might not be any police around to help him. There are so few fully manned rural police stations that are able to provide a 24-hour service. I can only suggest to Mr Unsworth that he get a thicker hide and check that the knives in his back are not coming from his own Party.

SPEECH.PARA: Strangely, it was only a matter of days ago that a rally was held in Tumut. It was called by timber workers in the area who, very understandably, are worried about their jobs, security for their families and the future of their town. Mr Unsworth managed to say later that he could not understand why anyone would want to have a rally down there. He said that the softwood forests of Tumut and Tumbarumba were safe for 100 years and that the Government was not in the business of closing down softwood plantations. What he neglected to say-because he did not understand it and did not even know-is that over 50 per cent of the area is planted with hardwoods. There are 73,000 hectares of hardwoods presently available for milling and 70,000 hectares of pine forests.

In Mr Unsworth's own State, in a seat held by one of the Government's supposed high-fliers, the Minister for Transport, the Premier does not even know what is being grown and what people do to make a living. Mr Unsworth's words of assurance to the timber industry fall on empty ground because the industry remembers his predecessor's words in 1983 when Mr Wran made the statement that no jobs would be lost to the timber industry in northern New South Wales. Since that promise, 760 jobs have gone. The industry also remembers another broken promise-Mr Unsworth's own assurances. Again in 1983, he said to the people of Grafton that he would look after the timber workers and see that their jobs were not endangered by any more national parks. That was only four years ago. What sort of memory has the Premier of New South Wales?

It is no wonder that the people of the Burrinjuck electorate are frightened and want answers and guarantees that their jobs, their families and their communities are safe, that the towns will not be closed down to appease the conservative lobby. It is no wonder that at the next election Mr Sheahan will be told convincingly that he has lost the confidence of the people of the Burrinjuck electorate. Even some of Mr Unsworth's Federal colleagues have started to question this passionate greenie vote buying. Senator Puplick mentioned earlier that that is what Senator Richardson was doing. Mr Jim Snow, the Labor Party member for Eden-Monaro, who conned his way back into this place at the last election on the premise that one can fool some of the people some of the time, has started to question the wisdom of shutting down whole towns.

The State member for that area, Mr Akister, the other Labor Party front runner, has also had constituents thrown out of work because of the Premier's greenie policies. Mr Akister has an even bigger battle on his hands than has his colleague in Burrinjuck. Towns such as Nimmitabel and Bombala have just about been gutted. Mr Snow has seen the writing on the wall. His Federal electorate includes 80,000 hectares of recently declared national parks in the New South Wales south coast hinterland and he shares similar boundaries to Mr Akister. Timber workers, after all, formed Australia's first primary industry. They are one of the few sections of the rural community that has always been solidly Labor. But what does this astute Premier do? He puts them all out of work then wonders why he is losing their support. The vision of the man really is quite astounding.

Mr Unsworth's wooing of the rural New South Wales vote has not been restricted to timber areas. A recent New South Wales Government study has come up with the suggestion that the Western Lands Commission be taken over by other sections of government, so losing its autonomy. The biggest fear amongst rural land holders is that it will be taken over by the Department of the Environment and Planning. Environmental lobbyists have long wanted to get their hands on the 40 per cent of the State encompassed by the western division. Land holders fear that if this happens, there will be an expansion of the national park syndrome, more wilderness areas and further restrictions on pastoral operations. Graziers in that area could well see the day when they will need to undertake an environmental impact study every time they wish to move a mob of sheep. It is just another example of the degeneration of rural New South Wales at the hands of the Labor Government.

The abuse of rural people seemingly is endless. I make a point about the long-running doctors' dispute in country areas. Only last week, a young woman from rural New South Wales who had a baby seven weeks prematurely was forced into a situation reminiscent of something out of a television soap opera. The baby needed medical attention and the hospital in which the baby was born had the appropriate equipment available. But because government grants which provided the staff to operate the machine had been withdrawn, the machine sat idle. The mother faced the prospect of having her baby transferred to Adelaide or Melbourne while she remained in New South Wales. If this is how the system is working in New South Wales and if this is what the latest $6m worth of advertising campaigns, telling us how terrific things are in the New South Wales hospitals, are all about, heaven help us all.

What about students in New South Wales? Students living in rural areas are also being squeezed and tossed around by the Unsworth Government. New South Wales country students struggle all through high school and when they finish they like to go on to further study. For years, the technical and further education (TAFE) system had a block release study system that provided rural apprentices with an opportunity to get trade education at the same standard and of the same quality as city apprentices. It worked through rural apprentices being given the opportunity to travel to Sydney TAFE colleges several times a year for blocks of concentrated study, in order to qualify for a trade. This year, metal fabrication apprentices throughout rural New South Wales have had that opportunity taken away. They no longer have that system available. Instead, they are being offered places at TAFE institutions, in some cases several hours travel away from home, to which they must travel once a week.

How does the small business in downtown Bega or Cobar cope with providing study time for those people? A Bega small businessman, Mr Max Pearce, wrote to his local State member, Mr Akister, for help. In the thoroughly useless reply Mr Pearce got, his local member said he `appreciated the difficulties this will cause you and other employers' and he promised to look into the matter. It is a pity that the local member was not more in touch with what his own Government was doing. Where was he when this resolution was passed through Cabinet? Why did he not know what his Government had decided? How does that help Mr Pearce get his first year apprentices educated this year? How does the employer afford to keep an apprentice when half the apprentice's working week is spent sitting on a bus travelling 100 kilometres to a technical institution?

Mr Unsworth says that the Labor Party is out of touch with the electorate; and he wonders why. I cannot let this matter of public importance pass without talking about the shemozzle that the New South Wales Government's gun legislation has caused. When rallies in small country towns can attract thousands of people, something is wrong. Rallies have been held all over the State. One cannot say that it is just farmers whingeing when so many are complaining. It is a classic shooting in the foot approach that the Labor Party has taken on this issue. Even other Labor States have said that the New South Wales approach is inappropriate and a knee-jerk reaction to recent incidents.

How well the New South Wales Government has thought through this issue can be demonstrated in the number of times the Premier has amended his original concept of the gun laws. As one weakness after another is exposed, he rewrites the Bill. One question he has not answered, which I know the police force would also like answered, is how the police will be expected to enforce the legislation. How will the police investigate the holding of weapons and seize weapons? Will police launch Hollywood-style raids on private homes? Where will the manpower come from to do that? Who will foot the bill for the estimated $800m compensation for the weapons handed in, and how will the weapons be disposed of?

If the Premier were genuine in his matter he would have supported the National Party State member for Gloucester in the New South Wales coalition, Wendy Machin, when she called for an inquiry into the causes of violence last year. Such an inquiry would have been a far more appropriate approach to the problem than a knee-jerk panic performance in which the State Premier has engaged.

The Federal Government is out of touch with the electorate. The Adelaide by-election made that fact clear. The Unsworth Government is equally out of touch, and the electors in New South Wales will show that clearly in the coming New South Wales election.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beahan Sen M.E. .

TALK.START.PARA: —I suppose I should not be surprised that the debate so far has had little to do with the substance of the motion and that almost every contribution to it--
—Have you run out of New South Wales senators?

—I shall explain that in a minute. Every contribution to the debate so far has been a direct criticism of the New South Wales Government, although the motion claims that the Federal Government is out of touch, and that is what Barrie Unsworth was talking about in the quotation that is referred to. Barrie Unsworth was talking about the Federal Government being out of touch and the Labor Party having to get its act together.

SPEECH.PARA: I am not a New South Welshman and I do not intend, therefore, to comment on the part of the motion that refers to New South Wales, but I am interested in the accusation that has been made as a central aspect of the debate, and that is the accusation that the Labor Party is out of touch with the people of Australia. It is also implied that it is particularly out of touch with its own base. I shall also deal with the Adelaide by-election and some of the claims that have been made about it. Although I am touched by the Opposition's concern for the well-being of the Australian Labor Party and the Opposition's desire to bring the Labor Party back into touch with its own base and everybody else in Australia, I find it surprising that the Opposition should have the gall to make such accusations, having substantially lost the last general election, losing four seats while the Government gained four seats.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is your own colleagues who are making the accusation that you are out of touch.

—I am referring to the fact that the Opposition is using that accusation against us and supporting it. It is not often that the Opposition supports Barrie Unsworth, but it has done so today. I am defending the accusations that Opposition members are making through him, or that he is making through them. Nevertheless, I find it surprising that, having lost the last general election, the Opposition has the gall to make such statements. I am also surprised-having been told by the Liberal Party's national President, Mr Elliott, that the reason it lost the last election was that the Liberal Party was unfit to govern and unfit to present its case to the electorate-that the Opposition has made those accusations. If the Government has a problem communicating with people, one can imagine the extent of the problem the Opposition has. It has no contact and no credibility with anybody in the community. That was proved in the last election; it was not disproved in the Adelaide by-election, as I shall demonstrate shortly.

SPEECH.PARA: At least the Government has policies. What does the Opposition stand for? What are its policies? At least the Government has spokespeople who are recognised. At least the Government has unity. Who are the Opposition's spokespeople? Is it Elliott, Howard, Peacock, or perhaps Macphee? The Opposition has so many spokespeople and so few policies. It has had so many presentations of those few policies that they have become confusing, and that has affected its credibility. This was evident at the last election.

The Opposition also draws a very long bow in basing its point of view on one by-election result and on a much exaggerated interpretation of comments by Premier Unsworth and others. The Government was, of course, not happy to lose the Adelaide by-election, but that must be taken in perspective. I remind honourable senators that by-elections always involve swings against governments and that many factors contribute to such swings. Timed calls--

TALK.START.PARA: —Will you support timed local calls?

—The matter of timed calls and the fear campaign that surrounded it, which was mounted by the Opposition dishonestly and against its own principles, was one factor. It needs to be noted that the estimated additional swing in traditional Labor areas is an average of 2 per cent, which can be further discounted when one considers the average swing in strong Australian Labor Party seats in 1987 and the average swing in weaker Australian Labor Party boxes in 1987 votes. I estimate it to be about one per cent. Honourable senators should not fall for the hyperbole that has followed the analysis of the by-election result because a number of factors need to be looked at. The Opposition cannot take much solace from that result.

SPEECH.PARA: I also draw attention to the hypocrisy of the Liberals in their opportunistic opposition to timed local calls. The user pays principle, along with drastic reductions in public expenditure, deregulation and privatisation-in a purely ideological way-are all central to the philosophy of the Opposition and Opposition members regularly espouse those philosophical positions. Mr Elliott has spoken of $3 billion cuts. Mr Howard has spoken of drastic reductions in government expenditure to the levels of the 1960s. He has also spoken of the need for extensive deregulation of transport and communications. Senator Alston at least had the honesty to apply those philosophies in his strong support for timed local telephone calls and also for the abolition of the cross-subsidisation policies of Telecom.

TALK.START.PARA: —Will you support timed local calls?

—I do not, although I certainly support cross-subsidisation. Yet for short term, politically expedient reasons, John Howard reversed this position, a position that was substantially based upon the philosophy that he has represented over a number of years. The Liberals were totally misrepresenting their position for short term political gain. Despite the Adelaide by-election result, Mr Howard cannot afford to be sanguine. The result was certainly not good for him. Polling carried out by Australian Nationwide Opinion Polls for the Australian Labor Party, which I have seen, shows that Howard's public approval rating has dropped to a low 39 per cent, but what is more interesting is that the dissatisfaction rate increased from an already high 43 per cent to an abnormally high 50 per cent. In many areas a dissatisfaction rate of that level would be regarded as terminal, and one would get rid of the source of dissatisfaction quickly. I suspect moves are already afoot to do that, if Mr Elliott's frequent pronouncements are any indication.
—That swinging voters are 89 per cent against you is pretty terminal.

—I shall not make excuses for that; I have said that it is a multi-faceted matter and I shall not go into the reasons for it. However, I have said, firstly, that the Opposition can take no solace from the result and, secondly, that one can usually expect swings in by-elections so the Adelaide result is not an indication of what would happen in a general election. If a general election were held tomorrow, it would be interesting to see how well the Liberals fared.
—It was a swing of more than twice the normal swing.

—It was not a swing of more than twice the normal amount. Average swings in Adelaide are higher than the average for Australia, and swings in recent years, including State swings, have been of the order of 8 per cent. But let us consider the accusation that the Government is not addressing the needs of its base supports-which is the point I wanted to reach, the comments about the Adelaide by-election being an aside. When moving the Address-in-Reply last year I indicated that the Hawke Government can claim a remarkable range of achievements despite very difficult economic constraints caused by external factors over which it had no control. It is true that in this climate working people, that is average Australians, have had to tighten their belts, and they and the unions which represent them have shown commendable responsibility in doing this.

SPEECH.PARA: Nevertheless, it is true that the Government has taken initiatives in areas of social infrastructure which are both substantial in themselves and carefully directed towards those in greatest need. For example, consider the question of employment. If the question of employment can be dealt with by any government, it overcomes a lot of other problems that occur in social welfare and other ameliorative policy areas of government.

We have increased jobs by more than one million. The rate of increase over the past five years has been 15.8 per cent, which is more than 3 per cent a year and double the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD) average. The introduction of Medicare has given people a secure system of health care which is equal to all. We have increased public housing by 42 per cent. I want the Opposition to take all of these things into account in relation to what it has been saying about the Government being out of touch with ordinary Australians and about the Government not understanding their needs.

One should also examine taxation reforms. The redistributive effect of taxation reforms, that have been brought about by the Hawke and Keating initiatives is, in my opinion, far reaching and gutsy in a way that has not been experienced before in Australian political history. I believe most Labor governments would not have had the nerve to do what the Hawke and Keating Government has done, and no Liberal government would have had the desire to do it. What the Government has done is to effect a massive redistribution of resources of wealth from the wealthy to those who are in need. I direct the attention of honourable senators to a few of those initiatives which have created the sort of wealth which can be redistributed through the social security system. The fringe benefits tax, which was so soundly attacked and opposed by the Opposition, is now working and is taking away some of the rip-offs that occurred before, and it is equalising the system to some extent.

The capital gains tax, which no Liberal Government would ever think of introducing, is working and is essential for the proper and equal distribution of wealth in this country. The substantiation rules, the disallowance of deductions for entertainment allowances and a number of other initiatives are significant but I will not go into them because time is limited.

We have increased social security funding in real terms despite very difficult economic circumstances. With careful targeting that has been successful. The family package is a good example of a very carefully targeted Government initiative in the social welfare area. Rent assistance, particularly for families with children, is another very well targeted social security package. The easing of poverty traps is another. Pensions have increased under the Hawke Government by 8.3 per cent to the point that now they are over 24 per cent of average weekly earnings and they are indexed so that they will maintain that level and gradually move towards our policy of 25 per cent of average weekly earnings.

In education, substantial increases in the number of children completing full secondary education have been achieved from 36 per cent in 1983 to 50 per cent in 1987, with a commitment to 65 per cent by the first half of the next decade. I could also refer to initiatives for women in the environment that was dealt with in the debate before this. They are nevertheless certainly constructive elements of policy which are directed at our base but also at the broader needs of the Australian community-the ordinary, every day and average Australian. There is no way that honourable senators can deny that. The Government has taken a sane, sensible consensus approach in industrial relations which has given a fair deal and is far different from the dog eat dog approach that the Opposition stands for. But overriding all of this is a record of economic responsibility which is both reshaping the economy and providing--

TALK.START.PARA: —Doubled the debt in New South Wales in five years; trebled it federally.

—If Senator Messner were here before or listening to the debate he would realise that I am talking to the substance of the debate, which most people were not. I am talking about what Mr Unsworth is reported to have said about this Government's policies and this Government's lack of touch. I am talking to the debate. Very few senators have been, but I am not surprised by that given the circumstances surrounding us. Overriding all of this is a record of economic responsibility that is reshaping the economy, providing hope for the future and permitting the sorts of social initiatives that I have listed. I admit that it is difficult to convey this to the people against a backdrop of commendable wage restraint, which the Opposition, incidentally, is pledged to increase. The screws will go on much tighter under an Opposition government-it has made that quite clear. The Opposition stands for wage cuts not wage indexation. It stands for a decentralised wage systems with a dog eat dog approach, not for a centralised and sensible system by which people can get a fair deal. Against a backdrop such as that, it is difficult to convey the advantages of these and other aspects of what we would call a social wage. Yet the benefits are real and this Government has achieved them.

SPEECH.PARA: How can it be argued that we have not addressed our traditional constituency, that we are not taking care of ordinary Australians? More important, does anyone seriously believe the Opposition would show the same care, the same finesse and discipline? It certainly shows no sign of it in its Opposition pronouncements, insofar as one can ever get policies out of them because there are so many different points of view about what is said.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired. The debate on the matter of public importance has concluded. Before I move to Government Papers, could I just say that earlier this afternoon I made a remark from the chair which obviously offended, and because it did offend I apologise for that remark.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

In July 1986 the then Minister for Transport, Mr Morris, directed the Bureau of Transport Economics to undertake a study of the possible impact of the closure of Tasrail. The Tasmanian Government was not consulted prior to this report being commissioned, and no reference was made to the Tasmanian Minister's office or input sought on the terms of reference. This cavalier attitude caused unnecessary harm and anxiety in Tasmanian rail circles and could have been avoided if the Minister had clearly spelt out at the time that the future of Tasrail was guaranteed. No-one would have objected to a commercial evaluation of the operations after a number of years, but the terms of reference must have been positively frightening to the workers of that organisation. I quote:
. . . the Bureau of Transport Economics should undertake a comprehensive study into the effects of closure of the Tasmanian rail system.

Thankfully, the inquiry found that, for several reasons, it was not practicable to close down Tasrail. In the summary of the report, the increased economic efficiency of Tasrail is detailed. Since 1977-78 when Australian National Railways took over the then Tasmanian Government railways, there has been a 75 per cent increase in freight task; an improvement in labour productivity of about 220 per cent; and a reduction of the operating loss by 54 per cent in real terms.

The report says that on balance the economic analysis suggests that there is not a strong case in support of the closing of Tasrail. However, there would be a great impact on Tasmanian welfare if Tasrail were closed because it directly employs about 900 people and is a major provider of apprenticeship training in Launceston, Devonport, Hobart and Burnie. If Tasrail were closed, 870 employees would be out of work and it would cause many problems to the Tasmanian road system. The infrastructure would be severely damaged and would require injections of Federal and State funding because of the drastically increased road haulage; some products such as sulphuric acid would have to be shipped by sea because they cannot be safely carried on the roads.

There has been a large influx of trucks hauling cement, limestone, logs and coal, and it would mean that those industries would have to completely restructure their operations to remain competitive. Tasrail customers would also have to pay a significantly higher freight cost. It has been stated that Tasmanian industry would have to find an extra $14.4m to cover the increased cost of transport in the 1988-89 year under the medium growth forecast outlined in the report. Such as large figure, because of the scale of Tasmanian business and industry, should alone support the maintenance of the Tasmanian rail system.

I am relieved that the Federal Government has at last decided not to move towards the closure of Tasrail, and I commend it for that as that would have been a quite irresponsible decision to take given the recommendations outlined in the report. However, one must have some concern about the Government's long term commitments to the Tasrail system. These commitments must be categorically given by the Minister in the chamber at the moment, the Minister for Justice, Senator Tate. It must be made clear that the position and livelihood of Tasmanian railway workers and ancillary staff involve the State. There is no basis for the Commonwealth withdrawing its support. As the report notes, the improvement in financial efficiency within Tasrail over the last 10 years is a result of co-operation between management, unions, customers and the Tasmanian and Federal governments. This review caused unnecessary alarm in Tasmania and the Government should have raised the terms of reference and handled the whole issue with sensitivity, mindful of the fact that it was dealing with a very significant employer and component of the Tasmanian economy. I commend those who took part in formulating the report, and I hope we can get a long term commitment from this Australian Labor Party Government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to supplement the remarks made by my colleague Senator Watson. I would certainly wish to give credit to the Federal Bureau of Transport Economics for the thoroughness with which it has undertaken this inquiry into the Tasmanian rail system. However, I think its recommendations needed to be much more decisive. I believe that that could have been, and should have been, the case. The railway service in Tasmania was in fairly poor shape at the time Australian National Railways took it over but now the tracks, the locomotives and the wagons are in first-class condition. More than 96 per cent of the total track is now without any speed restriction. It is as good as, if not better than, any track anywhere in Australia. There is now a complete stock of 52 locomotives, which is the best supply there has ever been, and they are in better condition than they have ever been. The wagons have been rebuilt or reconditioned throughout, and there is now no build-up of wagons requiring attention.

SPEECH.PARA: The organisation's business has shown a compounding increase of 6.3 per cent per annum. That is a remarkable increase for any form of business. The work force is down to 876 at present. The reduction in that work force has been a remarkable operation inasmuch as these curtailing deals usually involve a lot of hardship for employees. In this case the amount of industrial trouble created has been remarkably small. There has been some; there are one or two people in the railways staff who believe that they have to keep ringing the gong to let their workers know they are there, but apart from that the changes have been made very amicably, very reasonably and over a period of time. The worst feature as far as I am concerned is that the average age of Tasrail employees is now getting too high. It does need an influx of younger people or all at one time there will be an enormous run of older staff leaving.

It must be remembered that the railways themselves take the heavy freight. There is no question that Tasmania could not operate without a railway service, and this was not adequately stated in the report. It would just not be sensible to try to operate without a railway service to keep the considerable volume of heavy transport off the roads. Road maintenance would probably cost something in the order of $50m or $60m a year extra if we tried to put this traffic on to the roads, to say nothing of the disagreeable nature of it compared with the ordinary commercial and tourist traffic that already exists. An interesting figure for comparison is Tasrail's recovery rate. Ten years ago Vicrail was getting a 60 per cent return on every dollar that it spent; today it is 30 per cent. Ten years ago Tasrail was getting 30c in the dollar recovery; today it is getting a recovery rate of 70c in the dollar. This has been a fantastic recovery. I believe great credit should be given to the manager, Graeme Templer, and the staff generally for the work they have done. I support the comments made by Senator Watson and again give credit to the thoroughness with which the job was done.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

I believe that the annual report of the Housing Loans Insurance Corporation is a most disturbing document. Looking back on the comments that I made last year, it was fairly clear that the year under review in this report was going to be difficult. I would also say that the following year will also be very difficult.

Some of the statistics are very worrying, and the actions of the Government at a time like this have also been worrying. In 1985, 69,000 loans were insured but this has dropped to 39,000, reflecting a substantial downturn. Net premiums written in 1985 totalled approximately $19m, and that has dropped to approximately $11m. In 1985 there were $2m worth or claims and, in 1987, $25m worth of claims. These trends are most alarming. Gross operating profit in 1986 was $12m, while the gross operating loss in 1987 was $5m. So it goes on.

The problem in the housing area is considerable. Whether we are in touch or out of touch, the ordinary people we have been talking about are finding that the cost of housing has become absolutely prohibitive. The number of claims is going up and up. Just over 1,100 claims were paid out during the year. These claims have been lodged by people for whom the dream has become a nightmare. The losses are very considerable and the Government's attitude in all of this is to try to make this organisation one of its milking cows. The report shows that in November 1986 the Treasurer (Mr Keating) determined that the Corporation should pay a dividend of $3.4m in respect of the 1985-86 year while he directed in May 1987 that the Corporation transfer $10m from its general reserve to capital. The Treasurer determined that $10m of the Corporation's capital be then repaid to the Commonwealth. At a time when the Corporation's reserves were likely to face the severest drain ever, the Commonwealth decided to rip out $10m to bolster its otherwise parlous financial position.

The Corporation's total assets are falling rapidly. Its capital and general reserves, which totalled $27m in 1986, are now down to $12m and it is almost certain that this will be another year of heavy losses. I do not know how much lower we can let this go before we start to get very worried about the operation itself. The Corporation is not being run in a commercial way. It is one of these Government enterprises that need to be commercial; it is competing in a commercial area. The actions of the Government make it very chancy and I am disturbed that in spite of the comments made at this time last year all that has happened is that the position has become considerably worse and it is likely that next year's annual report will also review a bad year.

I would like to comment on the fact that Jim Fitzpatrick retired in June 1987 and that his place has been taken by Peter Bartlett, both of whom I know very well. I trust that by next year this position will be clarified much more, but I do urge the Government not to treat this as just another milking cow and not to keep on pulling money out of it when reserves are essential.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
