TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

I rise today to make a few remarks about the annual report of the Australian Trade Union Training Authority, which is known by its more common name of TUTA. The Authority has had a large impact since the passage of legislation to establish it in 1975. There is little doubt that in the industrial sphere TUTA has had a beneficial impact on the trade union movement as a whole. According to this report the 1982-83 financial year saw some 474 courses conducted by TUTA, with 9,748 people participating. These figures rose to 769 and 16,265 for the year 1986-87. Over the year 1985-86 there was a rise of 9 per cent in the number of training days and a rise in the participation rate of about 3 per cent. Some 178 unions were represented in these courses, and this figure is for Australia-wide.

Although each TUTA centre is represented in the capital cities, courses were conducted in 64 major regional centres. So the reach of TUTA courses to the average member of the rank and file is considerable. The comment that so often comes from the ignorance of the conservatives in Australia is that such programs are just an excuse for trade union officials to get together. In fact, the figures show quite clearly that this is not the case. Only 6 per cent of the total number of training days were taken up by full time trade union officials. Nearly 60 per cent of the total student training days were taken up by job representatives.

It is pleasing to see the useful variation of courses offered. Whilst the basic courses for new job representatives are much in demand and consume slightly over half of the training days available, other more specialised courses were also made available. Ten courses were conducted for Aboriginal workers, comprising 30 days of training and catering for 218 Aboriginal workers. Attendances by women unionists represented 26 per cent of attendances at regional centres. Of these, 651 attendances were at 31 basic courses designed for women workers seeking to play more active roles in their unions. The remaining 3,148 attendances for women workers were for TUTA courses.

The proportion of participants from non-English speaking countries was about 9 per cent, and basic courses were conducted for Vietnamese and Spanish speaking trade unionists. Whilst it has been customary for the conservatives in this country to attack the trade union movement, I am firmly of the opinion that an articulate, rational and competent trade union movement is essential for a democracy like the one we have in Australia. Furthermore, it is essential to give ordinary rank and file workers the opportunity to be made aware of the role of their unions and to the ability effectively to participate in the decision-making processes of the unions. Finally, it is pleasing to see that TUTA is adapting to the need to help migrants in the work force understand the trade unions and how they operate. Obviously the role of women workers is essential to our economy, and that too is recognised by TUTA courses. The benefits of TUTA's work in helping to establish a healthy and well balanced trade union movement in Australia are considerable. I commend the work of TUTA and I commend the report to the Senate.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bjelke-Petersen Sen F.I.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

I want to point out that over the last five years Commonwealth expenditure on all roads, whether they be national highways, arterial roads or local roads, has taken place under two programs. The first is the Australian land transport program (ALTP) and its predecessor the Roads Grants Act and the second is the Australian bicentennial road development program, or the ABRD program as it is known, the report of which we are presently debating. Both the ALTP and the ABRD program have been funded from taxes paid at the bowser by private motorists and other road users. The ABRD program has received 2c per litre from sales of petrol and diesel fuel since the program began in January 1984. Arrangements under the ALTP are somewhat more complex. When the program began in July 1985 a certain proportion of fuel excise was earmarked or dedicated to the ALTP, and the legislation establishing the program contained a provision that this proportion would be indexed so that the proportion of fuel excise dedicated to roads would keep pace with inflation. Unfortunately, that has not happened, and this is the sad tale of woe.

TALK.START.PARA: —Another broken promise.

—Yes, that is indeed a broken promise by this Government. The local authorities in Queensland are very concerned and very worried about funding for roads. I attended a meeting last Friday morning in Brisbane of representatives of 111 local authorities from the State of Queensland who were all very concerned about the real value of road funding allocations. They pointed out that the fuel tax revenue has dropped from 67 per cent in 1984-85 to a mere 27 per cent in 1987-88, which they said is the lowest percentage for more than 50 years. That is a very long time. We know that the ABRD funding program is nearing completion. As a matter of fact, that is how the report starts off. However, I am sorry to say that this Government seems to adopt the attitude that there are no votes in roads, particularly roads in rural areas.
—They never worry about the farmer.

—That unfortunately is one of the complaints that we have, particularly those of us who represent a big State such as Queensland which has a large rural area. Roads provide lines of communications between people, centres and States. Of course, they are the arteries for transport of people and produce. The further out one lives in a big State such as Queensland the more fuel one uses. One feels that more of the funds that are raised through the Australian bicentennial road development and Australian land transport programs ought to be given back to people using the roads. But this is not the way in which the programs have worked. The roads further out are getting worse and worse. I must say that the highways between the towns and cities are being improved. Around the cities one sees a tremendous amount of road works. I do not know whether honourable senators who fly into Canberra have a look at the beautiful roads that are being built just outside Canberra. As we came in from Sydney the other day I could see this gorgeous four-lane highway being built and I thought of the problems attached to road works out in the country areas of Queensland. I believe the users of fuel should be able to expect a fairer share of fuel tax revenue. Motorists unfortunately have become the milking cow for the nation. The milk that the Government gets from them in the form of money does not all go back to the cows that are milked, I am sorry to say.

SPEECH.PARA: We need good roads. We need good roads throughout Queensland. Councils need funds to keep their gangs employed. We need good roads for tourism in Queensland, for transporting of grain harvests, for transporting of cattle and for all the big transports that are used. The maintenance of existing roads is a real headache. I feel quite sure that everybody in the Senate, particularly senators from both sides of the chamber who represent Queensland, would hope that when the present ABRD program finishes the Government will see its way clear to make more funds available for roads.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

We are debating the annual report of the Australian Broadcasting Corporation at a time when the ABC is in crisis. That is not just a statement from the Opposition but it comes from the Board of the Australian Broadcasting Corporation itself. A Press release dated 10 February, only a week or so ago, by Mr Bob Somervaille, the Chairman of the Board, was issued with agreement of the Managing Director, Mr David Hill. It said:
The Board also: declared that the Australian Broadcasting Corporation can no longer adequately fulfil its obligations under the Charter set down by Federal Parliament.

That is bad news for Australia because everyone in this country knows the very great degree to which Australians depend upon a reliable, independent broadcasting service from the Australian Broadcasting Corporation. The Corporation serves not just metropolitan listeners, who may represent in a sense minority listeners in the whole community, but also those audiences in the far flung parts of Australia, in the rural areas and in the outback and beyond. It also, of course, represents a substantial part of the development overseas of a regard for Australia in that the ABC is also responsible for the Radio Australia programs which as we all know present Australia in a very good light and, indeed, are very important to the development of Australia's image overseas. It has come to the point now where it behoves the Government to make at the earliest possible opportunity a firm statement about the future funding directions of the ABC. This is another case of the Hawke Government fiddling while the whole ABC, in this case, burns down.

Very little attention is being given by this Government to the needs of the ABC. One has to look at only one or two numbers to understand the depth of the problem. The ABC is approximately $120m in backlog in the capital development programs it needs in order to keep up with modern developments. That $120m has to come from somewhere. The Government apparently is reluctant to enter into any definite program as to the future directions of the ABC. What this means virtually is that the ABC's capital investment and equipment are falling down around its ears. One does not have to visit too many branches of the ABC-I am thinking particularly of television-to understand the depth of the problem. The fact is that equipment is breaking down almost continuously and is not being upgraded because there is simply a lack of money available from the Federal Government.

The Liberal Party of Australia and the National Party of Australia would like to see a firm statement from the Government as to future funding. There are many options and we do not have time to canvass them now, but clearly it behoves the Government to look at those things and to make a firm statement as to the future direction of the ABC in the interests of all Australians. The ABC is a national institution of very great importance in this nation. It behoves the Government to ensure its success and continued viability and to ensure most of all that it operates with an independent and even-handed program policy in regard to the presentation of current affairs.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The time allowed for consideration of Government Papers has now expired.

DEBATE.TITLE: STANDING COMMITTEE ON LEGAL AND CONSTITUTIONAL AFFAIRS

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hamer Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is an important report and also, I think, a very valuable one. I congratulate the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs on the work it has put into it. It was given only a short time to prepare a report on this complex subject and I think it has served the Senate very well. It is a credit to both the Committee itself and I suspect even more to the Committee staff who normally do the great bulk of the work in preparing such a long and complex report as this. As most honourable senators will be aware, I am very much in favour of referring complex Bills such as the War Crimes Amendment Bill to a committee for consideration where there can be public input, questioning and cross-examination of witnesses. I think out of it much better legislation results. The fact that this Committee has been able to report so promptly and has not significantly delayed the Bill is to the credit of the Committee and also shows the way in which much more Senate legislation should be handled.

SPEECH.PARA: The Committee made a number of recommendations on the subject. It was dealing with only one aspect of the Bill, a point I will come to in a moment. The aspect it was dealing with was the quality of the evidence on which the alleged war criminals were to be charged. Since much of this evidence will come from communist controlled countries, Eastern Bloc countries, there are real problems here. The KGB is certainly not above skilled forgery. The Committee has recommended that any witnesses from these communist controlled countries should give evidence in court before a jury and be subject to examination and cross-examination if necessary. The Committee also felt that there should be no prosecutions for war crimes unless the Government was satisfied that the defendants would have access to defence witnesses, were able to visit the sites of the alleged crimes and would have access to documents needed for their defence.

Finally, the Committee recommended that legal aid should be given as necessary to ensure a fair trial. We must recognise that these trials, if conducted, will be extremely expensive. There is no way an ordinary defendant could afford to conduct a proper defence of his own unless he was extremely wealthy. These three recommendations were the unanimous view of the Committee. They should, I believe, be accepted by the Senate and by the Government. There is a problem in this regard. If they are accepted, as they should be-and I do not see how anyone can seriously argue that any of those requirements are not necessary and appropriate to ensure a just outcome-I think it is quite possible that no cases will be brought to trial. That may be the outcome; I do not know. Even if they are adopted, that does not mean that the Committee has solved all the problems.

There are two other areas of serious doubt in this Bill which the Committee has not examined because it was not given the task of examining them in its terms of reference. I refer to one area which is mentioned in passing in the report-the definition of war crimes; the ones that could be prosecuted in our courts. They range from murder and rape to wounding and being, by act or omission, in any way, directly or indirectly, knowingly concerned in or party to the commission of such crimes. The war criminal can even be prosecuted if what he did was required or permitted by the law in force when or where the act was committed. These requirements, I believe, should have been examined by the Committee and will have to be examined very carefully by the Senate, because they appear to me to go far beyond what could usefully or properly be prosecuted in an Australian court under a retrospective law.

In evidence to the Senate Committee, the Director of Public Prosecutions, Mr Ian Temby, QC, said that the definition of serious war crimes would permit lodging of charges in circumstances that would be quite inappropriate and that he had decided to narrow the investigations to murders and mass murders. This seems sensible, but I am afraid that it does not entirely eliminate potential problems. I will give one extreme example. What about an Australian pilot bombing Germany as part of a force that raised a fire storm in Hamburg or destroyed Dresden? Can he be charged? It would be no defence to say that he was acting under orders. We may find that we have created for ourselves a terrible monster.

Another aspect which is seriously questionable about this Bill that was not canvassed by the Committee report is the question of whether it is appropriate for war crimes to be confined only to those committed in the Second World War, which ended 42 years ago. What has happened about all the other wars? Since 1945 there have been 70 wars. Ten are still going on now. We have taken in migrants from many countries in which wars were going on. For example, what happened in Pol Pot's Kampuchea was worse than anything that happened in Hitler's Germany. We have taken in 14,000 Kampuchean refugees. Are any of them war criminals? I do not know; I am sure that the Government does not know. This Bill does not allow us to deal with them, if we are serious about it. Because of the special problems of extradition, the problems of evidence, the problem of whether people get a fair trial, it is normally not appropriate to send alleged war criminals back to the country in which the crime was committed. What we are doing is giving Australian courts the power retrospectively to try these offences which were committed in foreign countries by people who are now Australian residents. But if we are doing that because of special circumstances, it seems to me that it should apply to all war criminals and not just ones of a particular war that ended 42 or 43 years ago. I think it is important that we get this right.

One could make a case for saying that the whole business of war criminals is too difficult; we will extradite people when we are satisfied that they will get a fair trial, otherwise it is not our business; our laws do not extend beyond Australia and we cannot deal with them. Alternatively, we could argue that because very serious crimes are involved and because the extradition process relating to the country in which the offence was committed is not usually workable, we have to try them in our own courts. Surely that argument should apply to all war crimes, not just to the particular group that happened in a war that ended 43 years ago.

This Bill has very serious defects and I think we have to tackle them. I am sorry that the Committee, because it was not given the power by the Senate, did not continue its excellent investigation into the other very doubtful aspects of this Bill so that we could have an informed debate on it. I am sure this Committee report will enable us to have a very sensible debate on the problem of evidence. I wish we could have the same amount and quality of material before us when we debate the other questionable aspects of the Bill-that is, the definition of war crimes and why this Bill is limited to one particular war when there have been 70 wars since 1945 and many migrants have come from areas where those wars were going on. I think it is illogical for us to do this. The Bill is extremely difficult, complex and potentially socially very divisive. We must be quite sure that we get it right or do not touch it at all. The passage through the Senate of an unsatisfactory, defective Bill would be very damaging to the Australian people.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Powell Sen J.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —As a member of the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs, whose report we are addressing today, I simply want to make a few very brief comments. As a member of this Committee only since the election last year-a new member and a non-lawyer-I would like to comment on the process, which other speakers commented on in the debate earlier today, which was undertaken by this Committee. There was a very short time frame in which the Committee had the opportunity to address the issues. Those issues were limited, as has already been said, by the terms of reference which were given to the Committee. It was my feeling from the very beginning that the limitation of those terms of reference might be so stringent that, in effect, the Committee might be unable to make any real contribution to the issues surrounding the War Crimes Amendment Bill as a whole.

SPEECH.PARA: As it turned out-and I would like to thank fellow members of the Committee and certainly the staff of the Committee-I believe that the public hearings, the evidence that was brought before us by way of other submissions, and the deliberations of the Committee itself, meant that in spite of the very restrictive nature of the terms of reference, we have been able to give a considered judgment. It is one which I think will be of assistance not only to the Senate in its deliberations but also to the community, which we recognise has a great deal of concern-as rightly there should be-about a very sensitive piece of legislation. It is quite an experience for a non-lawyer to serve on the Legal and Constitutional Affairs Committee of the Senate. It gives one a strong sense of being not only a politician but also a legislator.

I would like to stress those aspects of the report which lay great emphasis on the Committee's belief that the due processes of the legal system as we know it in Australia are very well served to be the jurisdiction for the trials which might take place as a result of the passage of this legislation. Given that fact, the Committee felt that it was worth while to make some recommendations-all of which have been well canvassed in this debate-for, perhaps, caution in relation to evidence which might be brought forward in relation to war crimes as they would be defined under this legislation. We were very careful, however, not to get into the exercise-which Senator Cooney warned us about earlier this morning-of having any kind of breakdown regarding what is a very important separation of powers between the legislature, the Executive and the judiciary. It was a very fine line to tread. We were urged by some witnesses to take a stronger line, and that the Parliament should give direction to the judiciary in this circumstance. I, for one, resisted that advice quite strongly. However, we have come up with some cautionary notes which, as other speakers have said, will be of interest in the debate which is yet to come.

One recommendation is that special provision be made for legal aid in the event of prosecutions proceeding under this legislation. That is something which the Parliament as a whole, and governments of whatever colour which might be in office while any such trials are taking place, need to take very seriously, not just from the point of view which the Committee was addressing, that is, the point of view that anybody involved in these trials will need to be supported-it will be a very expensive process-but also from the other end, the point of view of the situation facing legal aid in Australia at the moment where funds are very limited. Resources are very stretched. Further limitations which are very discomfiting to people working in the area are already in place. This may be one of the major challenges ahead of us subsequent to the passage of this legislation. I draw to the attention of the Senate this recommendation which will need to be met and which future governments will have to take on board.

I have considerable sympathy with the comments made by Senator Hamer with regard to the restrictive nature of this legislation. He tells us that there have been 70 wars since 1945. I urge people to look at the report which gives a very clear background to the arrival of this legislation before the Parliament, involving a special set of circumstances and particular reference to a particular period in which Australia was officially at war in certain theatres of war. I do not believe that it would be beyond this Parliament or any government to bring before the Parliament future legislation should similar concerns arise with regard to people living in Australia who may have been involved in crimes of any sort in any other war. As officially we do not appear to have been at war-we do not appear to be at war now-since 1945 we would have to use terminology other than war. So it is an ongoing concern. It has been an experience of considerable interest to me as a member of the Committee.

I congratulate the Committee staff for the work that they have done and thank them for the backup and support they have given the members of the Committee. I also congratulate the Chairman of the Committee, Senator Bolkus, on his elevation to the Ministry. It will be quite a challenge for the Government to provide the Committee with a new member of such stature as Senator Bolkus.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-I think I will be closing the debate on this matter so I will also take the opportunity to thank the staff of the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs for the excellent work they have put in to helping us produce this report within a very tight time frame. Having met the time constraints of the Senate we have perhaps set an example to other committees and, I would like to think, helped the Senate in its deliberations. I also thank all the Committee members for the way in which they constructively approached what I believe was a difficult task. Certainly I found it one of the most difficult tasks I have had to face during my years in the Senate for the reasons that were well put by Senator Chaney in the debate this morning. It is a highly emotive subject with a great deal of stress on both sides of the debate.

SPEECH.PARA: Those who suffered from the Holocaust obviously are still very much entitled to expect those who are guilty of offences relating to it to be brought to justice. I can quite understand that. In many ways I support that sentiment. But, on the other hand, there are those within our community who fear that they may well become the subject of some sort of show trials who may have suffered a great deal in the war. They and their communities are deeply concerned about this prospective piece of legislation. Their stress and concern were certainly brought forward to the Committee. So it was not an easy task. I feel confident that we have put before the Senate and before the Government the concerns that they have expressed and also, I believe, some constructive solutions to lessen those concerns.

I wanted to use this opportunity to make a few personal comments. Senator Hamer, in my view, was quite correct when he pointed out today that our Committee certainly was not dealing with all the difficulties that the Senate faces in relation to this piece of proposed legislation. Certainly there remains outstanding the question of the selectivity of the Bill, the fact that it relates only to a particular period and to particular regions within the world. He is quite correct in saying that many others have suffered from war crimes in many wars and why do we selectively choose a particular war and a particular designation of criminal. I think his case is well made out. It is a case that has not as yet been adequately answered by the Government. I hope that the Government will seriously address his concerns.

The other area Senator Hamer raised which is also outstanding-both areas are outstanding because they were beyond the terms of reference given to our Senate Committee-is that of the definitional problems, the crimes with which these people might be charged. They were dealt with to some extent in the evidence before the Committee. I hope that the Government and its draftsmen will look at that evidence and realise that there are major problems with the definitions as set out in clause 6. If the Government is to proceed with this Bill we would hope that many of those problems would be overcome before the Bill returns to the Senate.

A couple of areas cause me particular concern. The longer this inquiry went on the more concerned I became. Firstly, it became apparent that trial or prosecutions under this Bill will continue only for a limited period. I think it was Mr Temby, the Director of Public Prosecutions, who pointed out how resources are limited and that a matter like this can be ongoing unless it is restricted in some way. What concerns me about that is that there are obviously, therefore, going to be a limited number of prosecutions during this specified period. Not necessarily the worst of the criminals, if I can put it in those terms, are going to be prosecuted but rather those who are easiest to prosecute. That may be because there are those on whom evidence is readily available or more accessible or because witnesses happen to be in Australia as opposed to being in Eastern European countries or the Soviet Union, or for a number of different reasons that do not relate to the seriousness of the offence.

I, for one, am one senator who will be most concerned if what happens as a result of this proposed legislation is that there will be a limited number of show trials in order that this Government can show that it is treating the matter seriously and those who may have committed the more serious of the crimes, if I can put it like that, are absolved simply because the Government has not the resources or the time to get around to the more difficult cases. That, in my view, is not justice. I am concerned that it may occur in this case.

The second area that causes me considerable concern is that, although we were not permitted under out terms of reference to look at specific cases, I gained the impression as the inquiry went on that perhaps in terms of chiefs and Indians those who were being examined as possible defendants in these cases very much fall within the category of Indians. As I said, the definitions are extremely broad. What they could mean is that someone who had the task of locking the wagon doors in the railway yards for the poor, unfortunate persons who were being sent off to slave camps could well fit within the category of a war criminal under this Bill and may well be prosecuted under the Bill. That would cause me concern. I hope that those who are being prosecuted are those who have had the independence to make decisions or who have acted in a sort of extra-abhorrent way rather than those who, as I said, I would describe as simply the Indians in this terrible process that took place as part of our history. But I am concerned on the basis of what was put to us. It is rather those who fall within that latter category who will be the subjects of these show trials. If that is so, again I, as one senator, express considerable concern.

Having said that I want to make it quite clear that I do not believe time absolves those who have committed horrible crimes. Because these crimes were committed a long time ago, over 40 years ago, I do not believe that these people should escape justice. If we have mass murderers in this country who have come to this country after the last World War, I would like to see them brought to justice. I do not believe that they should be extradited to Eastern European countries and to the Soviet Union. For one reason I do not believe in the death penalty. I believe they should be tried in Australia and, therefore, to provide a mechanism whereby that can happen is perhaps a good course of action to take.

What we have tried to do in this report is to stress that justice is a two-way street and in the hype of these trials that is going to develop-in many ways they will become media trials with extremely emotive evidence of what happened in these horrible scenes in Europe at the time of the last World War-we must also remember that we have a responsibility in terms of justice to those who are put on trial. We stress in this report that for those who are put on trial that must only occur if this Government can first be assured that they are going to be given a fair opportunity to put their defence. What that will mean in these cases where the evidence is in the Soviet Union and the Eastern European countries is that this Government must first be satisfied that these defendants will be able to go to these countries and examine and determine their witnesses. Honourable senators must remember that the defendants would not have seen these people for over 40 years. They should be assured that they are there and that those who are critical to their defence are able to come to Australia to give evidence. The Government should be assured that they have access to archives in these countries in order to prepare their defence and that they have access to sites necessary in preparation of their defence. In other words, they should be treated as criminals would be in any other criminal case in Australia and accorded the same standards of justice that we would apply to any other defendant in a criminal case in this country.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: ROYAL COMMISSION INTO ABORIGINAL DEATHS IN CUSTODY

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —For the information of honourable senators, I present a letter from the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs in response to the Senate's resolution of 24 November 1987 concerning the work of the Royal Commission into Aboriginal Deaths in Custody. With the agreement of honourable senators, the letter will be incorporated in Hansard.

INTERJECT.PARA: Thank you for your letter of 27 November conveying the Senate's resolution concerning the deaths of Aboriginals in custody and supporting the work of the Royal Commission.

The Commonwealth is determined to do all that it can to prevent further deaths occurring. On 10 September 1987 it convened a meeting of Commonwealth and State Ministers responsible for police and corrective services. That meeting considered a draft code of practices and procedures designed to prevent further deaths in custody. A meeting of the Australian Police Ministers Council on 27 November commended the draft code and urged its implementation on an interim basis pending further consultations with Aboriginal communities and legal services.

The draft code addresses the matter of the safety of Aboriginals in detention. It urges that the detention of Aboriginals should be avoided where possible. Where this is not possible special measures should be taken for closer supervision, ready availability of medical assistance and the presence of a friend or companion where an Aboriginal prisoner is at risk.

In addition, the Standing Committee of Attorneys-General has endorsed the amendment of procedures and conditions attaching to the granting of bail. The implementation of reforms should reduce the numbers of Aboriginals under detention.

All State administrations are now fully alert to the problem and, although the recent deaths to which you refer are regrettable, I am aware of several incidents in which prompt action has prevented deaths in custody.

I appreciate the deep interest and concern of the Senate in this matter, and take this opportunity to assure you of my personal commitment and the Government's determination to improve the circumstances of Aborigines in respect of the criminal justice system.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill received from the House of Representatives.
That the Bill may proceed without formalities and be now read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-
The Bill is the centrepiece of the Government's child support scheme.

The common experience of many Australian families over the last 10 years or more has been that separation of parents leads to a dramatic and sustained drop in living standards for the custodial parent and children. For many custodial families this has added the trauma and distress of poverty to the difficulties experienced because of the breakdown of the marriage.
Experience around the world shows that there are three elements essential to the eradication of poverty for sole parents and their children:
Flexible and effective programs to assist the sole parents get and keep jobs;
effective assessment and collection of child support providing the custodial parent with security that child support will be received regularly and on time;
adequate public income support integrated with labour market measures and child support.
The government is committed to ensuring that by 1990 no Australian child need live in poverty.

The child support scheme is central to achieving that objective. Other programs in the social security and employment education and training portfolios complement the child support scheme by helping to meet the Government's objective of adequate support for Australian children by 1990.

Under the first stage of the child support scheme we will effect fundamental reforms to Australia's child support system. We will make the legal right of children to be supported by both their parents a real right. We will turn what for most children is an empty promise into solid regular financial support.
The child support scheme will also substantially reduce Commonwealth expenditures on pensions and benefits.
Seventy per cent of children of separated parents do not receive regular cash maintenance.
Over half of the estimated 800,000 children in poverty in this country are in sole parent families.
This scheme will increase the number of families receiving maintenance, increase the level of that maintenance and will ensure that it is received on a regular basis.
The enforcement of child maintenance has been recognised as a significant social problem in major Western countries, like the United States.
While those countries have adopted various collection mechanisms, the problem has continued and they are interested in the approach we are about to adopt in this country.
We are indeed fortunate to be in a unique position to be able to use our family law, taxation and social security powers under the Constitution to integrate a national system.
In addition to the Child Support Bill 1987, it is necessary to enact two other pieces of legislation to give full effect to the first stage of this scheme.

The recently enacted Family Law Amendment Act 1987 will provide for child maintenance obligations to be given priority over all commitments of non-custodial parents, other than those necessary for their own support.

That Act will also put an end to the practice of maintenance being essentially nothing more than a top-up to social security benefits by preventing the courts from considering social security eligibility when making orders that relate to maintenance.

A further Bill, which it is proposed to bring before the Parliament later this sitting, will amend the Social Security Act 1947 to provide for changes to the way maintenance is treated in the social security system.
I turn now, to outline briefly the essential features of the Child Support Bill.
Effective collection of maintenance has never been achieved in this country.

The only way to ensure that children receive the support to which they are entitled is by a collection system that does not depend on voluntary payment. The deduction of maintenance automatically from salary or wages guarantees, in the vast majority of cases, that regular financial assistance is provided.
The Bill will establish a Child Support Register which will record details of maintenance liabilities that will be enforceable under the Bill.
There will be a Child Support Registrar who will be responsible for the administration of the Bill and the keeping of the Child Support Register.

Under the Bill, the Child Support Registrar will be the Commissioner of Taxation. The Registrar will administer the Bill through a section of the Australian Taxation Office to be known as the Child Support Agency.
A Child Support Agency within the Australian Taxation Office is best equipped to perform this task for three reasons-
the Tax Office has an existing relationship with employers, who under the scheme of the Bill will be required to deduct maintenance from the salary or wages of liable employees;
the Tax Office can best trace those persons who seek to avoid their obligations under the Bill; and
the Tax Office has substantial experience in the enforcement of financial obligations.

The Bill is drafted in such a way that all child maintenance liabilities that are payable on a periodic basis under a court order or a registered maintenance agreement are registrable on the Child Support Register.
The Minister for Social Security's statement on 24 March last year outlined the parameters that would be applied to limit the population to be covered by the scheme.

The Child Support Agency will collect periodic child maintenance that relates to children of parents who separate after the commencement of this Bill, or-where the parents have not cohabited-to children born after that day.
In all cases where the person receiving the maintenance is in receipt of an income tested pension, allowance or benefit, the Child Support Agency will be able to collect the maintenance.
The Child Support Agency will take over the functions of State collection agencies. It will collect any orders lodged with those agencies on the date their functions are taken over.
It is proposed to establish these parameters by regulation so that if in the future there are sufficient resources to extend the scope of the scheme, it will not be necessary to amend the Bill.
A significant feature of the Bill is that in the vast majority of cases maintenance will be deducted automatically from the salary or wages of liable parents.
The effect of this automatic withholding is that regular payments are assured to custodial parents.

The Government rejects the suggestion that automatic withholding be imposed only when default in payment occurs. Overseas experience is that a default will almost certainly occur in the two years after an order for payment is made. Stigma attaches to automatic withholding if it is imposed upon default and this would detract from the success of the scheme.

The enforcement of child support has been recognised as a problem in the United States since the mid-1970s. Those States that have adopted less effective collection mechanisms to overcome this have found that the problem has continued.
In some cases, it will simply not be possible to impose automatic withholding and in these cases the liable parent will be required to pay the maintenance directly to the Child Support Registrar.
The Bill also provides a statutory mechanism which ensures the payment to custodial parents of moneys paid over to the Registrar.

The Bill contains strict secrecy provisions for Commonwealth officers and employers regarding any information obtained through their involvement in the scheme. It is intended that family privacy will be protected to the greatest extent consistent with ensuring regular support for children.
The Bill provides comprehensive appeal and objection rights to all parties affected by the registration of a maintenance liability covered by the Bill.

Since the Minister's announcement of 24 March last year, the Government has decided to extend the scheme to cover spousal maintenance where that maintenance is payable in conjunction with registrable child maintenance.
In addition spousal maintenance will also be collectable by the Registrar in respect of individuals who are 45 years of age or over and in receipt of an income tested pension, allowance or benefit.
This additional category of maintenance is an acknowledgment by this Government of the difficulties that persons in this age bracket may have in securing a satisfactory form of income support.
Spousal maintenance will also be collectable where the order or agreement has been lodged for collection with a State collection agency and the Child Support Agency takes over those functions.
The revenue effect of these measures was estimated for 1987-88 budget purposes to be net gains of $7.6m in 1987-88 increasing to $192.8m in 1989-90.

Finally, I would mention that the Government intends to improve on this first stage of the child support scheme with the introduction as soon as is practicable of a system of formula assessment of maintenance obligations.

Effective collection of maintenance is only part of the problem. Levels of child support awarded by the courts or agreed upon by parents have been consistently inadequate when compared to the real cost of raising children. The provisions of the Family Law Amendment Act 1987 giving child support a priority over all other commitments of the parents, other than those necessary for their own support, will in part redress this problem.
The Child Support Consultative Group, under the chairmanship of Mr Justice Fogarty of the Family Court, will be soon advising the Government on elements of that formula.

The child support scheme is a major initiative of this Government of which Australians can be proud. It may be the forerunner for other countries to examine in addressing the real problem of child poverty.
I commend the Bill to the Senate. In doing so, I present the explanatory memorandum on this Bill.
Debate (on motion by Senator Reid) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: The Acting Clerk-Papers are tabled in accordance with the list circulated to honourable senators.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boswell Sen R.L.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to move a motion that the Senate take note of two papers in the list of papers just tabled by the Acting Clerk.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the Proclamation dated 19 January 1988 made under the World Heritage Properties Conservation Act 1983 and the World Heritage Properties Conservation Regulation amendment as contained in Statutory Rules 1988 No. 2 and made under the World Heritage Properties Conservation Act 1983.

Just a few seconds ago the Acting Clerk of the Senate tabled a proclamation in the Senate which will stop logging in the World Heritage area under the World Heritage legislation of 1983. This Labor Government has sold out the people of north Queensland. It has destroyed between 2,000 and 3,000 jobs by that proclamation; it has destroyed an industry worth $33m; and it has ripped the soul and the livelihoods from many people living in the World Heritage area. The workers of north Queensland who work in the logging areas have every reason to feel that they have been betrayed by the Australian Labor Party (ALP) which they traditionally support in both Commonwealth and State elections. This Labor Party has deserted the working men and women of north Queensland. If there is a lesson to be learned, the Labor Party should have learned that lesson in the Adelaide by-election two weeks ago. Clearly, the electorate said to the Labor Party, `You no longer represent us any more. We cannot trust the Labor Party to look after our interests in this national Parliament'. Therefore, they deserted the Labor Party in droves.

What is happening now is that the Labor Party is representing trendy minority groups-feminists, conservationists and a mishmash of other minority groups. It no longer represents the working man and woman of Australia. Honourable senators have only to look at today's Sydney Morning Herald to see that many of the Labor Party people are jumping for the lifeboat.

The honourable member for Kalgoorlie, Mr Graeme Campbell, is very vitriolic in his attack on the policies of the Labor Government. Even the honourable member for Bowman, Mr Sciacca, who is in my area, is saying that he no longer wants any World Heritage area listing on Stradbroke Island. He wants to protect the jobs of his constituents. The honourable member for Hinkler, Mr Courtice, has said that he wants jobs in the sand mining areas of Byfield, and so we can go on. The change is already happening in the Labor Party. Members and senators realise that they are fighting for their political lives. They can see that the winds of change are blowing. They can see that their majorities will be halved and that they will be removed from this Senate and from the House of Representatives as the people realise that they are no longer represented by the Australian Labor Party.

I want to say something to the present President of the Labor Party, Mr Mick Young. Now that he has got time because of his retirement from the House of Representatives, I say to him, `Mick, go down to the local pub. Go down to where there are some working class people and nominate them for the House of Representatives because there are no workers in this Parliament.'. I just did a quick exercise today on the front bench of the Labor Party: Senator Tate, the Minister for Justice, lecturer in law; Senator Bolkus, lawyer and research officer; Senator Button, the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commence, barrister; Senator Gareth Evans, barrister and solicitor; Senator Walsh, member of the squattocracy; Senator Cook, member of the Western Australian Trades and Labour Council and a union hack; Senator Robert Ray, the Minister for Home Affairs and the Minister Assisting the Minister for Transport and Communications, also a union hack; Senator Richardson, General Secretary of the Australian Labor Party in New South Wales; and Senator Reynolds, the Minister for Local Government, lecturer in law and married to a lecturer in law.

Senator Reynolds is supposed to represent north Queensland, the people who work in the northern areas of my State. She has neglected them. The only person who represents the working class people is Senator Devlin from Tasmania. At least he was a good waterside worker and he represents the workers of Tasmania. This Senate is devoid of any people who represent the working people of Australia. It there were some senators here who could represent the people in the $16,000 to $23,000 income bracket, those senators would be able to tell the front bench of this Labor Party what it would be like to go on the dole and what it would be like to tell one's children, `Sorry, son or daughter, I have not got a job. I cannot give you any pocket-money. I cannot pay the rent or the grocery bill. The Labor party has taken my job. It has destroyed me. It has devalued my house. It has destroyed the town you live in-and I voted for these people last election'. That is why the Labor Party needs some working class people to tell it what it is like in the $16,000 to $23,000 income bracket, a position that none of those opposite have ever been in.

I am terribly worried about the people of north Queensland. They did have a working class member of the ALP in Senator Harradine but the Party threw him out. He would have been a good representative of the ALP and would have told honourable senators opposite what the people in the $16,000 to $23,000 income bracket feel-but he was thrown out. The whole exercise of world heritage listing in north Queensland is nothing but a sham to attract the greenie vote. In the Government's lust for power, it has given no thought to the people of my electorate in Queensland who will be devastated by the proposal. Despite this, the Government has pushed through and declared an 877,000 hectare area of Queensland.

I would like to bring to the attention of the Senate the shabby way this has been done. Senator Richardson issued a Press release and said, `There shall be no more logging in north Queensland'. He did it by Press release-not by going to this Parliament. Senator Richardson then said, `If you do not stop logging there will be no compensation. There will be no compensation if you disobey my Press release'. That type of action might be all right in the right wing of the ALP in NSW but it definitely does not cut any ice in the Parliament of Australia. So, by Press release and pressure we built up such a case that Senator Richardson had to go to the Governor-General to seek a proclamation-not because he wanted to but because he was forced by Press release. He went to the Governor-General when Parliament was in recess so that we could not debate the issues. He was not man enough to bring forward the proclamation while this Parliament was sitting. That is not the way for the ALP to carry on.

The Labor Party has admitted that Senator Richardson spent $300,000 on consultancy fees-$300,000 of taxpayers' money for socio-economic reports and environmental impact studies. Yet Senator Richardson admits in a Press release that none of these reports has been brought before the Parliament. He is not in receipt of any of the eight consultancy reports that he requested. He has said to the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organisation (UNESCO), `I want you to destroy between 2,000 and 3,000 people's jobs. I do not have any scientific evidence or any socio-economic impact studies to say how we will replace those jobs. I do not know where we will place the people. I do not even know whether the forest husbandry that the Queensland Government was using when it was taking only 10 trees per hectare, every 40 years, is detrimental or degrading to the forest. All I want you to do is list the 877,000 hectares because the Labor Party is going to win votes in an election'. That is what the whole, cynical exercise is all about.

If Senator Richardson had any scientific proof, he should have presented it to UNESCO before he sought listing. He should have put the proclamation before this Parliament and let the elected representatives of the people of Queensland debate the issue before he asked UNESCO to list. But in his haste to list this area he has not done any of those things. He has gone to UNESCO and said, `List this area without any scientific or socio-economic reports and without the matter being debated in the Parliament'. He has put UNESCO in an untenable position. I have written to UNESCO and have said, `You have the right to protect the environment of the world but you also have a duty to protect the living standards of my people in Queensland'. Senator Richardson has done neither of those things.

It is a cynical exercise to win votes and destroy the livelihood, hopes and aspirations of the people in north Queensland. It is a disgusting exhibition. The people in Adelaide reacted against it. The people of Port Adelaide, in another two weeks, will again have a chance to tell the Government what they think of the Labor Party's destroying 2,000 jobs. The Labor Party, that is supposed to represent the working man and woman of Australia, is destroying between 2,000 and 3,000 jobs.

Let me talk about some of the reports that have been listed. Eight consultancy reports have been requested by the Government but only two reports have been listed. There was a report from the Anthropology and Sociology Department of the University of Queensland and the School of Australian Environmental Studies at Griffith University. That report was scathing. The study identified massive loss of jobs, a decline in business, the creation of economic and financial uncertainty and increasing strains among families within the proposed world heritage listing area. That was a report requested by the Government. It was an interim report and I will table it in Parliament. The findings have been backed up by the release of an independent report by Professor Percy Harris, a Professor of Economics at the James Cook University in north Queensland. The report identified a number of problems, including loss of employment, from migration of population, decreases in the value of capital assets, a drop in the use of local government facilities, a loss of community identity and social disruption of the local community.

The only other report that has been listed was the tame cat report of Dr Aila Keto, President of the Rainforest Conservation Society of Queensland. The Labor Government paid her $13,000 to produce the report. Fancy accepting that as a report with any credibility. She is a biochemist, not a forester. She has no ability to make any professional judgment on the World Heritage listing.

There are two reports that have been devastating to the World Heritage legislation, yet the Government has ignored them. I am glad that Senator Walsh is in the chamber because he will have to foot the bill for something between $60m and $100m. That is what the compensation will cost the Government if it meets its commitments. Senator Walsh is on record as saying that he does not have a clue what it will cost. The Government has ignored consultancy reports and the Parliament of Australia and, by Senator Walsh's own admission, he has no costings of the World Heritage listing. The Labor Government has an open chequebook approach. I blame Senator Richardson, who has such a pragmatic character that he does not worry about anything except winning, and winning at any cost. He has said, `I want to win elections and if it costs $100m of the taxpayers' money, I am prepared to pay that price'. That is what Senator Richardson thinks of the working-class people of Queensland and Australia. The proposal is a sham to win votes. Of course, the Labor Party claims that it tried to consult the Queensland Government and that the Queensland Government would not talk to it. I shall put on record what happened.

Approaches were made to the Queensland Government on the World Heritage area and it was indicated that 877,000 hectares would be listed, and that that was not negotiable. The Queensland Government was told that if it wanted to discuss compensation and jobs, the two Governments could work together, but that was the extent of the talk between Senator Richardson and the Premier's Department in Queensland. It was a gun at the head attitude. This Government indicated that it did not want to consult the Queensland Government on what areas would be listed. It said it was prepared to talk about compensation. It is no wonder that the Queensland Government said, `If that is your attitude, we are not prepared to talk to you about anything and we will fight it out in every avenue and every area we can'.

There are no reasons, no environmental impact studies and no reports to suggest that husbandry of the forest by the Queensland Government was damaging the Queensland rainforests. The timber industry has been operating there for more than 100 years. It was set up to take away the excess of timber for farms, but the Queensland Government reduced the forest take from 190,000 cubic feet to 60,000 cubic feet on its own volition to sustain logging in the forest. This Government has ignored all the scientific approaches. Independent foresters were prepared to give their own opinions, but everything has been neglected. No one has looked at any scientific evidence. No scientific reports have been presented to the Government because Senator Richardson has said that he will not receive them until February, yet the listing has taken place. UNESCO has been asked to do the listing. I advise UNESCO to be careful as it is not protecting the environment but being used as a tool to win seats for the Labor Party.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sanders Sen N.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —After that tirade of abuse and misinformation by Senator Boswell, I fell I must set the record straight. In the first place, Queenslanders should be proud, as all Australians are proud, that the area has been listed as a World Heritage area. It is an important listing. Many people on the face of the earth would be happy if their areas were listed as World Heritage areas. Very many of the people of Queensland are happy about the listing, so Senator Boswell does not represent even the majority of people in his own State.
—I polled more than 7 per cent of the vote. The National Party has 38 per cent of the vote, and you get 7 per cent.
—Order! I ask Senator Boswell not to interject while Senator Sanders is speaking.

—Thank you, Mr Acting Deputy President. The same argument occurred in Tasmania over a World Heritage listing. Even the Robin Gray Government now admits that the listing of the area has provided a great economic boom and resulted in massive tourism. It has revived the town of Strahan, as it will revive other world heritage listing areas. Listing of a World Heritage area helps the tourism industry. I have just been talking to two people who came from Cape Tribulation, an area with which I am sure Senator Boswell is familiar. They said that property values in areas included in the listing have been increasing because people are now realising the potential of tourism in the preservation of those magnificent areas.

SPEECH.PARA: Honourable senators have heard much about jobs. Senator Boswell referred to 2,000 jobs. I do not know how he arrived at that number of jobs. I know how the number of jobs was calculated in Tasmania. If there were 30 jobs involved, the number was increased by a multiplier, and then multiplied again, to give a vast number. Let us look at what is happening in the whole forestry industry not only in Queensland but around Australia. In the past 20 years jobs have been lost. The industry is in a shambles because of overcutting in all States, including Queensland. Rainforests timbers are running out. One can no longer buy specific species of timber as one used to be able to do. One must now buy a mix. The industry has cut out all the valuable sawmilling timber and is now cutting timber that it would not have considered cutting 20 years ago. The forests are being depleted of commercial stock. The forest industry is in ruins in many areas. In areas I have visited it is suggested that the mills may run for only two or three years and then the jobs will definitely be lost. It makes perfect sense to stop while there are still trees left to attract tourists, and to divert people from the sawmilling industry into the tourist industry. Some of those people may have difficulty getting jobs, but new job opportunities will open. Instead of being an area that people will leave because there are no employment opportunities, people will be flocking there to build facilities for tourists. It is time we took a good hard look at what this World Heritage listing really means. It will mean that once again Australia will be on the World Heritage map. We already have the World Heritage areas of the Franklin River in Tasmania and the Great Barrier Reef, which is a major attraction, and now we will have the wet tropics. The wet tropics are unique in the world. They deserve saving and should not be sacrificed on the altar because it might cost a few hundred temporary jobs.

What we have here is a remnant of a once vast forest. It is a vast treasure-house of scientific information, of tree species and of genetic engineering for the creation of pharmaceuticals and new chemical products. It is a museum of the past. Some of these tree species go back 200 million years. They were dinosaur fodder. It is a tribute to the Labor Government that it has seen fit to preserve this area because it sees its value. The arguments raised by Senator Boswell were emotional but not based on any scientific fact. I understand the emotions of some people from that area. They feel that they have been deprived of their sovereignty, but I think, as time goes on, they will recognise that this World Heritage listing will be the best thing that has ever happened to north Queensland, as the other listings have been one of the best things to happen to Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Burns Sen B.R

TALK.START.PARA: —I was unimpressed by the tirade from Senator Bos- well--
—I didn't think you would like it.
—Order! Senator Boswell, you are not even in your seat and I have warned you before about interjecting.

—I was unimpressed by what he said and also by the way in which he said it. I questioned his motives because I understand the way he operates and I have heard him speak in the chamber on other issues. I say thank God for the conservationists. They are the people who have put before this country the need to care about and preserve our environment. I am not suggesting that everything they say is correct. Some people talk about environmental extremists and that is the case. There are extremists in every area of pursuit and especially among people who have ideas that they try to persuade other people to accept. But then again most things of a progressive nature in this country and in other countries have come about because of people who had fairly extreme ideas and after being subjected to the fire of argument had to temper those ideas in order to come up with a more rational view. I believe there must be some balance in regard to the protection of the environment because we could protect it to the extent that all mankind would disappear.
—Would you speak to Senator Richardson about that, then?

—But the trees may still be there. I would speak to Senator Richardson, but I am sure that his knowledge and the knowledge that he has at his fingertips are far greater than that contained in my mind and to which I have access at the moment. Senator Boswell said that the forest has been logged for the past 100 years. I would challenge anybody in this chamber or elsewhere to suggest that timber-getters and loggers in the past 100 years have given a damn about our environment or about the trees and conservation of any part of this country. All they were concerned about was cutting down logs and making a quid. They were not concerned about future generations or if there would be anything left.

SPEECH.PARA: In more recent times people who have been trained as foresters in the area of forestry have some sort of balance about the issue. They want to look at managing the forest so that there can be some harvesting of timber, but the future will be guaranteed by protecting the forest generally, providing for regeneration and also examining the question of creating new forests by being involved in projects by forestry authorities in the various States.

There has been a great hue and cry about all the jobs that are being lost. I suggest that there are many hundreds of thousands of jobs that have been lost in this country because of the philosophy of the now Opposition, the then Government, in terms of rationalisation in industry. In championing the idea of trying to continue and enlarge the export of primary products and to keep Australia as a primary producer of raw materials to export throughout the world they have tried to trade that off by buying manufactured goods. Many of the people that I have represented over many years have suffered job loss in respect of that. I have not heard Senator Boswell utter one peep. All he is worried about and all he says is, `You have to compete and if you cannot do that, it is too bad, you will lose your job'.

Senator Boswell talks about the Labor Party not representing the workers. He would not know. I speak from experience and I have done so over some 30 years. I also had experience in watching and being involved in the sandmining industry when sandminers would just knock down every bit of vegetation, ruin the whole ecology, and leave it like a billiard table. Not once did the sandminers consider the environment or care what would happen in the future to some of those pristine areas that will never be replaced on this earth. They were then forced to do something about it because of the activities of conservationists and the role played by the trade union movement and those progressive people in the Labor Party.

I must say that Malcolm Fraser, probably in opposition to the National Party, finally took away the export licence for Fraser Island. So we now have Fraser Island somewhat intact, even though I think the trade-off was about exporting uranium. The facts are that trade unions that have been involved with members who have lost jobs in the manufacturing industry and other areas no longer say today, `We just have to have those jobs, that is it, no matter how efficient we are or how we operate'. They are now looking at ways in which they can become more efficient. They are looking at ways in which they with employers will be able to play a role in industry to become an effective enterprise that will enhance the economy of this country. Senator Boswell might make similar suggestions to people in north Queensland because if they are left to their own devices they will destroy every stick of rainforest in this country. The percentage of rainforest left in Queensland compared with what used to be is very small indeed. Areas of rainforest country have been destroyed. It has been destroyed not only by loggers but also by people who have cleared the land for pastoral or agricultural use. Senator Sanders was absolutely correct. As time goes on, they will find that it will be a valuable asset to this country for people who live here and for other people throughout the world who want to see what we have in Australia. Those jobs that will be generated as a result of the policy of the Labor Government in respect of rainforests will be permanent and ongoing jobs.

I suggest we should all collectively try to assist those people who have found themselves without jobs and not try to create enmity and problems where a confrontation can take place. TALK.START.PARA: —He is a wimp.
