DEBATE.TITLE: AUSTRALIAN AIRLINES (CONVERSION TO PUBLIC COMPANY) BILL 1987

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —When this debate on the Australian Airlines (Conversion to Public Company) Bill was adjourned earlier today I had outlined the fact that the Bill is based on two scores. Firstly, it clearly represents the incompetence of the Government in that it is reintroducing legislation that it wiped out four years ago, and the legislation that it wiped out four years ago was legislation passed by the Fraser Government. That surely represents incompetence in the first place; but in the second place, this Bill is a part of the Australian Labor Party's clear campaign of abandoning traditional Labor policies and instead moving in many areas-though not nearly enough-towards adopting those policies of the Opposition which clearly are to the benefit of the Australian people.

SPEECH.PARA: This legislation is to turn Australian Airlines, the old Trans Australia Airlines (TAA), into a public company. When this Bill was introduced in December of last year the Minister for Transport and Communications, Senator Evans, said:

An essential element of the deregulated environment after termination of the Two Airlines Agreement will be a strong, viable and efficient Australian Airlines which will be able to provide effective competition across the trunk route network.

The Bill now before the Senate represents an important first step in the process of preparing Australian for its future role by: establishing the airline as a public company; providing for reorganisation of the airline into a more appropriate structure prior to incorporation; and removing detailed Government controls on the airline's operations. The legislation will establish the airline as a company in the most efficient way possible, by providing for the Commission to be deemed to be a company incorporated under the Companies Act 1981 on a day to be proclaimed.

That, in simple terms, is exactly reversing the legislation passed through the Senate by this Government in 1984 which of course wiped out a situation which the Fraser Government had created in 1981. Senator Evans went on:

The airline has indicated it wishes to re-organise its activities into a holding company/subsidiary company structure, and views this as an essential part of the changes required in establishing the airline as a fully competitive public company, and to avoid any adverse legacy of its previous statutory authority form.
So here we have this enormous endorsement by the Labor Government of the concept of having TAA, or Australian Airlines, operating as a company structure. The Minister continued:

In these circumstances, this Bill represents an important first step on the part of the Government towards improved competitiveness of the airline by giving the management of Australian the flexibility to structure the airline in the most effective manner to meet the current and future challenges and the ability to run the airline without the hindrance of detailed bureaucratic controls.

The Opposition says `Hear, hear!' to all that. It said `Hear, hear!' to all that when in 1981 it introduced exactly the same legislation. It said `Hear, hear!' to all that when it opposed this extraordinary Government's decision in 1984 to cancel the legislation which created a public company structure for TAA as it then was. Of course in those days, when the public company structure legislation was passed by the Fraser Government, members of the Labor Party violently opposed the move, saying the most extraordinary and severe things which were totally contrary to what Senator Evans said when introducing this Bill. In fact, the Government's spokesman on transport in the House of Representatives, Mr Peter Morris, said:

The formation of TAA into a public company is an ill-conceived, expensive and unnecessary gimmick. The legislation constitutes a squandering of public resources by the Prime Minister in his latest manoeuvre to head off yet another rebellion by Government back benchers.

This is indeed extraordinary. I suppose one could say that we welcome the fact that the Labor Party is prepared to change its more asinine policies, but this is just a total reversal. I refer, for example, to the comments made by Mr Beazley less than four years ago when he wiped out the Fraser Government legislation which he is now embracing. I believe that is worth restating to the Senate to remind it and the people of Australia of yet the latest example of this Government giving up its basic Labor principles, its basic Labor policies, and instead adopting those policies which the Liberal and National Party coalition Opposition has been stressing are the best policies for Australia. Of course we have heard the nonsense expressed about the competence, the ability, of this Government's front bench and yet here we have another example, the latest, of that front bench and the Hawke Labor Government abandoning its long held policies and embracing those, which are of course the right policies, presented by the Opposition.

Here we have a situation where legislation introduced and passed by the Fraser Government and wiped out by the Labor Government is now being restored. It is interesting to note the manner in which this restoration is taking place, because when in May 1984 Mr Beazley, who was then the Minister for Aviation, moved that the Australian National Airlines Commission Retention Bill proceed-in other words, legislation wiping out the company structure that was passed by the Fraser Government-he said that the legislation is to `remove any doubt that Trans Australia Airlines will remain a statutory authority of the Commonwealth'. Of course that policy does not exist now, so it is a big change, is it not? He said:

Legislation was introduced in 1981 to repeal the Australian National Airlines Act with the specific purpose of setting up TAA as a public company. It was clear that the aim of the whole strategy of transforming TAA into a public company-
that is, the strategy of the Fraser Government-
was to sell it off to private interests.
It is the Government's view-
that is, the view of the Hawke Government-
that there is nothing to be gained in setting up TAA as a public company. It is the stated policy of this Government that TAA will remain wholly owned by the Commonwealth.

That is what Mr Beazley said in 1984. I wonder why in this latest legislation where the Government is restoring Australian Airlines to public company status, going back to the Fraser Government law, that undertaking given by Mr Beazley in 1984 that it is the stated policy of this Government that TAA will remain wholly owned by the Commonwealth is not repeated?

It is significant that the lefties of the Labor Party who are being kept under control at the moment because they have managed to do a deal to get Senator Bolkus elected to the front bench are clearly under constraint as part of that deal. No doubt they have been told to avoid attacking the Government on this issue, because the far left wing members of the Labor Party would certainly want to see a restatement of the policy that Australian Airlines should remain wholly owned by the Commonwealth. After all, if the Government wanted it could remain wholly owned by the Commonwealth, as it could at the moment by simply converting it from a statutory authority to a company in which the Commonwealth owns all the shares. But the absence of that undertaking is, I believe, of major significance in the current situation. In 1984 the Labor Government said, through its Minister:

We see no reason to subject TAA to the turmoil and dislocation of transforming the Commission into a company when it can operate just as efficiently and with full accountability to the Government and the Parliament in its present form. Nor can we justify to the taxpayer the very significant costs that would be incurred in such a transformation. This Government will retain TAA in full public ownership as a statutory authority. In this it can remain an arm of Government policy to ensure that the best interests of consumers are served.

We have had not one word of explanation by the Minister who introduced this legislation or by any of his acolytes who have got up and spoken-there has been only one so far and I believe that only one other is to speak-of why what was right in 1984 is now wrong according to the Labor Party. It would be very nice if the next speaker for the Labor Party, a representative of the Socialist Left, were in fact to tell us why what the Minister said in 1984 is no longer acceptable. It is incredible to me that in 1984 the Hawke Government was saying this through its Minister:

. . . the Government wishes to pursue a logical and structured approach to the future of the Australian domestic aviation industry. We will not pursue change for change's sake . . . Our aims are to ensure that the interests of consumers are properly protected and that the aviation industry is provided with the stability necessary for its future development. The retention of TAA in full public ownership and as a statutory authority is an essential precondition to the achievement of these aims.

According to the Government then, an essential pre-condition to TAA serving Australia properly was for it to remain a statutory authority. Can we please have from the Government some explanation of why that no longer holds? We did not believe it at the time and we said that it was a lot of nonsense. But would it not be decent of this Government, having taken a total reversal, a total change of policy, to explain why, to have the decency perhaps to apologise to the Australian people and to the Opposition for having rejected our original legislation, for having opposed it violently, for having then wiped it out when it got into office and for then having the temerity to come back without explanation, without justification and with the arrogance and lack of concern that I think is now the trademark or the hallmark of Labor administrations around this nation? We can look at New South Wales to see another example of that kind of arrogance.

Here the Government is wiping out all its statements, all its explanations of why it was necessary to restore TAA as a statutory authority. That was in 1984, and now everything it said is proved to have been bunkum and baloney and at last it is following the right course. We just regret that in those four years the attempt to improve the environment and provide a decent environment in which the airline industry in Australia can proceed has been delayed. It was a waste of four years, while this Government decided first to show its incompetence and ultimately to face reality and to abandon its traditional Labor policy on this matter.
As I said, we told the Government in 1984 that what it was doing was ridiculous. Mr Spender, who at that stage was our spokesman on this matter, said:

The retention of TAA as a statutory corporation, with all the special treatments and guarantee of existence that that status confers on it, is at odds with an attempt to inject into TAA some of the efficiencies and disciplines of the private sector.

That was the general approach we adopted then. It is the approach we adopt now. It is regrettable that the Labor Government is now belatedly adopting, as I said, a strongly held and long held policy position of the Opposition.

Let us deal with this matter of privatisation. As I said, the prospect of the privatisation of Australian Airlines is now very real indeed. It has been raised by many media representatives. The absence of a guarantee that Australian Airlines will not be sold, will not be privatised, from this legislation-after all, there was such a guarantee in 1984-is, I believe, a significant admission by this Government that it does intend ultimately to sell off Australian Airlines, or at least a part of it, once again following the policy lead set by the Opposition. I suggest that the comments made by Labor speakers so far that there is no necessary prospect of privatisation or sale of part of Australian Airlines are clear and self-evident nonsense.

The Opposition has for a long time advocated the sale of government assets to the private sector. In 1985, Mr Howard, in a National Press Club address, described the goals of privatisation as being two-fold: firstly, to achieve a more efficient balance between the public and private use of our resources; and, secondly, to improve the quality and choice of services available to consumers. In response, the Hawke Government then launched a vicious attack on the Opposition's privatisation proposals. In fact, in July of 1985 Mr Hawke himself commented that privatisation:
is a one-off fire sale, a sale of the century, of your assets-the assets of the people of Australia. They would transfer them into the hands of a privileged few, to the cost of every one of us.

Despite this, in his May 1987 economic statement, the Treasurer (Mr Keating) announced the sale of long term leases on all the Commonwealth's international airport terminals, the sale of the Williamstown Dockyard, the sale of a substantial portion of the Government Aircraft Factories in Victoria and the sale of surplus defence property. He announced the sale of part of our embassy site in Tokyo, Commonwealth Government offices in Sydney and Melbourne and other property. In addition, of course, there have been media reports indicating that the Government is planning to privatise 10 major statutory authorities, including Australian Airlines. Only very recently there was a front page story in the Australian to that effect.

So here we have once again the reversal of long held Labor policies by this allegedly competent and efficient Government, the abandoning of its policies and the adoption, belatedly, of policies that the Opposition parties over many years have been stressing are vital for the good government of Australia. When we look at the reversal of policy in this case, we find that it is only part of a general reversal of policies on many matters where the Government belatedly has had to admit that the Liberal and National coalition was right all the time.

For example, the Labor Party has congratulated itself on having introduced foreign banks, when in fact when in government Mr Howard, as Treasurer, had been advocating the entry of foreign banks since the release of the Campbell Report of the Committee of Inquiry into the Australian Financial System that he had commissioned. Not only that; in January 1983 he had in fact called for applications for foreign bank licences. At that time Mr Keating, who now claims credit for introducing foreign banks, criticised the proposal, stating that Mr Howard was representing the interests of `foreigners at every opportunity' to the detriment of `the little Australian'. Mr Keating also warned against the `loss of national autonomy over the economy in areas such as the exchange rate, interest rates and money supply' that would be caused by foreign bank entry. Eighteen months later, perhaps one could say 18 months too late, the Hawke Labor Government introduced exactly what it had blocked the previous Government from doing, what it had opposed with vigour and what it had been so personally insulting to John Howard about when he sought to introduce it.

This sort of cant and hypocrisy by this Government which continually rejects the policies of the Opposition, continually attacks them and then sneakily later on adopts them totally is represented in this legislation here today. Here we have, as I said earlier, legislation which simply restores legislation passed by the Fraser Government in 1981 which was wiped out by a doctrinaire, nonsensical Hawke Government in 1984 which at last has recognised that what is needed to improve this industry is this kind of legislation.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating the Australian Airlines (Conversion to Public Company) Bill 1987. In October last year Senator Gareth Evans released a statement announcing the Government's intention to deregulate the airline industry. The aims of this new policy were to increase airline responsiveness to consumer needs, to widen the range of fares and types of services offered and to increase competition and efficiency while maintaining Australia's world class safety record. The Bill now before the Senate is but a small part of that process. It deems Australian Airlines to be a company incorporated under the Australian Capital Territory companies code, thereby changing its status from that of a Federal government commission as it now is to that of an ordinary company with a share capital.

SPEECH.PARA: The Bill also removes a number of government controls over the airline. Australian Airlines will be able to make its own expenditure decisions on all matters except those which are so significant as to require a further injection of capital by the Federal Government. It will be able to determine its own terms and conditions of borrowing, leasing, investment of surplus money, choice of auditor, provisions for dividends and risk insurance-just those modest, simple, obvious and natural things that any corporation seeking in any way to have a capacity to make proper commercial judgments has.

It is claimed that this will give the airline flexibility to face the coming challenge of a deregulated domestic market. It almost certainly will and for that reason the Bill receives my support and the support of the Opposition, subject, of course, to the amendment that has been moved by Senator Messner. I do not criticise the Government's moves towards deregulation; I criticise it because it simply has not gone far enough.

It is not possible to examine the shortfalls in this Bill without considering them against the background of the airline industry as a whole. Broadly speaking, Senator Gareth Evans's statement, Domestic Aviation: A New Direction For The 1990s, announced the end of the two-airline policy. He said that when this occurs at the end of the three-year notice period it will be open to anyone to start an airline to fly whatever routes he so wishes using whatever aircraft type he chooses and charging fees that he judges to be competitive. The two inevitable limitations were the constitutional inability of the Commonwealth to regulate purely intra-State airline services and that the Commonwealth would retain responsibility for safety regulation.

The statement contained three other crucial limitations, each one of which, of course, has relevance to the Bill presently before the chamber. They were the Government's failure to announce that it would sell Australian Airlines to the private sector in whatever form; its continued restrictions on the role of international airlines in the domestic market; and the limitations on investment in Australian domestic airlines by foreign international airlines. I am not suggesting necessarily that they are a prescription that the Opposition supports but they seem to me to be matters that ought to be put on the table and debated openly and properly before conclusions are drawn. However, given the enormous infra- structure of Ansett Airlines, there seems to be no easy way of providing it with adequate and proper competition without in some way providing a competitor which has the capacity to compete with it on a financial basis.

The crucial importance of the retention of these limitations within a general framework of a deregulated airline industry is that rather than increasing competition they close it off, leaving the Australian domestic market wide open to domination by Ansett. There are only three immediate ways that the Government can ensure that Ansett does not dominate the domestic market. The first is to ensure that Australian Airlines is as strong as possible and able to compete in the open market without having one hand tied behind its back; the second is the use of international airlines, particularly Qantas Airways Ltd, to carry purely domestic passengers on the domestic legs of its international flights; and the final way is to allow international airlines, whether Qantas or otherwise, to establish Australian domestic subsidiaries. These are not judgments or measures that we necessarily support but they are matters that ought to be raised and debated. It seems to me they are necessary at least in part in some form or mix if we are in the short term to have proper competition for Ansett.

I turn now to Ansett Airlines. The position of Ansett is crucial to any decision about Australian Airlines if the Government is serious about wanting a flexible, competitive airline industry. I seek leave to have incorporated in Hansard a table showing the dominance of the two major airlines in the current domestic market.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. Ansett and Australian Airlines each control slightly more than 40 per cent of the market at present but when one takes into consideration the regional airlines one sees that Ansett Airlines owns, controls or has an interest in airlines covering almost 60 per cent of the total industry. Ansett has shown throughout its history that it will swallow up competitor airlines or at least bring them under its influence. It has made acquisitions including MacRobertson Miller Airlines, which is now Ansett Western Australia, Air New South Wales, Ansett Northern Territory, Queensland Airlines and Butler Air.

SPEECH.PARA: Ansett owned Airlines of South Australia until it ceased operations in 1986. Some of its services were taken over by Kendall Airlines. Kendall Airlines is partly owned by Bodas Pty Ltd, which is jointly owned by News Corporation and Thomas Nationwide Transport (TNT), the beneficial owners of Ansett. Bodas also owns Aeropelican, the Newcastle to Sydney commuter. Eastern Airlines is also partly owned by East-West Airlines Ltd, which is now being acquired by Ansett. However, I am aware that the Trade Practices Commission has said that Ansett has to divest some of the East-West operations. Nonetheless, it was the one airline that showed any potential to be a real competitor to the two major airlines we presently have.

In Australia, the Ansett Transport Industries group owns Gateway hotels, Ansett Pioneer coaches, Ansett Wridgways and Diners Club. Ansett's overseas interests include Ansett New Zealand. Ansett owns 90 per cent of Transcorp, a newly established freight company running from Hong Kong to Sydney with a single Boeing 707. Ansett also runs airlines on behalf of the Cook Islands Government and Western Samoa. The company is also presently negotiating with the Uruguayan Airline, Pluna, on a joint venture to run domestic air services in that country. Ansett Worldwide Aviation Services is a branch of Ansett which has only recently been established. It will be leasing new Fokker F50 turboprops, Boeing 737s, Airbus Industrie's A320 Skystars and old F27s and 727s from the Ansett fleet. One has to remember that Ansett is jointly owned by Thomas Nationwide Transport, the biggest land transport organisation in the world, and Rupert Murdoch's News Corporation, which is one of the biggest media organisations in the world. TNT has ordered 72 BAE 146 air freight jets from British Aerospace, tying up the company's total production in that line of aircraft for the next five years.

I am not criticising the Ansett group by any means, I am just setting out the enormous capacity and infrastructure it has in Australia and the supporting infrastructure it has overseas. I am sure that its success can be attributed to a great deal more than simply the protection it has received under the two-airline policy of the Australian Government until now. There is certainly nothing wrong with Ansett being the size it is and being able to diversify. Under no circumstances would I suggest that that corporation ought in any way to be broken up.

Against the backdrop of such an enormous and powerful company like Ansett, the Government must ensure that Australian Airlines is able to compete as effectively as possible if we are to have any hope whatsoever of a free and competitive aviation market. That, of course, is not likely to be the case if the Government remains moribund regarding privatisation. As was mentioned in the report of the May Independent Review of Economic Regulation of Domestic Aviation, Australian Airlines has always faced a number of constraints stemming from the fact that it is owned by the Government. It has had to obtain Cabinet approval to purchase new aircraft. It has had to obtain Loan Council approval to borrow. Australian Airlines must follow Federal Government purchasing policies and the salaries of senior management are set by the Remuneration Tribunal.

Some of these constraints will go, as I mentioned, under the legislation. Some, of course, will be retained. The most crucial of these is the Federal Government's involvement in the provision of equity financing to Australian Airlines. The balance sheet in the 1986-87 annual report of Australian Airlines shows that total equity for the group from the Commonwealth Government is just over $186m. Actual paid-up capital is only $130m. Expansion has been predominantly debt financed, leaving Australian with a high debt equity gearing ratio and with the constraint of regular interest payments.

Neil Smith, the airline's Chairman, said in April last year that the airline had been informed that it needed a capital base of at least $300m, which means that it needs an additional injection of another $170m. My guess is that that figure has substantially increased since April and it may well be heading towards $250m. The Chairman said that obviously the Government did not have $170m to play with. He suggested that the sale of shares to the public could provide Australian with the capital that it very badly needed. This is no ideologue talking. It is simply that the Chairman of the airline recognises what the Australian Labor Party (ALP) refuses to recognise-that is, that Australian Airlines needs capital which the Government is unable to provide. The Government can talk all it likes about flexibility of public company status, but if it starves Australian Airlines of the capital it needs, it will never be able to compete effectively with Ansett.

Australian desperately needs an improved capital base for the improvement of its airline fleet. Australian, as we who regularly fly with the airline know, is still flying DC9 aircraft which Ansett was able to abandon years ago. It still flies the old F27 Fokkers which, again, have been hived off by Ansett to its regional airlines. Ansett is, naturally, ahead of Australian in purchasing the more efficient 737 aircraft, yet the technology on these aircraft is continually being improved. Areas of improvement to aircraft, as we all know, include aerodynamic design, weight reduction from better materials for aircraft construction, more efficient engines and better flight systems, which, of course, make for more precise operation of flights and improve efficiency, economy, safety and, most of all, profitability. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a table showing the improvements that are expected to be made in aircraft in the 20 years from 1972 to 1992.

TALK.START.PARA: —In light of these changes, if Australian is to face problems in trying to get a mere $170m out of the Commonwealth, what possible hope is there of keeping up with and providing very real competition for Ansett when the Ansett group spends billions of dollars on aircraft? I find it the ultimate irony that those rabid left wingers of the ALP who normally have no end of energy for raving on about the evils of capitalism seem absolutely determined through their refusal to contemplate the privatisation of Australian Airlines to hand over aviation to a virtual monopoly. The very fact that they are starving Australian Airlines of capital, and that they are disallowing it from being a private company is guaranteeing, in a very real sense, the prospects of monopoly for Ansett Airlines.

SPEECH.PARA: Why the Labor Party wants to place the ball and chain of public ownership around Australian Airlines is beyond me. I can only imagine that some of the hopeless romantics still cling desperately to the tried, failed and discredited notion that one can socialise the industry. Despite the fact that airline privatisation has occurred or is occurring in Britain, South Korea, Japan, West Germany, Spain, Italy, Singapore and Turkey, the old head in the sand socialists of the ALP still pine for the democratic socialisation of the means of production, distribution and exchange. It is epitomised in no better way than in their attitudes towards TAA, or Australian Airlines as it is now known.

In another area of industry, even the Commonwealth Bank Officers Association has recognised that public enterprises will wither and die if they do not get the capital they need and they are not likely to get it from this Government or from any other government. Meanwhile, the members of the Government rely on the rhetoric of leaving the great institutions built up over the decades to our children.

I note that the May report made the point that Ansett Airlines has consistently produced a higher profit and a better return on assets than Australian. So not only does Australian face a bleak future, thanks to the Government's ideologues, but it seems that it is even starting out behind the eight ball.

Of course, I have been at pains to point out to a government committed to the deregulation of domestic airlines how hopelessly inadequate this Bill for the conversion of Australian Airlines to a public company is without those further steps of privatisation. Whilst discussing the inadequacy of the measures before the chamber, for the sake of completeness I touch upon the failure to include international airlines in the deregulation plans. In his airline statement, Senator Gareth Evans said that the Government would allow Qantas to interline. Of course, as we all know, this is the practice whereby airlines can carry overseas passengers on domestic legs. For instance, if a passenger purchased a ticket from Kuala Lumpur to Sydney, he could take a Malasian Airline System flight to Perth and then travel by Qantas to Sydney. This is an effort to overcome the ridiculous situation which currently exists whereby inbound Qantas flights from Europe to Sydney may offload passengers at Perth and then fly from Perth to Sydney three-quarters empty. While interlining of international passengers is undoubtedly an improvement-modest as it is-it still does not cover people who wish to make purely domestic journeys. No passenger wishing to undertake a purely domestic Perth to Sydney journey can board a Qantas flight. As we all know, there are people who buy tickets from Perth to Wellington and from Wellington to Singapore who are able to fly from Perth to Sydney in that roundabout way using Qantas. Of course, it is a very difficult route. We therefore have the ludicrous situation of about 17,000 empty seats each week on Qantas flights. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a table indicating the level of unused Qantas seating capacity each week between Australian ports.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is a ludicrous waste of resources. It equates to Qantas flying 40 empty aircraft around Australian skies every week. Of course, it denies Australians cheaper transport in a country in which distance has always been a national obstacle. Most of all it harms Western Australians, for the simple reason that we are farthest from most other parts of Australia. Qantas has indicated that it can carry passengers from Sydney to Perth for about $100 each way. We are presently paying $400 each way for an economy ticket. Qantas has carried domestic passengers before. For a period until 1976 Qantas could carry passengers from Darwin to Brisbane, Sydney or Melbourne. This was not successful because the condition attached to being able to fly passengers from Darwin to these ports was that Qantas charged no less than a normal first class fare plus one-third. I think it made a profit of $12,000 in one year.

SPEECH.PARA: International airlines carry domestic passengers in the United States. An inbound United Airlines aircraft from, say, Sydney to Los Angeles going on to New York can pick up Los Angeles-New York passengers. Rather than passengers going through Customs checks at the end of their journey all passengers are cleared through Customs at the first port of entry. Then they are able to travel comfortably and freely on all subsequent sectors as if they were domestic passengers. Despite the predictable opposition to such a proposal from Ansett Airlines I note that Ansett has been only too happy to enter the New Zealand market where the dominant competitor is Air New Zealand, which operates both international and domestic services. Ansett has also purchased 20 per cent of the Arizona airline America West and operates in a country where the artificial barriers between international and domestic flights have been removed.

In its response to the May report Australian Airlines did not favour international airlines carrying domestic passengers. It was, however, quite happy to see it occur if the international airlines first sold their seats to domestic airlines and the domestic airlines were then able to on-sell them to the traveller. One can assume that the positions of Ansett and Australian Airlines did not spring from any matter of principle but simply from a desire to protect their own interests. It ought not to be forgotten that Ansett and Australian Airlines were the only organisations, to my knowledge, to forward submissions to the May inquiry supporting the present two-airline policy.

International flights could never completely replace domestic flights. They face longer checking times, suffer very extensive delays and naturally do not operate as regularly. They are, therefore, never likely to be particularly attractive to business travellers. They may be attractive to families, tourists and students. The carriage of domestic passengers by international airlines would inject a very real sense of competition into the domestic market post-deregulation. It would improve the viability of international flights and improve the services to the smaller international airports, possibly leading to the establishment of more international gateways which would otherwise be considered not viable.

I understand that this week alone 100 senators and members are waitlisted seeking to travel from Melbourne to Canberra next Monday to return to their place of work. But the airlines are not putting extra aircraft on because they have a monopoly. There is no stimulus to ensure that the airlines are compelled to put extra aircraft on and to compete because if one airline does not have to put them on the other airline does not have to put them on.

The May report noted that allowing international airlines to carry domestic passengers may increase the number of departures from small international airports, as I have said. The alternative to not allowing this is that many international passengers will have to travel hundreds of miles to international airports, often then only to travel back over the same ground on an international flight. It may also result in more international flights stopping at two ports. If this were the case one could expect more flights to stop at Perth en route west. This would naturally increase tourism and mean that more Australians would see more of their own country rather than going overseas. Currently an economy fare to Sydney on Ansett or Australian Airlines costs $888 return. It is possible to obtain a reduced Apex fare of $577 return but this requires 30 days notice.

TALK.START.PARA: —Come on, wind it up.

—Senator Evans clearly is desperately short of time for reasons which, admittedly, escape me. I have spoken about Qantas. There is no logical reason why this should not apply to other aircraft, irrespective of their flags. With the indulgence of the Minister I conclude by saying that if the Government stops and looks at its aviation policy it will see the dangers that it holds for the aviation market. Its policy of deregulation is sound but it is the buts which follow it which give the word deregulation such a hollow ring. It has said deregulation but not privatisation of Australian Airlines, and without any international carriers carrying domestic passengers and deregulation, but without the ability of foreign international airlines being able to invest in Australian domestic airlines. It has, as a result, virtually handed over the domestic aviation industry to Ansett Airlines on a plate. The tragedy is that one suspects that if the Government does not change course this will happen very shortly. In the event that it does happen there is no possibility of any other real competitor coming into the market.

SPEECH.PARA: This Government ought to be condemned for not having the courage to move forward, in the way which I understand Senator Evans would wish, completely to privatise Australian Airlines, to allow it to have a proper capital base, to make autonomous decisions and, at this late stage if it is possible, to be really competitive with Ansett Airlines.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Burns Sen B.R

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition highlights or tries to focus on what it believes is a departure by the Labor Party from its principled position on many things. But we are not a fossilised party. We are a party that thinks on its feet. We have a very good leader in the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), a good front bench and a thinking and thoughtful back bench. We will never be in a position where we will not be thinking about different ways to serve the people of this nation. I think Australian Airlines is the finest internal airline in this country. It would never have been brought into existence without the decision of the Australian Labor Party Government some years ago. It has an excellent standard of service.

SPEECH.PARA: Reference has been made to the Fraser Government's legislation which was disallowed in 1984 and there has been some accusation about ALP doctrinaire attitudes. Again, what may have been appropriate yesterday is no longer appropriate today and what is appropriate today may not be appropriate in a week's time. We look at things on their merits as they stand and take the necessary and appropriate action at the time. The Hawke Government is an excellent manager of our resources and our economy. It sees this legislation as a first step towards a better and more efficient airline. That is the difference between this and the Fraser legislation. We want an airline to be proud of but an airline that is not on the road to privatisation.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is not different.

—Senator Messner was kind enough to advertise to everybody that I very much oppose the privatisation of Australian Airlines. I would like to say to everybody in the community and put on record here and now that I have worked in opposition to privatisation. I shall continue to do so, subject to the restraints of democracy and majority decisions, obviously. Ownership appears to be critical in the minds of Opposition members. They talk about our being opposed to a commercial operation. I suggest that because the airline is owned by the Government this does not mean that it cannot be efficient. One could not by any stretch of the imagination talk about a socialised industry in the terms that are suggested by the Bill. What the Opposition talks about in terms of competition is the anarchy of competition in a restricted market where people vying for a market that is too small for two will destroy themselves, their shareholders and in the process badly damage possibly the other company or organisation that seeks to operate in that area. As one of the speakers opposite has said, the role of Australian Airlines should be to serve the people of Australia. I agree with that. It should do so as a Government owned enterprise, managed by an enlightened management, practising consultative processes with an excellent, caring work force. I believe that this legislation will enable that to occur.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —It looks like the numbers are against us on the rhetoric of the second reading amendment that has been moved by the Opposition but that the numbers are with us on the substance of the Australian Airlines (Conversion to Public Company) Bill. So under those circumstances I shall bear with such fortitude as I can command the gales of rhetoric that have been coming across the chamber and respond very briefly, nonetheless, to indicate why the Opposition amendment is misconceived and sit down in order to enable the Bill to go through its remaining stages before we adjourn at 7.30 p.m. If I were to respond to every one of the hares or rabbits that have been set running during this debate it would, of course, take rather longer, but I think most of the contributions have not really been all that much to the point of this legislation and we can dispense with those formalities.

SPEECH.PARA: The first element in the Opposition's attack on the legislation in the second reading rhetorical amendment is to decry the hypocrisy allegedly of the Government in introducing this legislation to incorporate Australian Airlines against a background of having, in 1984, acted to repeal similar legislation set in train but never brought to fruition by our predecessors. I do not think it is hypocrisy to take a position on one occasion and then change one's mind if further and better information and argument comes to hand and a better Bill with it. That is not a sign of hypocrisy; that is a sign of maturity in Government. It is a much better Bill this time than was the case before, as is evident from the fact that the then Government's Bill-that is, the present Opposition's Bill-although enacted in 1981 still had not been proclaimed by the time we came into office in 1983 because it was so riddled with technical faults and flaws involving as it did a fundamental change in the character of the organisation in the course of its transition to the incorporated status that it was simply incapable of implementation in its present form. The particular technical approach that we have adopted which deems the existing statutory authority to be a company incorporated under the Companies Act is an approach which involves the need to transfer assets, to assign contracts, to reformulate staff terms and to change existing loan guarantees. It is much more streamlined and sensible legislation and, as such, deserves the commendation rather than the jeers of the Opposition by comparison with its own meagre efforts of yesteryear.

A number of different changes in the aviation environment have occurred since 1984 to alter the Government's approach and perspective to this, not least, of course, the deregulation decision-Senator MacGibbon, incidentally, does not seem to have caught up with this-made and announced in October last year. It will create a much more volatile and vibrant domestic aviation environment in Australia and one that makes it that much more crucial that Australian Airlines be strong and viable and a commercially successful entity in the way we believe this legislation will contribute.

We are, secondly, attacked for failing to take into account the recommendations of the advisory group established last October which has not yet reported. I simply say that that is a totally half-baked assertion because there is no possible conceivable conflict between the passage of this legislation to allow for incorporation of Australian Airlines and any subsequent report we may receive from the advisory group which will simply go to things like the airline's capital requirements for the future and which are perfectly easily able to be accommodated within this particular corporate structure we are now promoting and achieving whatever those recommendations may be.

We are, thirdly, castigated for our alleged failure to decide now whether or not to privatise Australian Airlines. I simply say that there is no need whatever to make that decision at this stage. There is plenty of time to debate the necessity or desirability of that particular matter. The question of ownership is quite distinct from that of commercialisation which is being achieved and advanced by this particular legislation. We are, fourthly, assaulted for creating `continuing, unnecessary uncertainty' among Australian Airlines' employees. This, again, is total nonsense. There is no uncertainty; the employees are perfectly happy as I understand it with the situation-certainly the trade union movement is happy. On transition to company status each staff member of the Australian National Airlines Commission will become an employee of the company on the same terms and conditions. All entitlements to long service leave and the like will be preserved.

We are castigated, finally, for our continuing poor administration of Australia's aviation infrastructure. There are many replies that I could make to that, not least to recite some of the courageous and far-reaching decisions that we have taken, not least, of course, the deregulation decision which the Opposition, for all its free enterprise rhetoric, did not get around to doing in fully 23 years in government. I refer to the creation of the Federal Airports Corporation, the imminent creation of the Civil Aviation Authority and matters of that like. We have really been a pretty good all round Government when it comes to aviation and we have made some pretty spectacular policy improvements in the last few months. This legislation is a fine example of the contributions that can be expected from a Government of the maturity of the present Hawke Administration. With those remarks, I commend this legislation to the House.
Amendment agreed to.
Original question, as amended, agreed to.
Bill read a second time, and passed through its remaining stages without amendment or debate.

PROCTEXT.PARA: That the Senate do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Schacht Sen C.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to take this opportunity in the adjournment debate to make a few remarks about a recent visit I made to Kampuchea. I want to place on record not just my impression but my thanks to the people involved in organising the visit. I also want to make some comment about the situation in that tragic country. I was very pleased to be able to accept an invitation from World Vision to join a delegation to visit Kampuchea in late January, early February this year. The Federal member for Dundas, Mr Phil Ruddock, was also part of the delegation, as were two other members of World Vision, Harold Henderson and Roger Walker. Mr Ruddock had visited Kampuchea two years ago. He warned me on my way there that it would be an emotionally wrenching experience. He, in no way, exaggerated that description. I have been involved in politics for 20 years, but that week in Kampuchea was the most profound in an emotional sense that I have ever experienced.

SPEECH.PARA: I thank World Vision for giving me the opportunity to visit the country. It is difficult for Australian parliamentarians to visit because of the diplomatic situation relating to Kampuchea. One gets a number of impressions about Kampuchea. I certainly do not wish to be taken as an expert after spending only one week in the country, but I think I can make some comment about the state of the country. First, one is not visiting a third world country. It is more like a fourth or fifth world country. It would have to be, if not the poorest country in the world, then very close to it. People say that nine years after the end of the Pol Pot regime, the country has shown significant improvement. All I can say is that I am glad I did not visit nine years ago because if the country is in an improved state now it must have been an absolute hellhole in 1979-80. The impression of the country is overwhelming and quite numbing. To see people who are poverty stricken and suffering from all types of malnutrition and practically every known disease that people have ever heard of-leprosy, malaria, dysentery, cholera, typhoid, dengue fever and so on-and an infant mortality rate of nearly 300 per thousand, makes one realise that one is dealing with an extraordinarily tragic situation.

One of the things Australians can be proud of is the fact that Australia is providing more aid to Kampuchea than is any other western country. That is a record of which the Australian people and the Australian Government can be very proud. The aid is provided through the operation of a number of non-government organisations, including the one I went with as part of the delegation, World Vision. Other Australian agencies such as Freedom from Hunger, the Australian People for Health Education Development Abroad, Austcare, Overseas Aid Abroad, and so on, are all operating there. I would like to compliment the Australian aid workers in that country. All Australians can be proud that fellow Australians have been willing to make the commitment to work in conditions that are not only threatening to their own health but also psychologically overwhelming. The fact that people work there for a year or two on these aid programs is something of which all Australians can be proud.

Secondly, not only is the Government of Kampuchea appreciative of the aid Australia has given, but also the ordinary people understand that, as a country, we are making a major contribution of humanitarian aid to the well-being of their country. It has made the standing of our country very high. The Australian people and the Government can be congratulated for their effort in supporting voluntary aid programs.

No visit to Kampuchea can be complete without seeing what are now termed in the west `the killing fields'. Although I had seen the movie, still photographs and documentaries, nothing prepared me for what I saw. I find it hard to describe the feeling when I walked into a nondescript shed and saw over 8,000 skulls neatly stacked in rows. Underneath were the rest of the skeletons and surrounding the shed were a hundred pits from which the bodies had been exhumed. It was really quite numbing.

If that were not bad enough, I was taken later in the day to the Tuol Sleng interrogation centre which the Pol Pot regime established. That was the pits as far as human degradation and cruelty are concerned. The Tuol Sleng interrogation centre was once a school. The Pol Pot regime established it to interrogate political prisoners. In a period of four years nearly 10,000 political prisoners were interrogated and tortured to death in that centre. The purpose was to torture those people into signing the most absurd confessions that they were part of Central Intelligence Agency (CIA) plots or plots by the Vietnamese Government to overthrow the Pol Pot regime. There is even unfortunate evidence that an Australian was killed there. He was on a yacht with some Americans, sailing in the Gulf of Siam, when they sailed too close to the coast of Kampuchea and were taken in custody by the Kampuchean navy. They were taken immediately to this interrogation centre and forced to sign mad confessions that they were part of a CIA plot, before they were tortured to death. The Australian's photograph is displayed on the wall.

When one goes through the centre one sees an extraordinary display. The man who ran the centre on behalf of Pol Pot was very methodical. He photographed every victim who was brought in. Those photographs were captured in 1979 by the Vietnamese army. They are now displayed around several walls of the prison. From time to time survivors of the Pol Pot regime go there to see whether they can find any record of what happened to their families. The man who ran the centre, Mr Duc, was not only interested in photographing people as they were taken into the centre, but he also liked to take photographs of his victims after they had been tortured, in many cases to death or near death. All around another room photographs of the most horrible kind are displayed. They are of people who have been beaten to death or have had limbs broken and were obviously suffering from malnutrition. There are photographs of the various methods of torture and drawings by the only known seven victims who survived the interrogation centre.

Although it is gruesome to describe these details, they should go on the public record because the world should never forget that from 1975 to 1979 a psychotic maniac called Pol Pot had control of the country and in that time he killed approximately two million of his own people. The methods of torture included drowning, beating, crushing hands and electric treatment. The beatings went on for a long time until people were forced to sign absurd confessions. Once the confessions were signed, if the people did not die from their torture, they were killed and dumped in the death pits I saw outside Phnom Penh.

The killing field and interrogation centre I saw were repeated all over Kampuchea. It is said that every village of any size and every town had its own version of what I saw in Phnom Penh-its own killing field. One cannot speak to any Kampucheans without finding that they lost some member of their families during the Pol Pot regime. Our interpreter was from a family of nine. Only he and his sister survived. His father was classed as an intellectual. He was a public servant and therefore, by definition, was an enemy of the Pol Pot regime and so was murdered. When Pol Pot came to power there were 1,400-odd doctors in Kampuchea. When he was kicked out in 1979, only 34 were found alive. It was the same with school teachers and dentists. Anyone with professional training suffered the same consequences.

It was a profound experience to see these dreadful things. However, in one sense I am glad I did, because it made me aware that whatever problems we might have in Australia, there are people in the world who have suffered immeasurably more than we have. Australia's role in Kampuchea is well recognised by the Kampuchean people. Not only in the aid area, but also, politically, the efforts made by our Government, and particularly by the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, Mr Hayden, are recognised by the people. Mr Hayden must take great credit for the efforts he has made. He is seen by the Kampuchean Government and the people as being one of the very few politicians in the world who have genuinely tried to get a solution.

While I was in Kampuchea with the delegation I was very fortunate to have an opportunity to speak with the Prime Minister of Kampuchea, Mr Hun Sen, only two days after his return from Paris after the second round of talks with Prince Sihanouk. Despite the enormous difficulties and the tragedy of Kampuchea, there seems to be some hope that a political settlement will occur. One should not be overly optimistic when dealing with Kampuchea. Pessimism seems to be a major quality in dealing with this unfortunate country. However, there is some hope that settlement between the various forces will be reached.

The two major factors that stop settlement being reached are the presence of Vietnamese troops in the country, numbering more than 100,000, and the fact that more than 30,000 armed Khmer Rouge soldiers under the control of Pol Pot and his supporters are still located over the border in Thailand. The Vietnamese say they will not withdraw until Pol Pot's army is disarmed. The people who support Pol Pot say they will not do anything until the Vietnamese withdraw. It is a vicious circle. However, negotiations in Paris are now leading to the stage where a settlement is possible.

According to the Prime Minister, both he and Prince Sihanouk agree that Australia will have a role to play in the settlement of the Kampuchean dispute. It was suggested by both of them that when an international conference takes place, which they hope will be chaired by Prime Minister Gandhi of India, Australia will be one of the countries invited to participate. Following that conference, Australia may be asked to be party to an international peace keeping force to provide internal security in Kampuchea while a free election takes place to ensure that the result of the election properly reflects the free will of the people of Kampuchea.

I believe that Australia will be invited to send a delegation to observe the election, either as parliamentarians or as Australian citizens; but if Australia is asked to participate in any way, I believe it should accept that invitation. It would be a final recognition that Australia has played a major and constructive role in resolving the Kampuchean dispute.

I shall conclude by making a final comment about the future of Pol Pot and his supporters. I find it incredible that Pol Pot is able to live comfortably in Thailand with the support of a number of countries. It is disappointing that both China and the United States of America in their own ways have been providing support to keep the Khmer Rouge going in Kampuchea. That is done by provision of aid to the United Nations Border Relief Operation (UNBRO), which is an agency providing aid to the refugee camps along the Thailand border. A large proportion of that aid ends up in the refugee camps controlled by the Khmer Rouge. The Khmer Rouge refuse to allow United Nations representatives into the camps to see how the aid is being used. Independent observers believe that much of the aid is used to feed and succour the soldiers of the Khmer Rouge.

I find it extraordinary not only that China is following the policy of allowing that to happen but particularly that the USA is doing so. The American Administration trumpets its anti-communism all over the world and such is its justification for what it is doing in central America, yet in the past year alone more than $12m worth of aid from the United States of America was provided to the camps and much of that ended up in the hands of Khmer Rouge. It is extraordinary that the Reagan Administration, despite its anti-communist credentials, is providing assistance to the worst communist regime this world has ever seen and hopes never to see again.

Only last year, when he was suffering from ill health, Pol Pot was given excellent medical treatment in a Bangkok hospital. I find that an obscenity when people of his own country are denied that type of medical attention, and were denied any reasonable medical attention when he was running the country. Last year, the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, Mr Bill Hayden, raised the suggestion that an international tribunal should be looking at the crimes of Pol Pot against the Kampuchean people and against humanity. I fully support that suggestion. I do not believe there can be any moral basis for a settlement in Kampuchea unless Pol Pot and his closest supporters, who perpetrated the genocide against their own people, are brought to some sort of reckoning in a world forum. Although it will not bring back to life the two million people who died under his regime in Kampuchea, it will at least show the Kampuchean people that the rest of the world cares about what happened to them and will do everything possible to ensure that such a genocidal regime will not develop again on this earth.

In conclusion, I say that my visit to Kampuchea was a profound experience for me. I thank World Vision for giving me the opportunity. I shall never forget what I saw, and the visit certainly makes me much more committed to do anything I can as a humble Australian politician to support a settlement in Kampuchea and to help the Kampuchean people to a just, prosperous peace. I thank the Senate for allowing me to put those comments on the record.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before directing the attention of the Senate to some of the difficulties associated with anti-dumping legislation, I take the opportunity of congratulating Senator Schacht on his very moving address. It is a pity that more senators were not present in the chamber to hear it, because it illustrated the degree of difficulty and deprivation that can occur in a country not far from Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: I take this opportunity of directing the attention of the Senate to a number of inadequacies in existing anti-dumping legislation, particularly deficiencies in the so-called fast-track mechanism. The anti-dumping laws are simply not offering adequate protection to industry from the unscrupulous dumping of products on the Australian market at prices significantly less than their normal value in their country of origin.

It is recognised internationally, and documented in the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade (GATT) subsidies and countervailing code, to which Australia is a signatory, that such practices are contrary to the conduct of fair trade between nations. This Government is supposedly committed to a quick and effective anti-dumping system, but Australia still maintains laws and procedures which are protracted and which afford little protection. Australian industry needs a system that will swiftly and efficiently apply measures to promote fair trade. Currently, the incentive to initiate anti-dumping action is being eroded by the prospect of an expensive and drawn-out procedure with no guarantee of a satisfactory remedy even where a case is proven.

I shall outline a particular case to illustrate what I have just said. The case concerns the dumping of peas from New Zealand on the Australian market. This action is of considerable concern in my own State of Tasmania, where nearly one-third of Australia's total pea crop is produced. The case commenced on 30 October 1985 when a complaint was lodged with the Australian Customs Service. On 31 August 1986, a preliminary finding was announced by Customs. Cash securities were requested. Early in 1987 a decision against the complainant was announced in the Federal Court and costs were borne by the complainant. In September 1987 a discussion on the draft of the Customs final report was held. In December 1987 the ministerial decision was announced.

More than two years passed between the initial lodgment of the complaint and the announcement of the final decision. During that time New Zealand continued to export significant quantities of peas to Australia at less than the normal value. During that period the Australian industry shouldered the impact of the dumping of the product on its market and bore considerable costs to bring the case before the courts. After two years of investigation the final decision, published in the Commonwealth of Australia Gazette of 6 January this year, found that there was a case for the application of the Customs Tariff (Anti-Dumping) Act in respect of frozen peas exported from New Zealand. However, the industry was less than satisfied to find that duties would be backdated only for a period of 120 days preceding the publication of the notice. That is despite the fact that substantial shipments of peas came into Australia between August 1986 and December of last year. It appears that New Zealand has escaped any penalty from August 1986 to September 1987.

The industry, understandably, feels it has suffered a loss as a result of this decision. The Government has not met its obligation under the Customs Tariff Anti-Dumping Act. One additional point that concerns me in this case further illustrates the inadequacies of the law. A countervailing action was also lodged in this case as the New Zealand exporters were benefiting substantially from an export assistance scheme. While the case was proven in this instance, little remedy has been forthcoming. As a result of negotiations, New Zealand has given an undertaking not to seek benefit from export grants between January and September of this year. I ask: Is this sufficient remedy, given that New Zealand exporters have been receiving export grants for the past two years?

Anti-dumping laws are simply not giving fair and adequate protection to Australian industry. What is needed is a much more streamlined procedure for handling anti-dumping complaints. The Gruen Report, released in April 1986, stated:
The (Anti-Dumping) Act should be amended to clarify its meaning and to ensure speedy and effective application of measures designed to promote fair trade . . .
Despite such recommendations this Government has yet to take any positive action in this direction. In fact, the reverse has been the case.

In August of last year the Australian Customs Service announced new investigation procedures for anti-dumping cases. While in the past maximum time limits for inquiries in the first stage of preliminary investigations have been 55 days, the maximum allowance is now 180 days. As a result, complainants can now expect an even longer wait before a decision is made. In the meantime Australian industry is suffering. It is time that the Government took some responsibility for this disastrous situation. I would be grateful if the Minister for Transport and Communications (Senator Gareth Evans) could provide a response to the issues that I have raised in relation to this anti-dumping case.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-That is a pretty tall order since I have not been listening to what Senator Watson said. However, I shall undertake to refer the substance of his remarks to the relevant Minister who, I presume, is Senator Button, the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce. I conclude my remarks by expressing my own agreement with Senator Watson's characterisation of Senator Schacht's remarks which were extremely important and were remarks of which this Senate and nation should take very clear heed.

SPEECH.PARA: It was a tragic situation that evolved in Kampuchea over that terrible period in the 1970s. An unhappy situation continues to exist in that country. Through the efforts of Mr Hayden, in consultation and co-operation with all the South East Asian foreign Ministers and the great powers, Australia is doing its best to inject some rational possibility of solution into the situation. It is incumbent on all of us on a bipartisan basis to give him and the Government support in that objective. Senator Schacht's remarks contributed to our understanding not only of the present problem but also that which brought it about.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Senate adjourned at 7.55 p.m.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, upon notice, on 15 September 1987:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Can the Minister confirm the report in the Sunday Telegraph of 24 May 1987 that the Main People's Congress in Sydney received approximately $100,000 from the Libyan Government last year via the Australian Islamic Foundation.

(2) Is this funnelling of money in direct contradiction to the Prime Minister's statement at his press conference of 19 May 1987 that the Government would do all in its power to restrict the flow of funds from Libya to Australia.
(3) Can the Minister detail what has been done to stop the flow of Libyan money into Australia.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Main People's Congress referred to in Senator Puplick's question is located in Melbourne and not in Sydney. It is a matter of public knowledge that the Main People's Congress and the Basic People's Congress, a similar organisation located in Sydney, have received funds in the past from the Libyan Government. I am advised that these funds are primarily for organ- isational expenditure such as rent, office equipment, vehicle purchases and salaries.

(3) When the Government floated the Australian dollar, it removed almost all exchange control restrictions and requirements. Banks are not required to report the source of funds entering the country. Even if the Government were to decide to impose controls on the inflow of funds from individual countries it would prove extremely difficult to monitor and police such a decision given the scope for funds to be sent via third countries.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Vallentine Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, upon notice, on 15 September 1987:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) (a) What conferences has the Libyan Government sponsored in the last five years to which Australian and Pacific Islanders have been invited; (b) how many people attended them, and (c) from which countries did they come.

(2) (a) What military or para-military training programmes in Libya have South Pacific Islanders participated in during the last five years; (b) how long were these courses; (c) how many people took part; (d) which countries did they come from, and (e) what training was involved.

(3) (a) How much Libyan money has been lodged in bank accounts for individuals or political organisations in the South Pacific including Australia in the last five years; (b) which countries are concerned, and (c) which political organisations have received money.
(4) What other evidence exists of Libyan involvement (a) in Vanuatu; (b) in New Caledonia (c) with OPM representatives from West Papua/West Irian; and (d) with other Pacific Islands.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: The Government has sufficient information about the kinds of activity to which the honourable senator refers to justify the concern which it has expressed about the potentially adverse consequences of Libyan activities for harmony and stability in the South Pacific. The Government is not in a position, however, to make this information available.

These offers, combined with those for the period 1982-1985, total 81. The balance of the 88 referred to in the Department of Trade submission would be those made in 1986 up to the date of the submission.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, upon notice, on 17 September 1987:

QUESTION.PARA: What provision is made for bilingual or otherwise skilled staff in passport issuing offices throughout Australia.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: There are no special positions provided for bilingual or otherwise linguistically skilled staff in passport issuing offices nor in post offices which now interview the majority of passport applicants. Passport offices deal with Australians from a very wide range of ethnic backgrounds and it would not be possible to provide for all the mother tongues of these citizens. The Telephone Interpreter Service is available to passport staff and applicants and notices to this effect are displayed in Passport offices.

Staff in Passport offices with good language skills are encouraged to exercise their language skills both in interview situations and in dealing with foreign language documents. Multilingual staff in Passports offices, like other staff of the Department, are entitled to apply for payment of a language proficiency allowance.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Surgery on External Genitalia of Women

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Haines Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Community Services and Health, upon notice, on 22 September 1987:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What evidence does the Federal Government have of the incidence in Australia, on a state by state basis, of surgery to remove, infibulate or otherwise alter the external genitalia of women in a manner consistent with the documented cultural practices of a number of African and Middle Eastern nations, on the basis of claims under the Medicare Medical Benefits Schedule since 1980.

(2) Is any medical (as distinct from, for example, cultural) justification required to be given by the surgeon; if so, what reasons were given in what proportion of cases, where Medicare claims were made for such procedures.
(3) What was the breakdown by age of the women upon whom these procedures were performed.
(4) Are any other indications (besides the incidence of Medicare claims) available to the Government of the prevalence of these practices in Australia.

(5) What action has the Government taken or will it take to examine the occurrence of and to prohibit the performance of mutilation of female genitals by surgery, except in carefully identified cases of medical necessity, in the public and private health sectors and in the community.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Community Services and Health has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Two Items of the Medicare Benefits Schedule relate to surgery to the female genitals-Item 6299: amputation of the clitoris; and Item 6302: vulvectomy, vulvoplasty or labioplasty. The major medical indication for such surgery is the treatment of cancer or the correction of congenital deformity. Both these Items carry the qualification ``where medically indicated''-that is, there is not entitlement to claim benefits if the surgery is not medically indicated.

The qualification ``where medically indicated'' was included in the Schedule on 1 July 1985, specifically to address the issue of ritual female circumcision. Since that time, there has been no variation in the pattern of claims made for the two relevant Item numbers-6299 and 6302. This indicates that claims made under the Medicare Benefits Schedule are not related to the incidence of ritual female circumcision in Australia.

(2) Notwithstanding that the existence of a Medicare Benefits Schedule Item has not encouraged or promoted the practice of female circumcision, I have arranged for the Health Insurance Commission to ensure that appropriate medical indications apply before Medicare benefits are paid.

While this will not in itself diminish the practice, as traditionally female circumcision has been a ritual performed by non-professionals, generally older women from within the relevant communities, it will ensure that the costs are not underwritten through the Medicare Benefits Schedule.
(3) A breakdown of the incidence of claims over recent years is as follows:
Item 6299
Item 6302
Figures for the years prior to 1983/84 are not comparable because of changes to Medicare at that time.
Further breakdown of claims by States for the September 1986 quarter:
