These September quarter figures of 1986 are from a one-off test exercise on computer resources undertaken by the Department of Community Services and Health. No subsequent breakdown by States for Items 6299 and 6302 are available.
It should be noted that for Item 6299: Amputation of the clitoris-no claims were made for patients under the age of 30 years.
For Item 6302: Vulvectomy, vulvoplasty or labioplasty-no claims were made for patients under the age of 10 years. The majority of claims were for patients aged 30 to 50.
This age breakdown is consistent with the medical indications for such surgery-that is, treatment of cancer and correction of congenital deformity.

(4) From time to time, my Department and I have received representations concerning female genital mutilation practices, and attempts have been made to obtain as much information as possible about the situation in Australia. Attempts to elicit documented details from health authorities, general practitioners and interest groups have, however, not been successful. Much of the information concerning circumcision of female children is anecdotal. There is, for example, no record of children or women presenting to health services with any of the common complications of the more severe forms of ritual circumcision.

(5) The issues involved are complex and sensitive and, in Australia, have mainly been raised in the context of child abuse. It is the view of Australian health authorities that steps should be taken to discourage the practice through a low key educational approach. The World Health Organization reiterated in 1986 that change should not come from outside campaigners but from within communities where female circumcision is still entrenched. In Australia, health and welfare authorities in several States are developing policies and programs to assist the process of change within their communities. The most appropriate avenue for such an approach is seen to be through health care providers and relevant community and religious groups. Primarily, of course, the matter is one for consideration by the States.

Apart from education and persuasion, any preventive action by way of deterrence through prohibition would need to be taken through child welfare and/or criminal law authorities at State level. Such action should be on the basis of well considered strategies that take account of practicalities involved and any limitations that exist as regards the State's responsibilities for the welfare and protection of its residents.
For its part, my Department will continue to monitor the situation regarding the practice of ritual female circumcision in Australia.

The honourable senator will appreciate this answer is similar to that given her by Senator Tate on 26 May 1987, in response to the same question (Question No. 1653, page 2959/60). The present response incorporates relevant statistics and breakdowns, by age and State, of the September quarter 1986 figures for the appropriate Medicare item numbers.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Sanders Sen N.K.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, upon notice, on 7 October 1987:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What steps does the Federal Government intend to take to expand the carcass trade, given that contrary to the recommendations of the Senate Select Committee on Animal Welfare, the live sheep trade has expanded to 8 million animals in 1986-87?
(2) What has the Government done to actively seek alternatives to the live sheep trade?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) and (2). The Government supports the promotion of carcass exports, but will not place restrictive limitations on the live sheep trade provided professional animal welfare standards are maintained.

This policy has been given practical expression through the establishment of the Sheepmeat Market Development Fund to promote the Australian sheepmeat trade to the Middle East, and to assist expansion into new commercial outlets. Since the first full year of fund operations in 1983/84, Australian sheepmeat exports to all destinations have increased from approximately 90,000 tonnes to about 164,000 tonnes in 1986/87, with much of this growth being achieved in Middle East markets.

Over the 1983/84 to 1986/87 period, exports of live sheep from Australia increased from 7.2 million head to 7.9 million head. The occurrence of this moderate growth trend illustrates the continuing preference of many Arab consumers for fresh meat because of deeply seated cultural and religious traditions, notwithstanding the increase which has occurred in exports of sheepmeat to these markets. The report on live sheep exports by the Senate Select Committee on Animal Welfare acknowledged that this preference was likely to persist for some time to come.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, upon notice, on 20 October 1987:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Does the Federal Government intend to fulfil its second replenishment to the International Fund for Agricultural Development (IFAD); if not, why not.
(2) Does the Government intend to contribute to the Special IFAD programme for Sub-Saharan Africa; if not, why not.

(3) If the Government does intend to contribute, is it intended that this contribution will amount to the real value difference between Australia's First and Second Replenishment contributions to IFAD (A$6.4 million, 1986-1988).

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes, as announced in my press release of 8 November 1987, Australia will contribute $A8.48 million to the second replenishment of IFAD.

(2) No. As noted in the abovementioned press release Australia will also be contributing $A335 million to the eighth replenishment of the International Development Association (IDA). The IDA is the concessional lending arm of the World Bank. Contributions to IDA represent the major form of Australia's multilateral aid to Africa. Donors have agreed that 45-50 per cent of IDA-8 resources will be allocated to countries in Sub-Saharan Africa. This means that, in effect, Australia will be supporting about $A168 million of IDA commitments to Africa over the next three years.
(3) No. See answer to question 2 above.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, upon notice, on 20 October 1987:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Did Palau hold a plebiscite on 21 August 1987 to consider the acceptance of a Compact of Free Association with the United States of America.
(2) Did such plebiscite obtain 73 percent support.
(3) Does not the Constitution of Palau require a 75 percent majority to be carried; if not, by which process was this 75 percent majority dispensed with.

(4) Does the Australian Government consider such process to be constitutional; if so, is it not possible for the Australian Government to by-pass the constitutional provisions of the Australian Constitution in the same way

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade has provided the following answers to the honourable senator's questions:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes
(2) Yes
(3) The Constitution of Palau was amended in a referendum on 4 August 1987 to enable a simple (rather than three quarters) majority to approve the Compact of Free Association with the United States.
(4) The Australian Government considers that it is for the authorities in Palau to determine whether the referendum was in accordance with the provisions of the Palau Constitution.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: South Pacific: Natural Resources and Environment

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, upon notice, on 20 October 1987:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Does the Convention for the Protection and Development of the Natural Resources and Environment of the South Pacific region provide a significant international regime for the protection of the marine environment in the South Pacific and for a treaty prohibition of the disposal at sea of radioactive wastes.
(2) Is it a fact that the Australian Government has not yet signed the Convention.
(3) Is this because consultations are required between the Australian and State Governments before such signature and ratification; if so, why are such consultations required.
(4) What is the progress of such consultations and which State Governments are obstructing the process.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) When the Convention for the Protection and Development of the Natural Resources and Environment of the South Pacific region (SPREP Convention) enters into force it will provide a significant international regime for the protection of the marine environment in the South Pacific and a treaty prohibition on the dumping at sea of radioactive wastes. It also requires parties to control and prevent any pollution that might result from the testing of nuclear devices.
The SPREP Convention will complement and re- inforce the treaty of Rarotonga's prohibition on radio- active waste dumping at sea in the South Pacific Nuclear Free Zone.
The Convention and Protocols therefore meet important Australian interests.
Australia played a prominent role throughout the negotiations which led to the adoption of the Convention and Protocols at a meeting of plenipotentiaries held in Noumea in November 1986.
The Convention has the strong support of the South Pacific Forum.

(2) to (4) It is essential that before Australia signs and ratifies an international agreement that Australian domestic legislation be consistent with our obligations under the agreement. There has for years been a system for consultations between the Federal and State and Northern Territory Governments on any treaty to which Australia is considering becoming a party. In fact, Australian domestic legislation is assessed to be already generally consistent with the requirements of the SPREP Convention, and consultations designed to confirm this (which began early last year) are now nearing completion.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, upon notice, on 20 October:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is it a fact that the United States of America does not recognise coastal state jurisdiction over highly migratory species of fish, i.e. tuna, affecting the sovereignty of Pacific Island states over such produce.
(2) What is the reason for this attitude of the U.S. Government.
(3) What representations has the Federal Government made to the U.S. Government in order to overcome this problem.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) to (3) The United States Government does not accept that coastal states have jurisdiction in their respective exclusive economic zones over highly migratory species of fish because of the frequency with which the species move between areas of the high seas and respective national exclusive economic zones.

In respect to tuna fishing in the South Pacific, the United States signed, on 2 April, a multilateral fisheries access treaty with twelve Members of the Forum Fisheries Agency under which it will pay US$60 million over a five year period to fish in the EEZs of parties to the treaty under mutually agreed conditions. As at 16 October, fifteen Members of the Forum Fisheries Agency have signed the Agreement. The treaty will enter into force when ratified by ten South Pacific parties including Papua New Guinea, the Federated States of Micronesia and Kiribati and by the United States.

Australia made strong and sustained representations to the United States Government including at high political levels to help achieve this treaty and participated in all ten rounds of negotiations between the Pacific parties and the United States. The United States Senate unanimously agreed to the ratification of the multilateral fisheries access treaty on 6 November 1987.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, upon notice, on 20 October 1987:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is it a fact that the World Bank has been unwilling to provide funds to all Pacific Island Forum countries to assist in the implementation of the South Pacific Telecommunications Development Program; if so, has there been any World Bank involvement in this project.
(2) What representations has the Federal Government made to the World Bank seeking a review of its decision.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) There has been considerable discussion between the managerial staff of the South Pacific Telecommunications Development Program (SPTDP) and the World Bank concerning World Bank funding of telecommunications projects within the South Pacific region. The World Bank has advised the Director of the South Pacific Bureau for Economic Cooperation (SPEC), the organisation under which the SPTDP has been established, that the Bank is willing to support telecommunications development in the South Pacific. However, the World Bank noted that there are important prerequisites to be met for the Bank to proceed with preparation and financing of a regional project involving several countries. These prerequisites are that: countries seeking financing must be Bank Members; the Bank needs confirmation from these countries that they desire to borrow from the Bank for such a project; there is agreement among the governments concerned on the role of the SPTDP in preparing and in implementing the project; and there is a statement of intent among those governments to cooperate in areas such as procurement, design, training and maintenance.

As yet, these prerequisites have not been met. South Pacific World Bank members attending a July 1987 meeting of the management group of SPTDP (i.e. Fiji, Kiribati, PNG, Solomon Islands, Tonga and Vanuatu) indicated that their governments were either not interested in seeking World Bank funding through the SPTDP or had not yet decided to do so. Consultations between SPEC and relevant member countries are continuing and have not as yet resulted in a final application for World Bank funding.
(2) In light of the above circumstances Australia has made no formal representation to the World Bank on this issue.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, upon notice, on 22 October 1987:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is it a fact that in the recent Referendum held by the French Government in New Caledonia the voters were asked to take one of two different coloured ballot slips, one colour indicating a desire for Independence, another indicating a desire to remain part of France.
(2) Does such electoral procedure indicate that the ballot was not a secret one.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) In the recent referendum held by the French Government in New Caledonia, voters were provided with two ballot slips, one yellow expressing a desire for independence and another blue expressing a desire to remain a part of France, as well as a single envelope. Voting took place in secrecy in polling booths supervised by magistrates sent from metropolitan France especially for the purpose. Voters were invited to place their preferred ballot slip in a sealed envelope before placing it in the ballot box provided. There were no instructions as to what voters should do with the other ballot slip. This was left to their own discretion.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, upon notice, on 20 November 1987:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) In view of the leading role played by the President of Costa Rica, Oscar Arias Sanchez, in attempting to reach a peaceful solution to the conflict in Central America, can the Minister say whether: (a) U.S. funds between $85 and $140 million have been withheld from Costa Rica since President Arias' initiative; (b) the Reagan Administration has imposed bans and restrictions on flowers, clothing and other Costa Rican exports to the U.S.; and (c) the U.S. Government in August 1987 and for the first time refused to intervene with American banks on Costa Rica's behalf.
(2) Does the Australian Government agree with this sort of pressure placed on a Government which is earnestly pursuing the cause for peace.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) (a) to (c). The United States Administration has denied that it is withholding economic assistance from Costa Rica, curtailing Costa Rican imports or refusing to intervene on Costa Rica's behalf with its commercial creditors. The Costa Rican Government, through its Ambassador in Washington, confirmed that United States economic assistance was not suspended but that delays occurred in the implementation of the 1987 program, largely due to technical factors related to concurrent negotiations involving multilateral financial institutions and commercial banks. Costa Rica's exports to the United States grew from US$451 million in 1983 to US$726 million in 1986-some anti-dumping measures have been taken and/or quotas have been imposed on a range of products (e.g. some agricultural products, flowers and textiles). The United States has supported efforts to provide Costa Rica with new loans.

(2) The position of the Costa Rican Government is that disagreements with the United States over United States policy in Central America have not resulted in any sanction, reprisal or pressure against Costa Rica. The Australian Government has long supported the efforts of the Central American countries to achieve a durable settlement of their problems.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: McLean Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Community Services and Health, upon notice, on 26 November 1987:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Can the term ``Health Screening'' be defined as services that are not reasonably required for the management of the medical condition of the patient.
(2) For what medical services, other than pathology, can the term ``Health Screening'' be applied.
(3) Are these same services, including pathology, often classified by the Health Insurance Commission (H.I.C.) as tools of diagnosis and management of an illness.
(4) What criteria does the H.I.C. use to determine whether such services are ``Health Screening'' or tools of ``diagnosis and management of an illness''.
(5) Does one of the criteria refer to the frequency of use of a particular service by a particular doctor.
(6) Is it correct that services classified as ``Health Screening'' are not subject to a Medicare rebate, whereas services classified as ``diagnosis and management'' are subject to a Medicare rebate.

(7) Does the H.I.C. notify in advance those doctors whose services they deem to be ``Health Screening'' and are those same doctors informed as to the reasons why such services are so classified; if not, why not.
(8) Does the H.I.C. keep a list of doctors whose services are classified as ``Health Screening''; if so, how does a doctor have his/her name removed from the list.
(9) What are the names and addresses of every doctor, in each State and Territory, who have in the past, or who are currently, on such a list and for what services are they on that list.

(10) What guarantees, if any, can the Minister give to members of the public such that they will always receive financial reimbursement from Medicare for those services currently on the Medical Benefits Schedule.
(11) What criteria does the H.I.C. use when deciding who, or which organisations, will be given access to individual patient records.
(12) What safeguards are there to ensure patient confidentiality.
(13) What medical qualifications, including areas of expertise, are required of medical assessors from the H.I.C.
(14) Why is there no medically qualified arbitration system available to settle disputes between an individual doctor and the H.I.C.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Community Services and Health has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes.
(2) Any examination or test conducted to obtain information about a patient which would not ordinarily be sought in reaching a diagnosis suggested by the patient's history and physical examination.
(3) Yes.

(4) The Commission's medical advisers identify multi system testing which suggests a screening process. Supporting clinical information is then requested from the treating doctor to satisfy the Commission's medical referee of a relationship between the tests in question and the management of the patient's condition which includes the establishment of a diagnosis.

(5) Where a particular doctor has become a common factor in a number of claims which have been recognised as screening, the Commission has a responsibility to monitor that practitioner's servicing which includes his generation of pathology services.
(6) Yes.
(7) Upon identification of a doctor as a common factor in such claims, the Commission's medical advisers seek contact with that doctor
(a) to explain section 19 (5) of the Health Insurance Act, 1973, and its application;
(b) to ensure full understanding of the Medicare scheme; and
(c) to allow the doctor the opportunity to warn patients that certain services may not attract Medicare benefit.

(10) The Health Insurance Act sets out to provide a benefit for medical services which are reasonably necessary to provide adequate medical care. the only limiting factor for services in the Medicare Benefits Schedule is that of patient need. The Act does not place an obligation upon doctors as to how they should practise. If a doctor chooses to provide services which are not necessary to provide adequate medical care, benefits are not payable. This was also the case prior to the introduction of Medicare.
(11) & (12) Section 130 of the Act prevents the disclosure of individual patient claims' information by the Commission or its officers.

(13) All medical advisers are well qualified and experienced in medical practice. The majority hold post graduate qualifications. The Commission also employs consultants in some specialities notably radiology and pathology.

(14) There are a number of learned professional societies and Royal Colleges which are the arbiters of excellence in medicine and it is to these bodies that medical practitioners should turn for support in seeking acceptance of policy change for services currently precluded from benefit by section 19 (5) of the Act. My Department may also seek opinion from such bodies in the event of continued dispute.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, upon notice, on 14 December 1987:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What information can the Minister supply in regard to the violence presently taking place in the Jaffna Peninsula area of Sri Lanka.

(2) Is the Minister aware of a specific incident which occurred on 16 and 17 October 1987 in the town of Urumbirai, in which elderly and sick people were shot by Indian soldiers in their homes, after the town had fallen and the young had fled; if so, have any representations about this type of abuse by a ``Peace Keeping'' Force been made to the Indian Government.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The security situation in the Jaffna Peninsula appears to be slowly improving. The Indian Peace Keeping Forces (IPKF) are now moving ahead with operations aimed at locating and disarming Liberation Tigers of Tamil Elam (LTTE) cadres and cutting off their supply routes. Although the unilateral 48 hour ceasefire on 21-22 November called by the Government of India was allowed to lapse without extension in the face of continued intransigence by the LTTE, there have been relatively few clashes between the IPKF and the LTTE in the Jaffna area over the past month.

(2) The full picture of the recent fighting in Jaffna is not known and it is difficult to comment on specific allegations or to distinguish propaganda from fact. It is clear, however, that there were unfortunately many civilian casualties, as would be expected from fighting in a heavily populated area. Both sides were responsible for civilian deaths. It was, however, the LTTE's choice to stand and fight a pitched battle in Jaffna town, with civilian casualties being the inevitable result. The Australian Government on many occasions has urged the parties to the Accord and all those who are genuinely concerned for the welfare of the people of Sri Lanka to reject violence and work together to give the Accord the chance of success it deserves.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Department of Community Services and Health: Logo

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Coates Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Community Services and Health, upon notice, on 16 December 1987:

QUESTION.PARA: Does the new logo for the Minister's department have a meaning; if so, what is that meaning.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Community Services and Health has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: The logo does not have a specific meaning.
It was agreed upon after consultation among Departmental staff at all levels because they felt that it depicted the three former agencies unified into one body.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 23 October 1987 (Hansard, page 1171) Senator Teague asked a question without notice concerning the Halton Task Force on Training and Education. The Minister for Employment, Education and Training has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: No single definitive report has been or will be delivered by Mr Halton because of the wide ranging and complex inquiries undertaken by the Task Force. The media release of 15 October 1987 and accompanying proposal encapsulate the Government's consideration of the advice received during the inquiry.

Advice received prior to the announcement of 15 October formed the first of a two phase consultation process. As a result of this first phase a proposal for the rationalisation of Employment, Education and Training advisory structures was developed.
The aim of the second phase is to allow interested parties the opportunity to comment in detail on the proposals before the final decisions are taken.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jones Sen G.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for the Environment and the Arts, upon notice, on 15 September 1987:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What action can be taken by the Federal Government, in view of various media reports of 26 August 1987 indicating a decision the previous day by the Queensland Cabinet to allow a private road to cut through 30 kms of rainforest, a Crown timber reserve, and a pine plantation from an area north of Mareeba to a point on the main Captain Cook Highway between Cairns and Port Douglas, to prevent this decision being implemented in view of the Hawke administration's proposal to list the area in the proposed World Heritage legislation.

(3) Is a Mr George Quaid a common director of both companies.

(5) Is there any link established by the Commonwealth Government in its investigations between Mr Quaid, either of the aforementioned companies, the National Party in Queensland, the Bjelke-Petersen Foundation or the Premier of Queensland himself.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

(2) I am advised that the road is being constructed by the Southedge Daintree Pastoral Company to provide access between the Company's tourist development near Round Mountain and the coast at Wangetti Beach.
(3) and (4) I have no information on these matters. The information may be obtainable from the Queensland Corporate Affairs Office, Brisbane.
(5) No investigation of these matters has been undertaken by my Department.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Sanders Sen N.K.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories:

QUESTION.PARA: Is the Australian Government promoting kangaroo products for Expo 88 in Brisbane.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: No. Indeed whilst there will be a retail outlet attached to the Australian Pavilion the sale of kangaroo products, or any other products from native animals, will be prohibited.
